binding.literal: A group of persons sharing a home or living space, who aggregate and share their incomes, as evidenced by the fact that they regularly take meals together. (Source: SOCIOL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Goods needed for living in a household.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) Dwelling-houses collectively and the provision of these. 2) Shelter, lodging.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The number of dwelling units or the residential population of a given geographic area. (Source: MIB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An addition, renovation or repair to a place of residence that increases its aesthetic, functional or financial value. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A binding rule or body of rules prescribed by a government to regulate the buying, selling, leasing, construction or maintenance of dwelling places. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A planned system of projects, services or activities intended to support individuals or families in need of shelter, including transitional or permanent housing and safe havens for low-income, elderly or homeless populations. (Source: HUD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A norm or measure applicable in legal cases and considered to reflect a relatively high grade or level of excellence in the construction, maintenance, operation, occupancy, use or appearance of dwelling units. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of repairing or reconstructing an edifice in order to return it to its original condition. (Source: ZINZANa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The study of human life and character. (Source: ZINZAN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An interruption, cessation or disorder of human bodily functions, systems or organs resulting from genetic or developmental errors, infection, nutritional deficiency, toxicity, illness or unfavorable environmental factors. (Source: SMD / ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The study of the growth, distribution, and organization of human communities relative to their interrelationships with other humans and other species and with their environment. (Source: UNUN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The avoidance of disease and injury and the promotion of normalcy through efficient use of the environment, a properly functioning society, and an inner sense of well-being. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Violent, sudden and destructive change in the environment caused by man. (Source: ISEP / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Branch of medicine concerned with the cause, origin, and nature of disease, including the changes occurring as a result of disease. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A branch of biological sciences that studies the functions of organs and tissues in human beings. (Source: OMD / WOR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Group of individuals having common characteristics. (Source: ZINZAN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The rights of individuals to liberty, justice, etc. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Cities, towns, villages, and other concentrations of human populations which inhabit a given segment or area of the environment. Human settlements are associated with numerous and complex environmental, pollution, and living condition problems for planning and management. (Source: UNUN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The more or less decomposed organic matter in the soil. Besides being the source of most of the mineral salts needed by plants, humus improves the texture of the soil and holds water, so reducing the loss of nutrients by leaching. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The pursuit and killing or capture of wild animals, regarded as a sport. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Area of land where the pursuit and killing or capture of game and wild animals is permitted. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A tropical cyclone of great intensity; any wind reaching a speed of more than 73 miles per hour (117 kilometers per hour) is said to have hurricane force. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act or process of producing hybrids that is an animal or plant resulting from a cross between genetically unlike individuals. Hybrids between different species are usually sterile. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any structure built to route the flow of water, or to support the weight and pressure of a body of water. (Source: ENC / LIV)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A branch of civil engineering concerned with the design, erection, and construction of sewage disposal plants, waterworks, dams, water-operated power plants and such. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The branch of science and technology concerned with the mechanics of fluids, especially liquids. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Study of organisms living in water. (Source: ZINZAN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A very large group of chemical compounds composed only of carbon and hydrogen. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A solution of hydrogen chloride gas in water; a poisonous, pungent liquid forming a constant-boiling mixture at 20% concentration in water; widely used as a reagent, in organic synthesis, in acidizing oil wells, ore reduction, food processing, and metal cleaning and pickling. Also known as muriatic acid. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Growing plants without soil but in sand or vermiculite or other granular material, using a liquid solution of nutrients to feed them. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Power station which operates with the free renewable source of energy provided by falling water. (Source: PORT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A flammable colourless gas that is the lightest and most abundant element in the universe. It occurs mainly in water and in most organic compounds and is used in the production of ammonia and other chemicals, in the hydrogenation of fats and oils, and in welding. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Flammable, poisonous gas with characteristic odour of rotten eggs, perceptible in air in a dilution of 0.002 mg/l. It is used as a reagent in chemical analysis; extremely hazardous; collapse, coma and death from respiratory failure may come within a few seconds after one or two inspirations; low concentrations produce irritation of conjunctiva and mucous membranes. Headache, dizziness, nausea, lassitude may appear after exposure. (Source: MGH / INDMER)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The science dealing with the occurrence of surface and ground water, its utilization, and its functions in modifying the earth, primarily by erosion and deposition. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Science which deals with the measurement and description of the physical features of the oceans, lakes, rivers, and their adjoining coastal areas, with particular reference to their control and utilization. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Violent, sudden and destructive change either in the quality of the earth's water or in the distribution or movement of water on land, below the surface or in the atmosphere. (Source: ISEP / APD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An accounting of the inflow to, outflow from, and storage in a hydrologic unit such as a drainage basin, aquifer, soil zone, lake or reservoir; the relationship between evaporation, precipitation, runoff, and the change in water storage. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The movement of water between the oceans, ground surface and atmosphere by evaporation, precipitation and the activity of living organisms, as one of the mayor biogeochemical cycles. Each day water evaporates from the oceans and is carried in the air from the sea over the land, which receives it as precipitation, and finally returns from the land to the sea through rivers, thus completing the cycle. (Source: ALLa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The science that treats the occurrence, circulation, distribution, and properties of the waters of the earth, and their reaction with the environment. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) Decomposition or alteration of a chemical substance by water. 2) In aqueous solutions of electrolytes, the reactions of cations with water to produce a weak base or of anions to produce a weak acid. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: That part of meteorology of direct concern to hydrologic problems, particularly to flood control, hydroelectric power, irrigation, and similar fields of engineering and water resource. (Source: ZINZAN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Energy obtained from natural or artificial waterfalls, either directly by turning a water wheel or turbine, or indirectly by generating electricity in a dynamo driven by a turbine. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The waters of the Earth, as distinguished from the rocks (lithosphere), living things (biosphere), and the air (atmosphere). Includes the waters of the ocean; rivers, lakes, and other bodies of surface water in liquid form on the continents; snow, ice, and glaciers; and liquid water, ice, and water vapour in both the unsaturated and saturated zones below the land surface. Included by some, but excluded by others, is water in the atmosphere , which includes water vapour, clouds, and all forms of precipitation while still in the atmosphere. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The science that deals with the principles and practices of good health. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Insects including bees, wasps, ants, and sawflies, having two pair of membranous wings and an ovipositor specialized for stinging, sawing or piercing. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The dense substance formed by the freezing of water to the solid state; it commonly occurs in the form of hexagonal crystals. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A large mass of detached land ice floating in the sea or stranded in shallow water. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Large areas of floating ice, usually occurring in polar seas, consisting of separate pieces that have become massed together. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The determination of the specific substance or substances that are causing pollution. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A body of ideas that reflects the beliefs and interest of a nation, political system, etc. and underlies political action. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of converting 'raw' remotely sensed data into a usable form through the application of various transformations such as supervised and unsupervised classification schemes. (Source: FORUMT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Codes published by Intergovernmental Maritime Consultative Organisation (IMCO) relating to international shipping, particularly regarding safety and marine pollution. (Source: BRACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: One of the possible consequences of the introduction of animal species in an area where they are not indigenous. Such translocation of species always involves an element of risk if not of serious danger. Newly arrived species may be highly competitive with or otherwise adversely affect native species and communities. (Source: RRDA / WPRa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: One of the possible consequences of the introduction of plant species in an area where they are not indigenous. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The reception of material, such as pollutants, by the environment and from any source. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Legislative and administrative procedures aimed at reducing the damage caused by emissions. Pollution control programmes are normally based on human-oriented acceptable dose limits. A very important measure concerns the organisation of an emission inventory. (Source: GOODa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Damage caused by pollution from a distinct source of emission. (Source: GILP96)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The prediction of immissions is calculated on the basis of the pollutant load, the source height, the wind speed and the dispersion coefficient. (Source: FLGISA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Maximum levels of selected pollutants which would lead to unacceptable air quality. (Source: PORT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The total amount of immissions introduced in a given environment. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A body system that helps an organism to resist disease, through the activities of specialised blood cells or antibodies produced by them in response to natural exposure or inoculation. (Source: KOREN / CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The ability of an organism to resist disease or toxins by natural or artificial means. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any of several methods for the quantitative determination of chemical substances such as hormones, drugs, and certain proteins that utilize the highly specific binding between an antigen and an antibody. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The disruption of the complex system of interacting cells, cell products and cell-forming tissues that protects the body from pathogens, destroys infected and malignant cells and removes cellular debris. (Source: SMD / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A branch of biological science concerned with the native or acquired resistance of higher animal forms and humans to infection with microorganisms. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Evaluation of the effect of a project upon the environment. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Actions, procedures or installations undertaken to reduce the extent or degree of negative effects on human health and the ecosystem introduced by human design or interaction with the environment. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Instrument which samples atmospheric suspensoids by impaction; such instruments consist of a housing which constrains the air flow past a sensitized sampling plate. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Precautionary measures, actions or installations implemented to avert negative effects on the environment. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Elements of an action which cause damage to the surrounding environment. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act of bringing goods and merchandise into a country from a foreign country. (Source: WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Permission from a government to bring within its borders and sell a product manufactured in a foreign country. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A material used to fill holes in wood, plaster, or other surfaces before applying a coating such as paint or varnish. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The forcing of a liquid substance into the spaces of a porous solid in order to change its properties, as the impregnation of wood with creosote to preserve its integrity against water damage. (Source: MGHa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The beneficial development or progress in the volume of output that is achieved in terms of productivity and input, or in getting the maximum possible output from given or allocated resources. (Source: ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Sudden immission in considerable amount of one or more pollutants in the atmosphere, in a water body or in the soil. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Noise characterized by transient short-duration disturbances distributed essentially uniformly over the useful passband of a transmission system. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Controlled process by which solid, liquid, or gaseous combustible wastes are burned and changed into gases; residue produced contains little or no combustible material. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The controlled burning of solid, liquid, or gaseous combustible wastes to produce gases and solid residues containing little or no combustible material in order to reduce the bulk of the original waste materials. (Source: ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The inclined surface of any part of the Earth's surface, as a hillslope; also, a broad part of a continent descending toward an ocean, as the Pacific slope. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The gain derived from capital, from labour or effort, or both combined, including profit or gain through sale or conversion of capital. (Source: WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Financial compensation, reimbursement or security for damages or loss offered by a government, insurance policy or contractual agreement under specified conditions and for specific casualties. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A body of water between the continents of Africa, Antarctica, Asia and Australia including the Bay of Bengal in the east and the Arabian Sea (with the Red Sea, the Gulf of Aden and the Persian Gulf) in the west, and containing several islands and island chains, such as the Andaman, Nicobar and Seychelles. (Source: INP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Something that provides an indication especially of trends. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Qualitative or quantitative parameter used as a measure of an environmental condition, e.g. of air or water quality. (Source: DIZAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Forests which are native to a given area. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Technologies employed by the native inhabitants of a country and which constitute an important part of its cultural heritage and should therefore be protected against exploitation by industrialized countries; the problem of indigenous knowledge has been discussed during the Rio Conference but it does not receive much protection under the Biodiversity Convention. Article 8 mandates that parties "respect, preserve and maintain knowledge, innovations and practices of indigenous and local communities embodying traditional life styles... and promote their wider application with the approval and involvement of holders of such knowledge, innovations and practices and encourage the equitable sharing of benefits arising from them". (Source: RRDA / WRES)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A non-domestic source introducing pollutants into a publicly owned waste-treatment system. Indirect dischargers can be commercial or industrial facilities whose wastes enter local sewers. (Source: EPAGLO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Chemical, physical or biological contaminants in the air inside buildings and other enclosed spaces occupied by humans. This pollution can arise from tobacco smoke, pesticides, cleaning agents, gases released from building materials, rugs, household products, etc. (Source: EED / ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Environment situated in the inside of a house or other building. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Areas allocated for industry within a town-planning scheme or environmental plan. The range of industries accommodated in a plan may include: light industry, service industry, general industry, hazardous, noxious or offensive industry, waterfront industry, extractive industry. Standards are usually defined for industrial areas relating to access and roads, drainage, car parking, aesthetics, landscaping, buffer zones, noise levels, and air and water pollution. (Source: GILP96)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A building directly used in manufacturing or technically productive enterprises. Industrial buildings are not generally or typically accessible to other than workers. Industrial buildings include buildings used directly in the production of power, the manufacture of products, the mining of raw materials, and the storage of textiles, petroleum products, wood and paper products, chemicals, plastics, and metals. (Source: JJK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any crop that provides materials for industrial processes and products such as soybeans, cotton (lint and seed), flax, and tobacco. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The disposal of any waste generated by a manufacturing or processing process by the agency or body which produced it. (Source: RHW / ERG)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The production, distribution, and consumption of goods and services resulting from all manufacturing business. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Materials generally discarded from industrial operations or derived from manufacturing processes. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Gas-borne pollutants discharged into the atmosphere from smokestacks of industrial plants. (Source: LEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The guiding procedure, philosophy or course of action for the protection of natural resources from pollution generated by manufacturing or business enterprises. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Equipment related to industrial activities. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any smokelike or vaporous exhalation from matters or substances, especially of an odorous or harmful nature, which result from trading, commercial or manufacturing processes. (Source: RHW / ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A device, system or piece of equipment installed for a particular industry. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process whereby manufacturing industry comes to occupy the predominant position in a national or regional economy. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A binding rule or body of rules prescribed by a government to regulate working conditions or the acquisition, processing and disposal of materials by the aggregate of factories, companies and enterprises in one or more manufacturing or technically productive fields. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The branch of medicine which deals with the relationship of humans to their occupations, for the purpose of the prevention of disease and injury and the promotion of optimal health, productivity, and social adjustment. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Noise produced by industrial plants activities.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of making arrangements or preparations to facilitate the manufacturing, producing and processing of goods or merchandise. (Source: RHW / ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Buildings where the operations related to industrial productive processes are carried out. (Source: ZINZAN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Course of action adopted by national government to support and promote industrial activities. (Source: GOODa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Pollution as a result of industrial processes and manufacturing. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any process of converting or transforming raw materials and other resources into goods or services which have value. (Source: ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A justifiable claim granted by government or some other authority that offers protection or excludes others from making, using or selling an invention, a unique design of an article of manufacture or some other creation or discovery. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The location for the individual manufacturing firm. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Sludge produced as a result of industrial production processes or manufacturing.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A large-scale community with diverse manufacturing sectors and an infrastructure and economy based on the science, technology and instrumental rationality of the modern West. (Source: FUT / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Waste materials discarded from industrial operations, or derived from manufacturing processes; may be solid, sludge (wet solids) or liquid wastes and may or may not be considered hazardous. (Source: HMD / ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Waste gases resulting from manufacturing and other industrial processes which may be treated and released, treated and reused or released without treatment. (Source: ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Waste water that results from industrial processes and manufacturing. It may either be disposed of separately or become part of the sanitary or combined sewage.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A system of land use planning that forms zones or boundaries to be used only by manufacturing or business enterprises. (Source: ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An industry is a group of establishments engaged in the same or similar kinds of economic activities. Industries produce commodities that are sold with the expectation of recovering the total cost of production. A single industry can produce many different commodities. (Source: PGE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of waste inertisation includes solidification and stabilisation; stabilisation is the process used for reduction of hazard potential of the waste by converting the contaminants into their least soluble, least immobile, or least toxic form. Solidification physically binds or encapsulates the waste in a monolithic solid of high structural integrity. Thus solidification may be used for powders, liquids or gases. (Source: ENVAR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Wastes that do not undergo any significant physical, chemical, or biological transformations when deposited in a landfill.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The rate of deaths occurring in the first year of life for a given population. (Source: MED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The entry and development or multiplication of an infectious agent in the body of a living organism. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Pathogenic condition resulting from invasion of an host by a pathogen that propagates causing infection. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Invasion of crop by parasites. Among vertebrate animals, many crop pests are mammals, especially in the order of rodents and birds. Among invertebrates, certain species of gastropods and a large number of roundworms from the class of nematodes harm crops. The most varied and numerous species of crop pests are arthropods-insects, arachnids and some species of millipedes and crustaceans. Diseases vary from viral, bacterial, and nutritional to fungal, environmental and non-specific. The FAO has estimated that annual worldwide losses done by plant pests and diseases amount to approximately 20-25% of the potential worldwide yield of food crops. (Source: RRDA / WPR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Food that has been contaminated and deteriorated by some kind of pest. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Movement of water through the soil surface into the ground. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Substance liable to catch fire. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) Water other than wastewater that enters a sewer system (including sewer service connections) from sources such as, but not limited to, roof leaders, cellars drains, yard drains, area drains, drains from springs and swampy areas, manhole covers, cross connections between storm sewers and sanitary sewers, catch basins, cooling towers, storm waters, surface runoff, street wash waters, or drainage. Inflow does not include, and is distinguished from, infiltration. 2) Action of flowing in; an inflow of effluent into a river. (Source: JJK / PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Science and technique of data elaboration and of automatic treatment of information. (Source: ZINZAN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: All facts, ideas or imaginative works of the mind which have been communicated, published or distributed formally or informally in any format, or the knowledge that is communicated or received. (Source: CCL / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A systematic series of actions performed by a person or computer on data elements including classifying, sorting, calculating, summarizing, transmitting, retrieving and receiving. (Source: JON)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An organized system of providing assistance or aid to individuals who are seeking information, such as by using databases and other information sources to communicate or supply knowledge or factual data. (Source: RHW / OMD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Generally, any resource initiating and substantiating the reception of knowledge or specifically, the origin of a data transmission. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any coordinated assemblage of persons, devices and institutions used for communicating or exchanging knowledge or data, such as by simple verbal communication, or by completely computerized methods of storing, searching and retrieving information. (Source: MHD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The systems, equipment, components and software required to ensure the retrieval, processing and storage of information in all centres of human activity (home, office, factory, etc.), the application of which generally requires the use of electronics or similar technology. (Source: ECHO2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A breach, violation, or infringement; as of a law, a contract, a right or duty. (Source: BLACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Electron magnetic radiation whose wavelengths lie in the range from 0.75 or 0.8 micrometer to 1000 micrometers. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Vibrations of the air at frequencies too low to be perceived as sound by the human ear, below about 15 hertz. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The basic network or foundation of capital facilities or community investments which are necessary to support economic and community activities. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A person occupying a region, town, house, country, etc.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A stress upon an organism that disrupts the structure or function and results in a pathological process. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A dispersion of a pigment or a solution of a dye in a carrier vehicle, yielding a fluid, paste, or powder to be applied to and dried on a substrate; writing, marking, drawing, and printing inks are applied by several methods to paper, metal, plastic, wood, glass, fabric, or other substrate. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Fishing grounds located in lakes, streams, etc. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The navigation of inland waterways, i.e. navigable rivers, canals, sounds, lakes, inlets, etc.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A lake, river, or other body of water wholly within the boundaries of a state. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Transportation of persons and goods by boats travelling on rivers, channels or lakes. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Something newly introduced, such as a new method or device. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A branch of chemistry dealing with the chemical reactions and properties of all inorganic matter. (Source: LEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Inorganic chemical which promotes plant growth by enhancing the supply of essential nutrients such as ammonium sulphate or lime. (Source: PORT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A pollutant of mineral origin and not of basically carbon structure. (Source: ERG)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Chemical compounds that do not contain carbon as the principal element (excepting carbonates, cyanides, and cyanates), that is, matter other than plant or animal. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any chemical agent used to destroy invertebrate pests. (Source: LBC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any placental mammal of the order Insectivora, being typically small, with simple teeth, and feeding on invertebrates. The group includes shrews, moles, and hedgehogs. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A class of the Arthropoda typically having a segmented body with an external, chitinous covering, a pair of compound eyes, a pair of antennae, three pairs of mouthparts, and two pairs of wings. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: In the natural or normal place. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An official examination and evaluation of the extent to which specified goals, objectives, standards, policies or procedures of an agency, organization, department or unit have been met properly. (Source: DAM)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An organization designated to look into, supervise and report upon, the staff members and workings of some institution or department, or the conforming to laws and regulations by a segment of society or other group. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The official authorization needed to assemble and place into position any apparatus, facility, military post or machinery. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The establishment and normalization of a law, custom, usage, practice, system or regulative principle in the activity or purpose of a group or organization. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Material used to reduce the transmission of sound to or from a body, device, room, etc. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act, system, or business of providing financial protection contingencies, such as death, loss or damage and involving payment of regular premiums in return for a policy guaranteeing such protection. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A commercial service which provides a guarantee against most losses or harm to a person, property or a firm in return for premiums paid. (Source: RHW / ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The protection provided against risks or a risk, often as specified by the type of protection or the item being protected. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Areas allocated to preserve and protect certain animals and plants, or both. They differ from national parks, which are largely a place for public recreation, because they are provided exclusively to protect species for their own sake. Endangered species are increasingly being kept in nature reserves to prevent them from extinction. Nature reserves also serve as a place for more plentiful species to rest, breed or winter. (Source: WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Technologies that meet environmental objectives by incorporating pollution prevention concepts in their design. Integrated environmental control strategies introduced in the early design stages of a process, rather than an end-of-pipe control option introduced in the later stages, improve the technical and economic performance of a process. (Source: ENVAR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A systematic, comprehensive approach to pest control that uses the insect's or rodent's own biology and behaviour to find the least toxic control methods at the lowest cost. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A procedure whereby all major emissions to land, air, and water are considered simultaneously and not in isolation to avoid situations in which one control measure for one medium adversely affects another. (Source: GILP96)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Specialized system of breeding animals where the livestock are kept indoors and fed on concentrated foodstuffs, with frequent use of drugs to control diseases which are a constant threat under these conditions. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Farming in which as much use is made of the land as possible by growing crops close together or by growing several crops in a year or by using large amounts of fertilizers. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The enhancement of activity of pesticides when they are used in combination with others. (Source: PARCOR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A transference of binary coded information items between two or more computers across any communications channel capable of carrying electromagnetic signals. (Source: WIC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The utilisation, combination and coordination of two or more appropriate disciplines, technologies and humanities in an integrated approach toward environmental problems. (Source: UNUN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A sum paid or charged for the use of money or for borrowing money over a given time period. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A group of people who share common traits, attitudes, beliefs or objectives and who have formed a formal organization to serve specific concerns of the membership. (Source: AUB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Tests performed at the same time in different laboratories to validate the quality of the results. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Partly finished goods or products that re-enter into production elsewhere. (Source: ISEP / MGHME)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Noise occurring at regular or irregular intervals. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Cooperation in international efforts to support global environmental goals. Solutions to environmental problems such as trans-boundary airborne and waterborne pollution, ozone depletion and climate change require action by all responsible countries. (Source: WRES)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The ability of firms to strive with rivals in the production and sale of commodities in worldwide markets. (Source: ODE / OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Treaties and other agreements of a contractual character between different countries or organizations of states creating legal rights and obligations between the parties. (Source: BLACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The collaboration between governments, businesses or individuals in which it is agreed to work together on similar objectives or strategies, particularly in research or in setting industrial standards. (Source: ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Judicial arm of the United Nations. It has jurisdiction to give advisory opinions on matters of law and treaty construction when requested by the General Assembly, Security Council or any other international agency authorised by the General Assembly to petition for such opinion. It has jurisdiction, also, to settle legal disputes between nations when voluntarily submitted to it. (Source: BLACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The worldwide allocating of resources or dispersing of goods. (Source: ISEP / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The political or diplomatic interaction or dealings between independent nations that pertain to ecological concerns. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Harmonisation of the interrelationship of sovereign states by the application of general principles recognized by civilized nations. (Source: DICLAWa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The system of law regulating the interrelationship of sovereign states and their rights and duties with regard to one another. (Source: DICLAW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Ecosystems whose importance is recognised at international level and which are, in some cases, protected by international conventions. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An association of independent states, whose representatives gather for the promotion of common interests including defense and trade. (Source: GT2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The use of methods, strategy, intrigue, decision making and power by governments and their representatives to achieve goals in policy making or governmental affairs in a worldwide or international arena. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The political or diplomatic interaction or dealings between independent nations. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Land area drained by a river and its tributaries whose waters are situated in and utilized by two or more countries. (Source: TOE / EWP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Freedom from danger or the quality of averting risk of harm to persons, property or the environment shared across one or more national boundaries; consequently, the combined efforts of more than one nation to achieve or preserve that state. (Source: OED / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of establishing or conforming something to a norm or measure that is recognized beyond the boundaries of a single country or nation. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The flow of commodities and goods between nations. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Portions of a geographical area which constitutes a hydrogeological unit as the catchment area for a single river which are under the jurisdiction of two or more countries. (Source: WPRa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Method employed in the assessment of the meaning and significance of data, results, facts, etc. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) The area between land and sea which is regularly exposed to the air by the tidal movement of the sea. Marine organisms that inhabit the intertidal zones have to adapt to periods of exposure to air and to the waves created by wind, which makes it the most physically demanding of the marine habitats. 2) The shore zone between the highest and lowest tides. (Source: WRIGHT / LBC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Stepping in or participating in problem solving efforts for troublesome or perplexing situations involving the natural world or scenery. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A detailed list of articles, goods, property, etc. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Survey of a forest area to determine forest depletion. The aim of the inventory is to give an overview of the forest conditions. Especially should the inventory aim to detect any changes in the forest conditions, but it should also provide the distribution of the forest damages and find out any relation with site and stand conditions. (Source: DUNSTEa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A reversal in the usual direction of a process, as in the change of density of water at 4 C. (Source: PITT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The atmosphere layer through which an inversion occurs. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any animal lacking a backbone, including all species not classified as vertebrates. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any item of value purchased for profitable return, as income, interest or capital appreciation. (Source: IVW / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Assay taking place in an artificial environment. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Experiments that are carried out in the living organism. (Source: UVAROV)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A nonmetallic halogen element; the poisonous, corrosive dark plates or granules are readily sublimed; insoluble in water, soluble in common solvents; used as germicide and antiseptic, in dyes, tinctures, and pharmaceuticals, in engraving lithography, and as a catalyst and analytical reagent. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process in which ions are exchanged between a solution and an insoluble solid, usually a resin. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A permanent insoluble material (usually a synthetic resin) which contains ions that will exchange reversibly with other ions in a surrounding solution. Both cation and anion exchangers are used in water conditioning. The volume of an ion exchanger is measured in cubic liters of exchanger after the exchanger bed has been backwashed and drained, and has settled into place. (Source: WQA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Radiation that is capable of energizing atoms sufficiently to remove electrons from them. In this state atoms become more reactive, so that ionizing radiation increases chemical activity and in this way produces biological effects, including effects that involve alterations induced in DNA. X-rays and gamma-rays are the only electromagnetic waves that cause ionization in biological material. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A region of the earth's atmosphere, extending from about 60 to 1000 kilometers above the earth's surface, in which there is a high concentration of free electrons formed as a result of ionizing radiation entering the atmosphere from space. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An electrically charged atom or group of atoms formed by the loss or gain of one or more electrons. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A malleable ductile silvery-white ferromagnetic metallic element occurring principally in haematite and magnetite. It is widely used for structural and engineering purposes. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A sector of the economy in which an aggregate of commercial enterprises is engaged in the extraction and refinement of iron ore to produce cast iron, wrought iron and steel. (Source: RHW / ENC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Industry for the production of iron articles. (Source: WEBSTEa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: To subject to or treat with light or other electromagnetic radiation or with beams of particles. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) To supply land with water so that crops and plants will grow or grow stronger. (Source: CAMB / WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A permanent irrigation conduit constructed to convey water from the source of supply to one or more farms. (Source: NALMS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Farming based on the artificial distribution and application of water to arable land to initiate and maintain plant growth. (Source: GOODa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A land mass, especially one smaller than a continent, entirely surrounded by water. (Source: AMHER)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Unique but fragile and vulnerable ecosystems due to the fact that the evolution of their flora and fauna has taken place in relative isolation. Many remote islands have some of the most unique flora in the world; some have species of plants and animals that are not found anywhere else, which have evolved in a specialized way, sheltered from the fierce competition that species face on mainland. (Source: WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of preventing or reducing the transmission of electricity, heat, or sound to or from a body, device, or region by surrounding it with a nonconducting material. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) Two or more compounds having the same molecular formula, but a different arrangement of atoms within the molecule. 2) One of two or more chemical substances having the same elementary percentage composition and molecular weight but differing in structure, and therefore in properties; there are many ways in which such structural differences occur. (Source: CED / MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: One or two or more atoms with the same atomic number that contain different numbers of neutrons. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The fine-grained creamy-white dentine forming the tusks of elephants, and the teeth or tusks of certain other large animals such as the walrus; it has long been esteemed for a wide variety of ornamental articles. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Persons united in a joint liability or indebtedness. Two or more persons jointly liable for the same debt. (Source: WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A program sponsored or administered by a government to guide through and represent in court proceedings persons who are in financial need and cannot afford private counsel. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any public organization or branch of government responsible for the administration of justice or the enforcement of laws. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Specific norms, regulations and precedents governing the conduct, procedure and arrangement of a judicial system, its various divisions and its officers. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The power of a court to hear and decide a case or make a certain order. (Source: DICLAW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The science or philosophy of law. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) A German rendering of a Serbo-Croat term referring to the terrain created by limestone solution and characterized by a virtual absence of surface drainage, a series of surface hollows, depressions and fissures, collapse structures, and an extensive subterranean drainage network. 2) A type of topography that is formed on limestone, gypsum, and other rocks by dissolution, and that is characterized by sinkholes, caves, and underground drainage. Etymology: German, from the Yugoslavian territory Krs; type locality, a limestone plateau in the Dinaric Alps of northwestern Yugoslavia and northeastern Italy. (Source: WHIT / BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: To keep a supply accumulated for future use. (Source: AMHER)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A thin oil distilled from petroleum or shale oil, used as a fuel for heating and cooking, in lamps, and as a denaturant for alcohol. (Source: AMHER)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Attaching a notice to a product or container bearing information concerning its contents, proper use, manufacturer and any cautions or hazards of use. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A room or building with scientific equipment for doing scientific tests or for teaching science, or a place where chemicals or medicines are produced. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Tests or investigations carried out in a laboratory. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Research carried out in a laboratory for testing chemical substances, growing tissues in cultures, or performing microbiological, biochemical, hematological, microscopical, immunological, parasitological tests, etc. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Discarded materials produced by analytical and research activities in a laboratory. (Source: ERG)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: One of the factors of production. It includes all the exertions - manual, physical or mental - by individuals, directed towards the production of wealth. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The branch of the legal system which lays down the rules governing employment relationships, trade union relations, and state intervention to provide protection against particular situations of need for citizens who are workers. (Source: NECTAR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The dynamics or general state of the association between management and non-management employees in an enterprise, industry or nation, with special attention to the maintenance of agreements, collective bargaining and the status of unions. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A material which contains a substantial quantity of a cellulose derivative, most commonly nitrocellulose but sometimes a cellulose ester, such as cellulose acetate or cellulose butyrate, or a cellulose ether such as ethyl cellulose; used to give a glossy finish, especially on brass and other bright metals. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A body of water cut off from the open sea by coral reefs or sand bars. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) The depression in the Earth's surface occupied or formerly occupied by a lake and containing its shore features. 2) The area from which a lake receives drainage. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The direct or indirect human alteration of the biological, physical, chemical or radiological integrity of lake water, or a lake ecosystem. (Source: Landy)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An enclosed body of water, usually but not necessarily fresh water, from which the sea is excluded. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A device that produces light, such as an electric lamp. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A specified geographical tract of the Earth's surface including all its attributes, comprising its geology, superficial deposits, topography, hydrology, soils, flora and fauna, together with the results of past and present human activity, to the extent that these attributes exert a significant influence on the present and future land utilization. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The permission or freedom to use, enter, approach or pass to and from a tract of land, which often consists of real estate property. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Procedure by which big land properties are divided in parcels of smaller size. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The system of registering certain legal estates or interests in land. It describes the land and any additional rights incidental to it, such as rights of way over adjoining land. (Source: DICLAW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The maximum extent to which ground or soil area may be exploited without degradation or depletion. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Removal of trees, undergrowth, etc. in preparation for ploughing, building, etc. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The care, preservation and re-use of solid areas of the earth's surface, especially soil regions valued as a natural resource or utilized as an agricultural resource. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Joining small plots of land together to form larger farms or large fields. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Land cover is the physical state of the land surface. It is the combination of vegetation, soil, rock, water and human-made structures, which make up the earth's landscape. The land cover is the interface between the earth's crust and the atmosphere, influencing the exchange of energy and matter in the climatic system and biogeochemical cycles. (Source: BRS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Planning of infrastructures, services and industrial settlements in order to promote the socio-economic growth of certain land area. (Source: DIFIDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Study of the relationship between terrestrial organisms and their environment. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The oldest method of waste disposal for the solid matter discarded in the domestic dustbin, along with the packaging material and paper from high street shops and offices. Landfill sites are usually disused quarries and gravel pits. When they were filled, previous practice was to cover them up with soil and forget about them. Housing estates have been built, often with disastrous consequences, on old landfill dumps. Waste burial has now become a serious technology and a potential source of energy. Landfill sites can be designed to be bioreactors, which deliberately produce methane, gas as a source of biofuel or alternative energy. Traditionally, waste tips remained exposed to air and aerobic microbes - those which thrive in air - in order to turn some of the waste into compost. However, open tips also encourage vermin, smell in hot weather and disfigure the landscape. In the 1960s, as a tidier and safer option, landfill operators began to seal each day's waste in a clay cell. While excluding vermin, the clay also excluded air. Decomposition relied on anaerobic microbes, which die in air. However, the process produced methane (natural gas), which was a safety hazard. The methane is now extracted by sinking a network of perforated pipes into the site. (Source: WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The protective shielding, consisting of soil or some other material, that encloses disposal sites for compacted, non-hazardous solid waste, or secures disposal sites for hazardous waste to minimize the chance of releasing hazardous substances into the environment. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Landfill gas is highly dangerous as methane is highly explosive; therefore it must be controlled at all operational landfill sites, whether by active or passive ventilation or both especially in the case of deep sites. There exist venting systems for shallow and deep sites respectively. (Source: PORT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Landfill gas is generated in landfill sites by the anaerobic decomposition of domestic refuse (municipal solid waste). It consists of a mixture of gases and is colourless with an offensive odour due to the traces of organosulphur compounds. Aside for its unpleasantness, it is highly dangerous as methane is explosive in concentrations in air between 5 per cent, the Lower Explosive Limit (LEL), and the Upper Explosive Limit (UEL) of 15 per cent. Landfill gas must be controlled at all operational landfill sites, whether actively or passively vented or both especially in the case of deep sites. (Source: PORT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Liquid that has seeped through solid waste in a landfill and has extracted soluble dissolved or suspended materials in the process. (Source: WWC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any physical, recognizable form or feature of the Earth's surface, having a characteristic shape and produced by natural causes; it includes major forms such as plane, plateau and mountain, and minor forms such as hill, valley, slope, esker, and dune. Taken together the landforms make up the surface configuration of the Earth's. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The use, settlement or possession of solid areas of the earth's surface. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The activity of designing, organizing or preparing for the future use of solid areas of the earth's surface, especially regions valued for natural resources, utilized as agricultural resources or considered for human settlement. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The presence of one or more contaminants upon or within an area of land, or its constituents. (Source: Landy)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Making land capable of more intensive use by changing its general character, as by drainage of excessively wet land; irrigation of arid or semiarid land; or recovery of submerged land from seas, lakes and rivers. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A register or survey of land, containing information on the surface of properties, tenants' names, commencing with the earliest owners through successive ownership and partitions, and such like. (Source: CED / WESTS / HARRIS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The treatment of any unusable land usually by filling with refuse or levelling until the land can be brought into productive use. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The traits, patterns, and structure of a specific geographic area, including its biological composition, its physical environment, and its anthropogenic or social patterns. An area where interacting ecosystems are grouped and repeated in similar form. (Source: EPAGLO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of mining disfigures the surface of the land, and in the absence of reclamation leads to permanent scars. The process spoils the vital topsoil, disrupts drainage patterns, destroys the productive capacity of agricultural and forest land and impairs their aesthetic and social value. (Source: WPRa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Landscapes might change through time as a result of human activities or natural processes such as fires or natural disasters. Changes in landscape structure can be documented by using data from aerial photographs or satellite images, and new technologies, such as remote sensing and geographic information systems. (Source: PARCOR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The creation, development, and decorative planting of gardens, grounds, parks, and other outdoor spaces. Landscape gardening is used to enhance nature helping to create a natural setting for individual residences and buildings, and even towns, particularly where special approaches and central settings are required. (Source: GILP96)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: In visual assessment work, landscapes can be divided into four major elements. a) Form is the perceived mass or shape of an object that appears unified, and which provides a consciousness of its distinction and relation of a whole to the component parts. b) Line is the real or imagined path, border, boundary, or intersection of two planes, such as a silhouette, that the eye follows when perceiving abrupt differences in form, colour or texture. c) Colour is a visual perception that enables the eye to differenciate otherwise identical objects based on the wavelengths of reflected light. d) Texture is the visual feel of a landscape. (Source: DUNSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The safeguarding, for public enjoyment, of landscape and of opportunities for outdoor recreation, tourism and similar activities; the concept includes the preservation and enhancement not only of what has been inherited but the provision of new amenities and facilities. (Source: GILP96)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The study of landscapes taking account of the ecology of their biological populations. The subjects thus embraces geomorphology and ecology and is applied to the design and architecture of landscapes. (Source: ALL2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Measures aiming at preserving landscape or controlling its transformations caused by anthropic activities or natural events. (Source: DIFID)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The aspect of the land use planning process that deals with physical, biological, aesthetic, cultural, and historical values and with the relationships and planning between these values, land uses, and the environment. (Source: UNUN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Elaboration and implementation of strategies and measures for the conservation, preservation, suitable use, and renewal of natural resources and nature or man-made components of landscape, in particular wildlife and natural systems of various standing. (Source: MOSGOV)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Area where landscape is protected for its particular features in order to maintain its role in contributing to the wider enjoyment of the countryside. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Using parts of landscape in a way that heavily modifies its features. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Using landscape or parts of it for tourism, sports, or agriculture. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The formulation of regional objectives, plans and programmes and the harmonization of the regional effects of sectorial planning. (Source: ECHO2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Mass-movement landforms and processes involving the downslope transport, under gravitationary influence of soil and rock material en masse. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Transport of persons and goods by a network of roads or railways. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The term land use deals with the spatial aspects of all human activities on the land and with the way in which the land surface is adapted, or could be adapted, to serve human needs. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The arrangement of land units into a variety of categories based on the properties of the land or its suitability for a particular purpose. It has become an important tool in rural land-resource planning. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The interdisciplinary process of evaluating, organising, and controlling the present and the future development and use of lands and their resources in terms of their suitability on sustained yield basis. Includes an overall ecological evaluation in terms of specific kinds of uses as well as evaluations of social, economic, and physical contexts to the land concerned. (Source: UNUN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Type of management and utilization of the soil. (Source: GOODa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The monetary or material worth in commerce or trade of an area of ground considered as property. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any sizable building which relies on machinery that converts energy released from the rapid burning of a fuel-air mixture into mechanical energy. (Source: PMA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Acronym for Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation; a device that produces a powerful, highly directional, monochromatic, coherent beam of light. Laser consist of a transparent cylinder with a reflecting surface at one end and a partially reflecting surface at the other. Light waves are reflected back and forth, some of them emerging at the partially reflecting end. The light source may be a ruby, whose chromium atoms are excited by a flash lamp so that they emit pulses of highly coherent light, or a mixture of inert gases that produce a continuos beam, or a cube of treated gallium arsenide which emits infrared radiation when an electric current passes through it. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act of washing and ironing clothes, linen, etc. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: One of the rules making up the body of law. (Source: DICLAW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An alteration of or addition to any statute with legal force that, if approved by the appropriate legislative authority, supersedes the original statute. (Source: LLL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any variety of activities associated with promoting compliance and obedience to the binding rules of a state, especially the prevention, investigation, apprehension or detention of individuals suspected or convicted of violating those rules. (Source: BLD / LLL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A binding rule or body of rules prescribed by a government to protect human health and the environment, manage growth and development or enhance the quality of life in small geographical and social areas within cities where residents share values and concerns and interact with one another on a daily basis. (Source: HUM)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Complex of rules fixed by law or custom which regulate social relations. (Source: ZINZAN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) The process of separating a liquid from a solid (as in waste liquid by percolation into the surrounding soil. 2) Extraction of soluble components of a solid mixture by percolating a solvent through it. 3) To lose or cause to lose soluble substances by the action of a percolating liquid. (Source: HARRIS / DICCHE / CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A heavy toxic bluish-white metallic element that is highly malleable; occurs principally as galena and is used in alloys, accumulators, cable sheaths, paints, and as a radiation shield. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Lead compounds are present as gasoline additives, in paint, ceramic products, roofing, caulking, electrical applications, tubes, or containers. Lead exposure may be due to air, water, food, or soil. Lead in the air is primarily due to lead-based fuels and the combustion of solid waste, coal, oils, and emissions from alkyl lead manufacturers, wind blown dust volcanoes, the burning of lead-painted surfaces, and cigarette smoke. Lead in drinking water comes from leaching from lead pipes, connectors, and solder in both the distribution system and household plumbing. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The presence and release into the air, water and soil, of lead, a toxic metal used in plumbing, gasoline and lead-acid batteries. (Source: FFD / EEN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A binding rule or body of rules prescribed by a government to reduce or eliminate the lead content in petroleum fuels used in vehicular and other engines that pollute the air with lead-carrying exhaust. (Source: GAS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A measure of the amount of lead or lead salts absorbed by the body as a possible sign of acute or chronic lead poisoning, which can affect the nervous, digestive or muscular systems. (Source: SMD / MED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The main organ of photosynthesis and transpiration in higher plants, usually consisting of a flat green blade attached to the stem directly or by a stalk. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The accidental, uncontrolled discharge or seepage of liquids, gases and other substances to unintended and unwanted locations, frequently causing risks of damage or harm to persons, property or the environment. (Source: WWC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The dressed or tanned hide of an animal, usually with the hair removed. (Source: AMHER)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Industry for the production of leather goods such as garments, bags, etc. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The fundamental law or judicial precedent that warrants or supports a subsequent decision or action by any governmental, corporate or private entity. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A justifiable claim to have or obtain something or to act in a certain way, which is supported by law and is covered or shielded from the danger of being revoked or repealed. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any order or rule issued by a government stipulating its procedures for the creation, execution or adjudication of laws. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The means by which a right is enforced or the violation of a right is prevented, redressed, or compensated. (Source: BLACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The exact wording or language of a law or other document in conformity with the law or having the authority of law. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act or process of making laws. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Rules concerning the limits of pollutant emissions. (Source: DIZAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A binding rule or body of rules prescribed by a government to manage and protect an area's natural water supply and waterways. (Source: DES / BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The power of a deliberative assembly of persons or delegates to bring a bill, resolution or special act to an official, legally binding status. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The skill, knowledge, qualification, capacity or authority to make, give or enact rules with binding force upon a population or jurisdiction. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Knowledge or a service providing knowledge concerning actual and proposed laws, including approval status, the history and content of deliberative proceedings and the specific language of those laws. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The department, assembly, or body of persons that makes statutory laws for a state or nation. (Source: WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Sports and recreational activities carried out in the time free from work or other duties.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Time free from work or other duties; spare time.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A large order of scaly-winged insects, including the butterflies, skippers, and moths; adults are characterized by two pairs of membranous wings and sucking mouthparts, featuring a prominent, coiled proboscis. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A progressive, malignant disease of the blood forming organs; a distorted proliferation and development of leukocytes and their precursors in the blood and bone marrow. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A ratable portion of the produce of the property and labor of the individual citizens, taken by the nation, in the exercise of its sovereign rights, for the support of government, for the administration of the laws, and as the means for continuing in operation the various legitimate functions of the state. (Source: WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The vocabulary of a particular sphere of activity, region, social class or individual, or the total set of morphemes or meaningful units of a language and its words. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Subjection to a legal obligation. Liability is civil or criminal according to whether it is enforced by the civil or criminal courts. (Source: JCU)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Subjection to a legal obligation, such as financial recompense or ecological reparations, for any harm or damage inflicted on persons, property or the environment in the course of commercial or recreational activity in, on or near a sea. (Source: BLD / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Subjection to a legal obligation, such as financial recompense or ecological reparations, for any harm or damage inflicted on persons, property or the environment during the production, use or transport of radioactive materials used as an energy source or in weaponry. (Source: BLD / MHD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A law or body of laws enacted that pertains to or establishes an obligation, debt or responsibility for loss, penalty, evil, expense or burden. (Source: BLD / ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Place where books and other literary materials are kept. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any process of granting and certifying legal or administrative permission to a person or organization to pursue some occupation or to perform some activity or business. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Procedures performed by administrative agencies in conjunction with issuance of various types of licences. (Source: BLACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Obligation to obtain a permit to pursue an occupation or to carry on some business. (Source: WESTSa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Composite organisms formed by the symbiosis between species of fungi and an algae. They are either crusty patches or bushy growths on tree trunks, stone walls, roofs or garden paths. Because they have no actual roots they get their sustenance from the atmosphere and rainwater. Lichens play an important role in the detection and monitoring of pollution, especially sulphur dioxide, as they are highly sensitive to pollution and different species disappear if pollution reaches specific levels. (Source: WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The phases, changes, or stages through which an organism passes throughout its lifetime. (Source: UNUN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A science based on living organisms collectively. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The particular attitudes, habits or behaviour associated with an individual or group. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Electromagnetic radiation that is capable of causing a visual sensation. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The supply of illumination in streets or dwellings. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A mechanical device for separating and removing residues from fuel and lubricating oil from waste water coming from filling stations and industrial plants in order to avoid pollution of water bodies; this system is based on the different specific weights of water and fuel residues that float on the water and can be easily removed. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Coal of relatively recent origin consisting of accumulated layers of partially decomposed vegetation, intermediate between peat and bituminous coal; often contains patterns from the wood from which it formed. (Source: MGH / CED / WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Extraction of brown coal from natural deposits; lignite is a brownish-black solid fuel in the second stage in the development of coal. It has a little over half the heating value of bituminous or anthracite coal. (Source: KORENa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any of various mineral and industrial forms of calcium oxide differing chiefly in water content and percentage of constituent such as silica, alumina and iron. (Source: AMHER)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A sedimentary rock consisting chiefly of calcium carbonate, primarily in the form of the mineral calcite and with or without magnesium carbonate. Limestones are formed by either organic or inorganic processes, and may be detrital, chemical, oolitic, earthy, crystalline, or recrystallized; many are highly fossiliferous and clearly represent ancient shell banks or coral reefs. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
