Symptoms of exposure include frequent coughing, severe respiratory infections, chronic bronchitis, abdominal pain, muscle pain, acne rashes, skin color changes, unexpected weight loss, nonmalignant or malignant liver disease. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Compounds consisting of three benzene rings linked to each other in either ortho, meta or para positions and substituted with chlorine atoms. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal:
Hydrocarbons containing two or more closed rings of atoms.
(Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Hydrocarbon molecule with two or more nuclei; examples are naphtalene, with two benzene rings side by side, or diphenyl, with two bond-connected benzene rings. Also known as polynuclear hydrocarbon. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) A thermoplastic polyester resin made from ethylene glycol and terephthalic acid; melts at 265C; used to make films or fibers. 2) Type of plastic used to make artificial fibres and plastic bottles, which can be recycled. (Source: MGH / PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) The bonding of two or more monomers to produce a polymer. 2) Any chemical reaction that produces such a bonding. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Substance made of giant molecules formed by the union of simple molecules (monomers). (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Polymer of vinyl chloride; tasteless, odourless; insoluble in most organic solvents; a member of the family of vinyl resins. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A natural body of standing fresh water occupying a small surface depression, usually smaller than a lake and larger than a pool. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any collection of liquid effluents or wastewater drained or separated out during the processing of crops or mineral ores. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A small, natural body of standing water, usually fresh; e.g. a stagnant body of water in a marsh, or a still body of water within a cave. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The density, dispersal pattern and apportionment of the total number of persons in any area. (Source: RHW / EEN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of numerical and structural change within populations resulting from births, deaths, and movements. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A group of organisms of one species, occupying a defined area. (Source: LBC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The study of the interaction of a particular species or genus population with its environment. (Source: ALL2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An increase in the total number of inhabitants of a country, city, district or area. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any shift or migration of a statistically significant number of persons inhabiting a country, district or area. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The organization of, and inter-relationships among, inhabitants of a given region, country or city. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The direction of change in the total number of persons inhabiting a country, city, district or area. (Source: RHW / WMA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Treatment of treated water or wastewater to improve the water quality. (Source: LEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any of several compounds containing potassium, especially soluble compounds such as potassium oxide, potassium chloride, and various potassium sulfates, used chiefly in fertilizers. (Source: AMHER)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Rock salt mining is an underground mining process in which the salt is physically dug out of the ground in an operation involving drilling, blasting and crushing the rock. The major percentage of this output is used for winter road maintenance. (Source: SALINF)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Domesticated fowl grown for their meat and eggs. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: One of the commonest of agricultural occupations. Many urban households and many farms maintain some chickens for both meat and eggs. (Source: LOGIE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: State in which the individual lacks the resources necessary for subsistence.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Company which is responsible for the supply and distribution of electric energy to a given area. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The ratio of the work done by an engine to the heat supplied. (Source: UVAROV)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A stationary plant containing apparatus for large-scale conversion of some form of energy (such as hydraulic, steam, chemical, or nuclear energy) into electrical energy. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of producing a separable solid phase within a liquid medium; represents the formation of a new condensed phase, such as a vapour or gas condensing to liquid droplets; a new solid phase gradually precipitates within a solid alloy as a result of slow, inner chemical reaction; in analytical chemistry, precipitation is used to separate a solid phase in an aqueous solution. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Increase of precipitation resulting from changes in the colloidal stability of clouds. This can be either intentional, as with cloud seeding, or unintentional, as with air pollution, which increases aerosol concentrations and reduces sunlight. (Source: PARCOR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Animal which kills and eats other animals. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Building whose sections are manufactured in specialized factories and later transported and assembled on a building site. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any introductory action in the judicial process designed to determine the need for further court involvement or to expedite a motion that requires immediate attention. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Amount to be paid for a contract of insurance or life assurance.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: To maintain and keep safe from harm, destruction or decay any species of proof legally presented at the trial of an issue, including witnesses, records, documents, exhibits and concrete objects. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A chemical added to foodstuffs to prevent oxidation, fermentation or other deterioration, usually by inhibiting the growth of bacteria. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Printed matter as a whole, especially newspapers and periodicals.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The application of a pressure to squeeze out the juice or contents of a fruit, seed, etc. (Source: WEBSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A type of stress which is exerted uniformly in all directions; its measure is the force exerted per unit area. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any politically active group with a common set of values about resource use allocation. Pressure groups seek to influence decisions on resource use allocation in excess of their proportional representation in the planned-for populace by seeking preferential consideration for their resource use choices. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The amount of money paid per unit for a good or service. (Source: ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The guiding procedure or philosophy for decisions regarding the monetary rate or value of a country or region's resources, including natural resources, human resources and capital, or man-made goods. (Source: RHW / ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The first five or six years of instruction in elementary schools. (Source: COE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Consumption of energy used in the same form as in its naturally occurring state, for example crude oil, coal, natural gas, e.g. before it is converted into electricity. (Source: BRACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: That part of a country's or region's economy that makes direct use of natural resources, including agriculture, forestry, fishing and the fuel, metal and mining industries. (Source: ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Order of mammals containing monkeys, apes, and human beings. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Forest which originally covered a region before changes in the environment brought about by people. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Principle adopted by the UN Conference on Environment and Development (1992) that in order to protect the environment, a precautionary approach should be widely applied, meaning that where there are threats of serious or irreversible damage to the environment, lack of full scientific certainty should not be used as a reason for postponing cost-effective measures to prevent environmental degradation. (Source: GILP96)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Principle stated by the World Commission on Environment and Development (The Bruntland Commission) in 1987: development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the needs of future generations. Sustainable development is a process of integrating economic, social and ecological goals, and should not mean a trade-off between the environment and development. Sustainable development should imply balance rather than conflict. (Source: GRAHAWa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A sector of the economy in which an aggregate of commercial enterprises is engaged in the reproduction of written text or images in multiple copies such as books, periodicals, newspapers or other similar formats. (Source: SIC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The art, process or business of producing reproductions of written text or images in multiple copies, in book, periodical or newspaper formats, or in other similar formats. (Source: SIC / RHW)

binding.name: label
binding.literal: prior notification for hazardous waste transport

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A formal announcement and, often, a request for permission to the proper governmental authorities of the intention to convey across political borders potentially harmful materials that have been left over from manufacturing or testing processes. (Source: KSA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Transportation mean belonging to an individual person. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Living quarters where a group of persons (family) live together. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The branch of law dealing with such aspects of relationships between individuals that are of no direct concern to the state. (Source: DICLAW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Segment of the economy not run by government, including households, sole traders, partnerships and companies. (Source: ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Transport performed with private means. (Source: ECHO2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The transfer of ownership or control of a government enterprise or other governmental property to a non-public, non-official company, organization or individual, either through sale or through the establishment of a special enterprise outside direct government control. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An order of herbivorous placental mammals characterized by having a proboscis, incisors enlarged to become tusks, and pillarlike legs with five toes bound together on a broad pad. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Organisms (i.e. prokaryotes) whose genetic material (filaments of DNA) is not enclosed by a nuclear membrane, and that do not possess mitochondria or plastids. Bacteria and cyanophyta are the only prokaryotic organisms. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Law which prescribes method of enforcing rights or obtaining redress for their invasion. Laws which fix duties, establish rights and responsibilities among and for persons, natural or otherwise, are "substantive laws" in character, while those which merely prescribe the manner in which such rights and responsibilities may be exercised and enforced in a court are "procedural laws". (Source: BLACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act of converting material from one form into another desired form. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any technical strategies, methods or tools used for the conception, design, development or implementation of any system. (Source: APD / SCP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Water used in a manufacturing or treatment process or in the actual product manufactured. Examples would include water used for washing, rinsing, direct contact, cooling, solution make-up, chemical reactions, and gas scrubbing in industrial and food processing applications. In many cases, water is specifically treated to produce the quality of water needed for the process. (Source: WQA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Obligations, responsibilities or debts imposed upon all members of an industry that manufactures or produces a product or service causing injury or harm to a consumer and apportioned according to each member's share of the market for the product. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Something produced by human or mechanical effort or by a natural process. (Source: AMHER)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Comparison of products or processes to identify those having reduced environmental impacts. (Source: DIZAMBa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Attaching a notice to a product or container bearing information concerning its contents, proper use, manufacturer and any cautions or hazards of use. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Factual, circumstantial and, often, comparative knowledge concerning various goods, services or events, their quality and the entities producing them. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The amount of output or yield per unit of input or expenditure achieved by a company, industry or country. (Source: ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The general direction or tendency in the measurement of the production of goods and services having exchange value. (Source: ISEP / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) The legal liability of manufacturers and sellers to compensate buyers, users, and even bystanders, for damages or injuries suffered because of defects in goods purchased. 2) A tort which makes a manufacturer liable if his product has a defective condition that makes it unreasonably dangerous to the user or consumer. (Source: BLACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A standard which prescribes aspects of the physical or chemical composition of products which have potential for causing environmental damage or the handling, presentation and packaging of products, particularly those which are toxic. (Source: GRAHAW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An excess of the receipts over the spending, costs and expenses of a business or other commercial entity during any period. (Source: ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A diagrammatic presentation of observed data in the sequence of their occurrence in time, in the context of water flow. (Source: ECHO1)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An interdiction or forbidding of an activity or action by authority or law. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The complex of actions, which have a potential for resulting in a physical change in the environment. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Process by which a disturbance at one point is propagated to another point more remote from the source with no net transport of the material of the medium itself; examples include the motion of electromagnetic waves, sound waves, hydrodynamic waves in liquids, and vibration waves in solids. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A gas used in aerosol preparations to expel the liquid contents through an atomizer. (Source: UVAROV)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The physical and chemical characteristics of the substances or parts of which a thing or object is made. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: That benefit or safety which the government affords to the citizens to insure their individual or corporate right to exclusive enjoyment and disposal of property, money and any other thing tangible or intangible that represents a source of income or wealth. (Source: LLL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Technique for causing a body to move by exerting a force against it. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The pursuit of legal proceedings, particularly criminal proceedings. (Source: DICLAW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: State of being prosperous; wealth or success.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Portions of land protected by special restrictions and laws for the conservation of the natural environment. They include large tracts of land set aside for the protection of wildlife and its habitat; areas of great natural beauty or unique interest; areas containing rare forms of plant and animal life; areas representing unusual geologic formation; places of historic and prehistoric interest; areas containing ecosystems of special importance for scientific investigation and study; and areas which safeguard the needs of the biosphere. (Source: DODERO / WPR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Natural or man-made areas which have been reserved for conservation, scientific, educational and/or recreational purposes. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Threatened, vulnerable or endangered species which are protected from extinction by preventive measures. (Source: RAMADE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Area surrounding a water recovery plant in which certain forms of soil utilization are restricted or prohibited in order to protect the groundwater. (Source: AZENP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Measures adopted for the safeguarding of species, of their ecosystems and their biodiversity. (Source: ADMIN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A series of procedures and devices designed to preserve people, property or the environment from injury or harm. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any of a class of high-molecular weight polymer compounds composed of a variety of alfa-amino acids joined by peptide linkages. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) The original draft of a document. 2) An international agreement of a less formal nature than a treaty. It is often used to amend treaties. (Source: DICLAW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A diverse phylum of eukaryotic microorganisms; the structure varies from a simple uninucleate protoplast to colonial forms, the body is either naked or covered by a test, locomotion is by means of pseudopodia or cilia or flagella, there is a tendency toward universal symmetry in floating species and radial symmetry in sessile types, and nutrition may be phagotrophic or autotrophic or saprozoic. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A geographic area of some considerable extent, smaller than a continent but larger than a region, which is unified by some or all of its characteristics and which can therefore be studied as a whole. A faunal province, for example, has a particular assemblage of animal species, which differs from assemblages in different contemporaneous environments elsewhere. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The power of a government agency or its administrators to administer and implement laws and government policies applicable to a specific geographical area, usually falling under the jurisdiction of two or more states. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A result or consequence stemming from mental processes that create or influence human consciousness and emotions. (Source: RHW / SMD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Strain or disequilibrium of the mind especially in its affective or cognitive functions, or the physical or mental stimulus, agent or experience that causes such an imbalance. (Source: SMD / MED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The science that deals with the functions of the mind and the behaviour of an organism in relation to its environment. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any result pertaining to the influence of the mind or higher functions of the brain upon the operations of the body, particularly bodily disorders or diseases. (Source: SMD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Illness arising from or aggravated by a mind-body relationship. (Source: GILP96)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The right or permission for all persons of a community to use government owned geographic areas such as parks, campgrounds and historical sites. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A measure or provision taken on behalf and with the consent of the general populace. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A place having baths for public use. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A building to which there is free access by the public and which is available for the use of a community. (Source: HARRISa / CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: That which can be accessed, used and shared by the general populace without restrictions, penalties or fees. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The theory and practice of governmental money matters, including taxation, spending, transfer and property incomes, borrowing, debt and revenue management. (Source: ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act of obtaining or furnishing money or capital for a program, purchase or enterprise from the general population of a community or state, usually through government allocation of tax revenues. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The discipline in health science that, at the level of the community or the public, aims at promoting prevention of disease, sanitary living, laws, practices and a healthier environment. (Source: GUNN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Right to appear and give evidence and also right to hear and examine witnesses whose testimony is presented by opposing parties. (Source: BLACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Factual or circumstantial knowledge or the service, office or station providing this knowledge for an entire population or community, without restriction. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A general classification of law, consisting generally of constitutional, administrative, criminal and international law, concerned with the organization of the state, the relations between the state and the people who compose it, the responsibilities of public officers to the state, to each other, and to private persons, and the relations of states to one other. The branch or department of law which is concerned with the state in its political or sovereign capacity, including constitutional and administrative law, and with the definition, regulation, and enforcement of rights in cases where the state is regarded as the subject of the right or object of the duty, - including criminal law and criminal procedure, - and the law of the state, considered in its quasi private personality, i.e., as capable of holding or exercising rights, or acquiring and dealing with property, in the character of an individual. (Source: WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The purported, collective view of the public on some issue or problem, typically formulated by selective polling or sampling, and frequently used as a guide to action or decision. (Source: RHW / ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The canvassing of a representative sample of a large group of people on some question in order to determine the general opinion of a group. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Park with big trees, ornamental plants, alleys bordered by trees or bushes, fountains and statues situated in a town and whose access is free. (Source: ZINZAN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The involvement, as an enfranchised citizen, in public matters, with the purpose of exerting influence. (Source: NRW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A joint venture between corporations and government or between community members and government or business beyond the course of normal interaction. (Source: NTL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The governmental process of purchasing supplies, equipment and services, or purchasing contracts to secure the provision of supplies, equipment and services, which are often sold by the private sector. (Source: OED / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A government agency for which an elected or appointed attorney or staff of attorneys is vested with the authority by a constitution or statute to try cases on the government's behalf, to represent public interest or to take legal action against persons violating federal, state or local laws. (Source: USC / LTM)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Segment of the economy run to some degree by government, including national and local governments, government-owned firms and quasi-autonomous non-government organizations. (Source: ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An enterprise concerned with the provision to the public of essentials, such as electricity or water. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act or the means of conveying people in mass as opposed to conveyance in private vehicles. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Vehicle for conveying large numbers of paying passengers from one place to another. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An enterprise concerned with the provision to the public of essentials, such as electricity or water. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Structures, as roads, dams, or post offices, paid for by government funds for public use.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any disease pertaining to the lungs. (Source: DELFIN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The cellulosic material produced by reducing wood mechanically or chemically and used in making paper and cellulose products. Also known as wood pulp. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A sector of the economy in which an aggregate of commercial enterprises is engaged in manufacturing and selling the soft, moist, slightly cohering mass deriving from wood that is used to produce paper sheets, cardboard and other paper products. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A machine that draws a fluid into itself through an entrance port and forces the fluid out through an exhaust port. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The removal of gases and vapors from a vacuum system. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The acquisition or the act of buying something by payment of money or its equivalent. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The removal of unwanted constituents from a substance. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Equipment for the removal of impurities and unwanted constituents from a medium. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Installation where impurities are removed from waste water. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any of a number of nitrogenous bases, such as guanine and adenine, that are derivatives of purine and constituents of nucleic acids and certain coenzymes. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The breaking apart of complex molecules into simpler units by the use of heat. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The inspection, analysis, and other relevant actions taken to provide control over what is being done, manufactured, or fabricated, so that a desirable level of quality is achieved and maintained. (Source: HARRIS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Quality of life is largely a matter of individual preference and perception and overlaps the concept of social well-being. Generally the emphasis is on the amount and distribution of jointly consumed public goods, such as health care and welfare services, protection against crime, regulation of pollution, preservation of fine landscapes and historic townscapes.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An open or surface working or excavation for the extraction of building stone, ore, coal, gravel, or minerals. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The surface exploitation and removal of stone or mineral deposits from the earth's crust. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The associations, tensions or harmony between two or more groups of people distinguished by history, culture, religion or physique: distinctions erroneously construed as being based on consistent biological differences and as representing, in effect, species of a human genus. (Source: SOC / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A system using beamed and reflected radiofrequency energy for detecting and locating objects, measuring distance or altitude, navigating, homing, bombing and other purposes. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Emission of any rays from either natural or man-made origins, such as radio waves, the sun's rays, medical X-rays and the fall-out and nuclear wastes produced by nuclear weapons and nuclear energy production. Radiation is usually divided between non-ionizing radiation, such as thermal radiation (heat) and light, and nuclear radiation. Non-ionizing radiation includes ultraviolet radiation from the sun which, although it can damage cells and tissues, does not involve the ionization events of nuclear radiation. (Source: WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Somatic and genetic damage to living organisms caused by exposure to ionizing radiation. (Source: GUNN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The total amount of radiation absorbed by material or tissues, in the sense of absorbed dose, exposure dose, or dose equivalent. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Prolonged exposure to ionizing radiation from various sources can be harmful. Nuclear radiation from fallout from nuclear weapons or from power stations, background radiation from substances naturally present in the soil, exposure to X-rays can cause radiation sickness. Massive exposure to radiation can kill quickly and any person exposed to radiation is more likely to develop certain types of cancer than other members of the population. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act or state of being subjected to electromagnetic energy strong enough to ionize atoms thereby posing a threat to human health or the environment. (Source: APD / MHD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The periodic or continuous surveillance or analysis of the level of radiant energy present in a given area, to determine that its prescribed amount has not been exceeded or that it meets acceptable safety standards. (Source: TOE / OMD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The study of ionizing radiation and its effects on matter. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Precautionary actions, measures or equipment implemented to guard or defend people, property and natural resources from the harmful effects of ionizing energy. (Source: MHD / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A binding rule or body of rules prescribed by government to establish measures to keep humans and natural resources safe from harmful exposure to energy waves released by nuclear materials, electromagnetic current and other sources. (Source: MHD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The complex of symptoms characterizing the disease known as radiation injury, resulting from excessive exposure of the whole body (or large part) to ionizing radiation. The earliest of these symptoms are nausea, fatigue, vomiting, and diarrhea, which may be followed by loss of hair (epilation), hemorrhage, inflammation of the mouth and throat, and general loss of energy. (Source: TDH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process, equipment or programming involved in transmitting and receiving sound signals by electromagnetic waves. (Source: MHD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Contamination of a substance, living organism or site caused by radioactive material. (Source: FLGISA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The removal of radioactive contamination which is deposited on surfaces or may have spread throughout a work area. Personnel decontamination is also included. Decontamination methods follow two broad avenues of attack, mechanical and chemical. (Source: PARCOR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Waste generated by the emission of particulate or electromagnetic radiation resulting from the decay of the nuclei of unstable elements. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The release of radioactive substances into the environment deriving from nuclear installations and from mining, purification and enrichment operations of radioactive elements. (Source: FLGISA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The material that descends to the earth or water well beyond the site of a surface or subsurface nuclear explosion. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A substance undergoing spontaneous decay or disintegration of atomic nuclei and giving off radiant energy in the form of particles or waves, often associated with an explosion of a nuclear weapon or an accidental release from a nuclear power plant, holding facility or transporting container. (Source: DEE / ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any substance that contains one or more radionuclides of which the activity or the concentration cannot be disregarded as far as radiation protection is concerned. (Source: ECHO2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A radioactive isotope which, when injected into a biological or physical system, can be traced by radiation detection devices, permitting determination of the distribution or location of the substance to which it is attached. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any waste that emit radiation in excess of normal background level, including the toxic by-products of the nuclear energy industry. (Source: GRAHAW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The total supervision of the production, handling, processing, storage and transport of materials that contain radioactive nuclides and for which use, reuse or recovery are impractical. (Source: EIS / HMH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The property possessed by some atomic nuclei of disintegrating spontaneously, with loss of energy through emission of a charged particle and/or gamma radiation. (Source: BRACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A nuclide that exhibits radioactivity. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A radioactive gaseous element emitted naturally from rocks and minerals where radioactive elements are present. It is released in non-coal mines, e.g. tin, iron, fluorspar, uranium. Radon is an alpha particle emitter as are its decay products and has been indicted as a cause of excessive occurrence of lung cancer in uranium miners. Concern has been expressed at radon levels in some housing usually adjacent to granite rocks or old tin mining regions. (Source: PORT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Discarded textile waste, either post-consumer waste or pre-consumer waste, such as manufacturing process scraps. (Source: ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The movement and circulation of vehicles transporting goods and people on railroad systems. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Transportation of goods and persons by railway. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A permanent track composed of a line of parallel metal rails fixed to sleepers, for transport of passengers and goods in trains. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Precipitation in the form of liquid water drops with diameters greater than 0.5 millimeter. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A forest of broad-leaved, mainly evergreen, trees found in continually moist climates in the tropics, subtropics, and some parts of the temperate zones. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Process by which particles in the atmosphere act as centres round which water can form drops which then falls as rain. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Water which falls as rain from clouds. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The building up of land by the deposition of allochthonous material, such as rocks, gravel, etc. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Tests which do not always yield the same result when repeated under the same conditions. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A Eurasian cruciferous plant, Brassica napus, that is cultivated for its seeds, which yield a useful oil, and as a fodder plant. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Species which have a restricted world range. (Source: UNUN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A crude, unprocessed or partially processed material used as feedstock for a processing operation. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The developed countries depend on a stable supply of raw materials for their industries. Total resource requirements are increasing rapidly over the entire world. In developed countries, although population is increasing slowly, per capita use is increasing rapidly, while the opposite is happening in developing countries. Traditionally raw materials have been classified as non-renewable resources, but a distinction may be important between "loosable" resources, such as oil and coal, and "non-loosable" resources, such as metals, which can be used several times over by recycling processes. (Source: WPR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Measures used to ensure the provision of or the access to crude, unprocessed or partially processed materials used as feedstock for processing or manufacturing. (Source: RHWa / MHD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: That branch of physical chemistry concerned with the mechanisms and rates of chemical reactions. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A device that introduces either inductive or capacitive reactance into a circuit, such as a coil or capacitor. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Those studies and activities that seek to minimise the risk of a nuclear reactor accident. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The planting of trees in forest areas which have been cleared. Reforestation has become increasingly important for preventing or reversing environmental degradation and for helping to maximize economic returns on commercially forested lands. (Source: WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Techniques and practical applications associated with recombinant DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid artificially introduced into a cell that alters the genotype and phenotype of the cell and is replicated along with the natural DNA). (Source: DELFIN / KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Recommendation refers to an action which is advisory in nature rather than one having any binding effect.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Reclamation measures taken to restore the environmental quality level of a landscape to its predisturbed condition. (Source: AQDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of returning wildlife ecosystems and habitats to their original conditions. (Source: DUNSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A formulated or systematic method for the restoration of natural resources or the reuse of materials and objects. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Activities that promote refreshment of health or spirits by relaxation and enjoyment. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A piece of publicly owned land, especially in a town, used for sports and games. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Characteristic of materials that still have useful physical or chemical properties after serving their original purpose and that can, therefore, be reused or remanufactured into additional products. (Source: LEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Plastic waste that can be transformed into new products. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Waste materials that are transformed into new products in such a manner that the original products may lose their identity. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Paper that has been separated from the solid waste stream for utilization as a raw material in the manufacture of a new product. Not all paper in the waste stream is recyclable. It may be heavily contaminated or otherwise unusable. (Source: LEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A resource recovery method involving the collection and treatment of a waste product for use as raw material in the manufacture of the same or a similar product. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Management of all the stages involved in the life of a product such as raw materials acquisition, manufacturing, distribution and retail, use and re-use and maintenance, recycling and waste management, in order to create less environmentally harmful products. (Source: PORT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A binding rule or body of rules prescribed by government to establish and regulate provisions for the minimization of waste generation through recovery and reprocessing of re-usable products. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An administrative or legal remedy that attempts to restore a person to his or her original or expected position prior to loss or injury, including breach of contract. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Sea water which is covered or discoloured by the sudden growth of algal bloom or by a great increase in single-celled organisms, dinoflagellates. Red tides are often fatal to many forms of marine life and, in some cases, can result in human deaths because the dinoflagellates are eaten by clams and mussels which concentrate the paralysing toxins which they produce. (Source: WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Chemical reaction in which an element gains an electron. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any of various types of tall stiff grass-like plants growing together in groups near water. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A line of rocks in the tidal zone of a coast, submerged at high water but partly uncovered at low water. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A factory for the purification of some crude material such as ore, sugar, oil, etc. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal:
The processing of raw material to remove impurities.
(Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The return of waves or particles from surfaces on which they are incident. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The study of the reflectance of light or other radiant energy. (Source: WEBSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A substance that by undergoing a change in phase (liquid to gas, gas to liquid) releases or absorbs a large latent heat in relation to its volume, and thus effects a considerable cooling effect. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The cooling of substances, usually food, below the environmental temperature for preservative purposes. Refrigeration is responsible for the largest and fastest-growing use of CFCs in the developing world. The industrial countries, and some developing countries, have taken exceptional steps to control and, eventually, ban the production of CFCs and other ozone-depleting materials by the year 2000. However, many developing nations have not signed the Montreal Protocol because they are afraid that the cost of changing over to alternative, ozone-friendly technology will be too high. (Source: MGHa / WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An appliance, a cabinet, or a room for storing food or other substances at a low temperature. (Source: AMHER)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A restricted and isolated area in which plants and animals persisted during a period of continental climatic change that made surrounding areas uninhabitable; especially an ice-free or unglaciated area within or close to a continental ice sheet or upland ice cap, where hardy biotas eked out an existence during a glacial phase. It later served as a center of dispersal for the repopulation of surrounding areas after climatic readjustment. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A person who is outside his country of origin and who, due to well-founded fear of persecution, is unable or unwilling to avail himself of that country protection. (Source: GUNN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Special vehicles designed and equipped for the collection of wastes and their transportation to a waste disposal site. (Source: MANCOSa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Fuel produced from domestic refuse, after glass and metals have been removed from it, by compressing it to form briquettes used to fuel boilers. (Source: PORT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Compost derived by the biodegradation of the organic constituents of solid wastes and wastewater sludges. The major public health issues associated with composting using solid wastes mixed with sewage sludge are pathogens, heavy metal, and odors. The heat generated during composting, as a result of the activities of thermophilic organisms, is capable of killing bacteria, viruses, protozoa and helminths present in sewage sludge. The metallic elements in sludge of greatest concern to human health are cadmium, lead, arsenic, selenium, and mercury. Only cadmium is normally found in sewage sludge at levels which, when applied to soils, can be absorbed by plants, and accumulate in edible parts, thereby entering the food chain. (Source: CORBIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The renewing or reuse of materials such as activated carbon, single ion exchange resins, and filter beds by appropriate means to remove organics, metals, solids, etc. (Source: LEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Making changes to old industrial plants installing new equipment's and facilities for the disposal of gas emissions in the atmosphere, of waste water and waste material in soil and water. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A designated area or an administrative division of a city, county or larger geographical territory that is formulated according to some biological, political, economic or demographic criteria. (Source: RHW / ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An assembly of national, political party or organizational delegates representing persons or the interests of a specific geographic area, or the pact or the agreement that arises from such an assembly. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The progress or advancement for a large geographical territory or a designated division of a country or state, particularly in economic growth that leads to modernization or industrialization. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The plan for a region according to some physiographic, biological, political, administrative, economic, demographic, or other criteria. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The step by step method and process of defining, developing and outlining various possible courses of actions to meet existing or future needs, goals and objectives for a designated area or an administrative division of a city, county or larger geographical area. (Source: RHW / BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A body of rules or orders prescribed by government, management or an international organization or treaty pertaining to or effective within a specific territory of one or more states. (Source: BLD / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The organization or arrangement of a large geographical territory or a designated division of a country or state that may be formulated according to some administrative, biological, political, economic or demographic criteria. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An instance of or a certificate attesting to the fact of entering in an official list various pieces of information in order to facilitate regulation or authorization, including one's name, contact information and, in some instances, data concerning a specific possession or property. (Source: BLD / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The course of action or record in which an individual, company or an organization formally enrolls with a government agency or an authority in order to be granted certain rights, particularly trademark or copyright privileges, or the permission to sell and distribute a product. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Resources that have a natural rate of availability and yield a continual flow of services which may be consumed in any time period without endangering future consumption possibilities as long as current use does not exceed net renewal during the period under consideration. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A body of rules or orders prescribed by a government or an international organization or treaty establishing levels of hazardous materials in the environment or in ingestible substances beyond which human exposure is deemed health-threatening. (Source: SPR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A rule established by authority; a permanent rule of action; a law or statute. In its most common meaning, the term is used to designate the enactment of the legislative body. (Source: WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Government supervision over the obligations and rights of an industry or enterprise for the purpose of providing the public with services that are considered important, vital or necessary to most members of a community or area. (Source: DAM)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A conservation measure involving the correction of past abuses that have impaired the productivity of the resources base. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: To provide with new or different housing. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Reintroduction of exterminated species in an area; it is bound to fail if the chosen animal became extinct in the area too long ago and if the area itself has undergone too many changes. Reintroduction needs years of careful planning - the approval of local population, technical conditions of the release, feeding system, protection and breeding control - and even then some unexpected problems may arise. (Source: WPR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The relating of causes to the effects that they produce. (Source: UVAROV)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The release of organisms in the environment creates the risk that once released they may exhibit some previously unknown pathogenicity, might take over from some naturally occurring bacteria or pass on some unwanted trait to such indigenous bacteria. (Source: WPR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The expression of man's belief in and reverence for a superhuman power recognized as the creator and governor of the universe.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) The scientific detection, recognition, inventory and analysis of land and water area by the use of distant sensors or recording devices such as photography, thermal scanners, radar, etc. 2) Complex of techniques for the remote measure of electromagnetic energy emitted by objects. (Source: LANDY / ZINZAN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: General term indicating the elimination of substances from a medium or from the environment. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A process of returning natural ecosystems or habitats to their original structure and species composition. Restoration requires a detailed knowledge of the original species, ecosystem functions and interacting processes involved. (Source: DUNSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Energy sources that do not rely on fuels of which there are only finite stocks. The most widely used renewable source is hydroelectric power; other renewable sources are biomass energy, solar energy, tidal energy, wave energy, and wind energy; biomass energy does not avoid the danger of the greenhouse effect. (Source: UVAROV)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Resources capable of being continuously renewed or replaced through such processes as organic reproduction and cultivation such as those practiced in agriculture, animal husbandry, forestry and fisheries. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Dwelling places occupied by tenants who make periodic payments to landlords or owners for use of the facilities as residences. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any commercial activity, position or site that involves work in restoring or fixing some material thing or structure, such as by replacing parts or putting together something torn, broken or detached. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Substitution of an atom or atomic group with a different one. (Source: ZINZAN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The amount of money involved to replace or have an item take the place of another item. (Source: EFP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any conduct or action undertaken on behalf of a person, group, business or government, often as an elected or appointed voice. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Restoration of contaminated nuclear fuel to a usable condition. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any of various processes, either sexual or asexual, by which an animal or plant produces one or more individuals similar to itself. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The technology involved in altering in some prescribed way the genetic constitution of an organism. Typically "useful" genes, i.e. very short sequence of DNA, are isolated from one organism and inserted into the DNA of a bacterium of yeast. These microorganisms multiply rapidly and can be cultured easily, enabling large quantities of the gene product to be obtained. Reproductive manipulation has been used for the large-scale production of antibiotics, enzymes, and hormones (e.g. insulin). Organisms into which foreign DNA has been artificially inserted are called "transgenic organisms". (Source: UVAROV)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A class of terrestrial vertebrates, characterized by the lack of hair, feathers, and mammary glands; the skin is covered with scales, they have a three chambered heart and the pleural and peritoneal cavities are continuous. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Service organized to provide immediate assistance to persons injured or in distress. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Scientific investigation aimed at discovering and applying new facts, techniques and natural laws. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Place where systematic investigation to establish facts or principles or to collect information on a subject is performed. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Proposal, plan or design containing the necessary information and data for conducting a specific survey. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An area of land and/or of water designated as having protected status for purposes of preserving certain biological features. Reserves are managed primarily to safeguard these features and provide opportunities for research into the problems underlying the management of natural sites and of vegetation and animal populations. Regulations are normally imposed controlling public access and disturbance. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An artificial or natural storage place for water, such as a lake or pond, from which the water may be withdrawn as for irrigation, municipal water supply, or flood control. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Area that has only private houses, not offices and factories. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A building allocated for residence. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Residential zones where raised areas are built across roads so that vehicles are forced to move more slowly along it. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Amount of water left in a water course after it has fed a hydropower plant in order to maintain a satisfactory dry-weather-flow for allowing the survival of biotic communities. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Remaining potential for harm to persons, property or the environment following all possible efforts to reduce predictable hazards. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Material left after any waste treatment process, including industrial, urban, agricultural, mining or other similar treatments. (Source: ERG / ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Analysis of residues from agricultural chemicals used in food crops and contained in foodstuff. The analyses use gas chromatography, liquid chromatography, mass spectrometry, immunoassays, etc. (Source: RRDA / USDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Recycling of material or energy which is left over or wasted in industrial processes and other human activities. Examples include waste heat and gaseous pollutants from electricity generation, slag from metal-ore refining, and garbage. A residual becomes an output or input when a technological advance creates economic opportunities for the waste. (Source: GILP96)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any of a class of solid or semisolid organic products of natural or synthetic origin with no definite melting point, generally of high molecular weight; most resins are polymers. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) The ability of a plant to overcome, retard, suppress, or prevent infection or colonization by a pathogen, parasite, or adverse abiotic factor. 2) The ability of insects, fungi, weeds, or other pests to survive normally lethal doses of an insecticide, fungicide, herbicide, or other pesticide. (Source: DUNSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A formal expression of the opinion of an official body or a public assembly, adopted by vote, as a legislative resolution. (Source: BLACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Absorption or, less commonly, adsorption of material by a body or system from which the material was previously released. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any component of the environment that can be utilized by an organism. (Source: LBC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Assessment of the availability of resources in a given area. (Source: GILP96a)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Reduction of overall resource consumption and utilization of recovered resources in order to avoid waste. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A conscious process of decision-making whereby natural and cultural resources are allocated over time and space to optimize the attainment of stated objectives of a society, within the framework of its technology, political and social institutions, and legal and administrative arrangements. An important objective is the conservation of resources, implying a close and integrated relationship between the ecological basis and the socio-economic system. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process in living organisms of taking in oxygen from the surroundings and giving out carbon dioxide. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Air volumes inspired and expired through the lungs. (Source: DELFIN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any of a group of devices that protect the respiratory system from exposure to airborne contaminants; usually a mask with a fitting to cover the nose and mouth. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The structures and passages involved with the intake, expulsion and exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the vertebrate body. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The structures and passages involved with intake, expulsion, and exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the vertebrate body. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The obligation to answer for an act done, and to repair or otherwise make restitution for any injury it may have caused. (Source: WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The counteracting or undoing of negative effects or influences on the environment. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Resistant structure that allows the organism to survive adverse environmental conditions. (Source: ALL2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of renewing or returning something to its original, normal or unimpaired condition, particularly works of art, cultural artifacts, furniture or buildings. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Procedure or course of action taken to reestablish or bring back to state of environmental or ecological health. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any decision, action or policy which limits or constrains the making of valued goods or services. (Source: ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A limitation on the utilization of land or some other property, often inscribed in a deed or lease document. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The sale of goods to ultimate consumers, usually in small quantities.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A basin designed and operated to provide temporary storage and thus reduce the peak flood flows of a stream. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) Addition of a pollution control device on an existing facility without making major changes to the generating plant. 2) Providing a jet, an automobile, a computer, or a factory, for example, with parts, devices or equipment not in existence or available at the time of original manufacture. (Source: TOE / AMHER)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any container which has been conceived and designed to accomplish within its life cycle a minimum number of trips or rotations in order to be refilled or reused for the same purpose for which it was conceived. (Source: PORT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any re-utilization of products or components, in original form, such as when used glass bottles are sterilized and refilled for resale. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Planting of new trees and, particularly, of native plants in disturbed sites where the vegetation cover has been destroyed, to stabilize the land surface from wind and water erosion and to reclame the land for other uses. Revegetation practices are employed in mined lands, roadsides, parks, wetlands, utility corridors, riparian areas, etc. (Source: REVEGa / CORBIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A method of obtaining pure water from water containing a salt, as in desalination. Pure water and the salt water are separated by a semipermeable membrane and the pressure of the salt water is raised above the osmotic pressure, causing water from the brine to pass through the membrane into the pure water. This process requires a pressure of some 25 atmospheres, which makes it difficult to apply on a large scale. (Source: DICCHE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An erect grass, Oryza sativa, that grows in East Asia on wet ground and has drooping flower spikes and yellow oblong edible grains that become white when polished. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A legal guarantee or just claim enabling a citizen or employee to compose and submit a formal written request to an authority asking for some benefit or favor or for intervention and redress of some wrong. (Source: BLD / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The legal guarantee or just claim inhering in a citizen's relation to some physical thing, but especially a plot of land, including the right to possess, use and dispose of it. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A legally enforceable claim for payment or reimbursement to pay for damages, loss or injury, or for remuneration to pay for services rendered, whether in fees, commissions or salary. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The individual's right to know in general about the existence of data banks, the right to be informed on request and the general right to a print-out of the information registered and to know the actual use made of the information. (Source: ECHO1)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: To attach a numbered ring to the leg of a bird so that its movements can be recorded. Ringing is a very common method of tracing bird movement and providing information about bird's ages. It can also cause stress to the birds. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The removal of thin layers of surface material more or less evenly from an extensive area of gently sloping land, by broad continuous sheets of running water rather than by streams flowing in well-defined channels; e.g. erosion that occurs when rain washes away a thin layer of topsoil. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) Terrestrial areas where the vegetation complex and microclimate are products of the combined pressure and influence of perennial and/or intermittent water... and soils that exhibit some wetness characteristics. 2) Zone situated on the bank of a water course such as a river or stream. (Source: DUNSTE / GILP96)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The slow vertical instability of the earth crust involving up-and-down movements as in the volcanic district west of Naples, Italy. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Sea level rises are a possible consequence of global warming. As the amount of free water in the ocean increases, and as the water becomes warmer, global warming will increase. In addition, according to theory, the heating at the poles may reduce the amount of water trapped in glaciers and ice caps. By the year 3000, the seas could rise between one and two metres. Such an event would clearly threaten low-lying areas, particularly in Asia, where million of people live and farm on river deltas and flood plains. (Source: WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The expected number of lives lost, persons injured, damage to property and disruption of economic activity due to a particular natural phenomenon, and consequently the product of the probability of occurrence and the expected magnitude of damage. (Source: GUNN / RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Technique used to determine the likelihood or chance of hazardous events occurring (such as release of a certain quantity of a toxic gas) and the likely consequences. Originally developed for use in nuclear and chemical industry where certain possible events, of low probability, could have extremely serious results. Attempts are being made to use concepts from probabilistic risk analysis to characterise environmental impacts, whose occurrence and nature are not easy to predict with any degree of accuracy. (Source: ERIN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The qualitative and quantitative evaluation performed in an effort to define the risk posed to human health and/or the environment by an action or by the presence or use of a specific substance or pollutant. (Source: LEEa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A systematic process of evaluating and assessing the hazards of loss versus the possibility of financial gain or profit. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The exchange of information about health or environmental risks among risk assessors and managers, the general public, news media, interest groups, etc. (Source: OPPTIN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A subjective appreciation by individuals which will more often than not bear little relation to the statistical probability of damage or injury. (Source: GRAHAW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any act, instance or process lowering the probability that harm will come to an area or its population as the result of some hazard. (Source: ISEP / TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A stream of water which flows in a channel from high ground to low ground and ultimately to a lake or the sea, except in a desert area where it may dwindle away to nothing. A river and all its tributaries within a single basin is termed a drainage system. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any growth, maturation or change in an area of land drained by a river and its tributaries. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The alteration of a natural stream by excavation, realignment, lining or other means to accelerate the flow of water. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The direct or indirect human alteration of the biological, physical, chemical or radiological integrity of river water, or a river ecosystem. (Source: Landy)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Water which flows in a channel from high ground to low ground and ultimately to a lake or the sea, except in a desert area where it may dwindle away to nothing. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A long piece of hard ground that people can drive along from one place to another. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The care or upkeep of streets, highways and other routes, including improvements in alignment, widening and markings, and work involving buried cables, water mains or gas mains. (Source: CSD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any measure, technique or design intended to reduce the risk of harm posed by moving vehicles along a constructed land route. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Salt used against the formation of ice on roads; when excess salt washes off the roads, it can poison roadside vegetation or raise salt concentrations in streams and reserves of underground water. It also accelerates the deterioration of concrete and metal. (Source: WPR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Circulation of motor vehicles and people on the road network. (Source: ZINZAN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Discipline which includes the design of highways and pedestrian ways, the study and application of traffic statistics, and the environmental aspects of the transportation of goods and people. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Transportation of goods and persons by vehicles travelling on a road network. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any aggregate of minerals that makes up part of the earth's crust. It may be unconsolidated, such as sand, clay, or mud, or consolidated, such as granite, limestone, or coal. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A generic term for felted or matted fibers manufactured by blowing or spinning threads of molten rock, slag, or glass. The material is used for thermal insulation. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any of the relatively small placental mammals that constitute the order Rodentia, having constantly growing incisor teeth specialized for gnawing. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The absorbing and anchoring organ of a vascular plant; it bears neither leaves nor flowers and is usually subterranean. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A heat-treating furnace of circular construction which rotates the workpiece around the axis of the furnace during heat treatment; workpieces are transported through the furnace along a circular path. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any established or selected course for passage or travel. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The activity of designing, organizing or preparing for the construction of boulevards, turnpikes, highways and other roads. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A cream to dark brown elastic material obtained by coagulating and drying the latex from certain plants, especially the rubber tree. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The systematic series of actions in which a solid substance deriving from rubber trees and plants is toughened and treated chemically to give it the strength, elasticity, resistance and other qualities needed for the manufacture of products such as erasers, elastic bands, water hoses, electrical insulation and tires. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A sector of the economy in which an aggregate of commercial enterprises is engaged in the manufacture and marketing of natural or synthetic rubber products. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any refuse or unwanted material made of synthetic or natural rubber, often the byproduct of rubber processing. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Rate at which water is removed by flowing over the soil surface. This rate is determined by the texture of the soil, slope, climate, and land use cover (e.g. paved surface, grass, forest, bare soil). (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Area outside the limits of any incorporated or unincorporated city, town, village, or any other designated residential or commercial area such as a subdivision, a business or shopping center, or community development. (Source: LEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Environment pertaining to the countryside. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The total number of persons inhabiting an agricultural or pastoral region. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A collection of dwellings located in a rural area. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Holidays organized in a farm: meals are prepared with natural products and guests are entertained with handicraft, sporting and agricultural activities. (Source: DIFID)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The state of being secure from harm, injury, danger or risk, often as a result of planned measures or preparations. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of studying the need for or efficacy of actions, procedures or devices intended to lower the occurrence or risk of injury, loss and danger to persons, property or the environment. (Source: OED / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An action, procedure or contrivance designed to lower the occurrence or risk of injury, loss and danger to persons, property or the environment. (Source: OED / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A principle or regulation governing actions, procedures or devices intended to lower the occurrence or risk of injury, loss and danger to persons, property or the environment. (Source: OED / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A norm or measure applicable in legal cases for any action, procedure or contrivance designed to lower the occurrence or risk of injury, loss and danger to persons, property or the environment. (Source: BLD / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A collection of rules and regulations adopted by authorities concerning structural and mechanical standards for safety. (Source: HARRISa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Research, detailed examination and usually a written report on the need for or efficacy of actions, procedures or devices intended to lower the occurrence or risk of injury, loss and danger to persons, property or the environment. (Source: OED / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any of various urodele amphibians, such as Salamandra salamandra of central and S Europe. They are typically terrestrial, have an elongated body, and only return to water to breed. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The accumulation of soluble salts by evaporation of the waters that bore them to the soil zone, in a soil of an arid, poorly drained region. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: General name for a family of microorganisms, one of the largest groups of bacteria, that includes those most frequently implicated in food poisoning and gastroenteritis. Unhygienic handling and inadequate cooking of poultry and meat, improper storage of cold meats and, more recently, contamination of battery-reared hen eggs, are the most common sources of salmonella infections. (Source: WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal:
Amount of salt contained in a solution.
(Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Areas of brackish, shallow water usually found in coastal areas and in deltas. There are also inland marshes in arid areas where the water has a high salt level because of evaporation. They are environmentally delicate areas, extremely vulnerable to pollution by industrial or agricultural chemicals, or to thermal pollution, which often results when river water has been used as the coolant in power stations and industrial plants. (Source: WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A meadow subject to overflow by salt water. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A mass of salt which is injected as a diapir (a dome in which the overlying rocks have been ruptured by the squeezing-out of plastic core material) into overlying sedimentary rocks, thereby piercing and deforming them. The mechanism is similar to that of an intrusive magma, with the salt deforming and behaving plastically under pressure. It is of great economic importance because it assists in the formation of a "trap" structure for oil accumulation, in addition to its associated deposits of anhydrite, gypsum and sulphur.
