binding.literal: Any monetary grant made by the government to a private industrial undertaking or charitable organization, but especially one given to consumers or producers in order to lower the market price of some service or product and make it readily affordable to the public. (Source: MGHME / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Soil underlying surface soil, devoid of plant roots. (Source: MGH / ZINZAN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The removal of surplus water from within the soil by natural or artificial means, such as by drains placed below the surface to lower the water table below the root zone. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The capability of a substance of being replaced by another, for example sweeteners used in place of sugar. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Halogenated compounds, because of their toxical and persistent character, should be substituted by environmental friendly compounds, like water-based fat solvents in metal processing industry or water-based coating agents. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Replacement of phosphate in detergents by environmentally safer substances, such as zeolite. The substitute will not act as a nutrient, and so will not cause eutrophication as a result of the accelerated growth of plants and microorganisms if it is released into waterways. (Source: WRIGHTa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The interacting system of a biological community and its non-living environmental surroundings in regions bordering on the tropics or the regions between tropical and temperate zones. (Source: TOE / DOE / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A residential district situated on the outskirts of a city or town. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A sweet crystalline or powdered substance, white when pure, consisting of sucrose obtained mainly from sugar cane and sugar beets and used in many foods, drinks, and medicines to improve their taste. (Source: AMHER)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Establishments primarily engaged in processing raw cane sugar, sugar beets or starches to finished sucrose, glucose or fructose. By-products of this industry include beet pulp and inedible molasses. (Source: PGE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A salt or ester of sulfuric acid, widely distributed in nature and often found in the atmosphere. (Source: INP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any compound that includes one or more sulfur atoms with a more electropositive element, either carbon, metal or some other nonoxygen atom. (Source: RHW / MHD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A nonmetallic element existing in a crystalline or amorphous form and in four stable isotopes; used as a chemical intermediate and fungicide, and in rubber vulcanization. It is deposited from volcanic vents and fumaroles and also is found in sedimentary rocks, particularly with gypsum and limestone, and associated with salt-domes. Native sulphur is the main source of sulphur for the sulphuric acid industry, followed by sour gas (natural gas containing hydrogen sulphide) and pyrite. Sulphur is an essential plant macronutrient. (Source: MGH / ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Sulphur content in a solution. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Emissions of the gas given off during the burning of fossil fuels in power stations and other boilers. Sulphur dioxide is created because sulphur is an impurity in most coal and oils. When the fuel is burned the hot sulphur reacts with oxygen in the atmosphere to form sulphur dioxide. (Source: WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A toxic, corrosive, strongly acid, colorless liquid that is miscible with water and dissolves most metals, and melts at 10C; used in industry in the manufacture of chemicals, fertilizers and explosives, and in petroleum refining. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An oxide of sulphur, such as sulphur dioxide and sulphur trioxide; they are formed primarily from the combustion of fossil fuels; major air pollutants and cause of damage to the respiratory tract as well as vegetation. (Source: MGH / KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The oversight or direction in the construction and maintenance of houses, facilities, offices and other structures. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The oversight or direction over the process of setting up or making adjustments to a building or to a mechanical or electrical system or apparatus. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An appointed or official group given the responsibility of overseeing or managing normal work operations, special projects or other functions of an organization or agency. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The willingness and ability to sell a range of quantities of a good at a range of prices, during a given time period. Supply is one half of the market exchange process; the other is demand. (Source: AMOS2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A substance that, when used in small quantities, modifies the surface properties of liquids or solids. A surface-active agent reduces surface tension in a fluid or the interfacial tension between two immiscible fluids, such as oil and water. Surfactants are particularly useful in accomplishing the wetting or penetration of solids by aqueous liquids and serve in the manner of detergent, emulsifying, or dispersing agents. They are more effective than soap in certain situations and are used by conservators for such purposes as cleaning, wetting, and dispersing. (Source: PALIM)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Water that travels over the soil surface to the nearest surface stream; runoff of a drainage basin that has not passed beneath the surface since precipitation. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The force acting on the surface of a liquid, tending to minimize the area of the surface; quantitatively, the force that appears to act across a line of unit length on the surface. Also known as interfacial force; interfacial tension; surface intensity. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any method of treating a material (metal, polymer, or wood) so as to alter the surface, rendering it receptive to inks, paints, lacquers, adhesives, and various other treatments, or resistant to weather or chemical attack. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: All waters on the surface of the Earth found in streams, rivers, ponds, lakes, marshes or wetlands, and as ice and snow. (Source: LANDY / BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any tissue, blood or mucus removed during surgery or autopsy, soiled surgical dressings, or other materials requiring special disposal procedures. (Source: UMT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The extent to which assets exceed liabilities, especially the profits remaining after operating expenses, taxes, interest and insurance costs are subtracted. (Source: IVW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: System that permits the continuous observation, measurement and evaluation of the progress of a process or phenomenon with the view to taking corrective measures. (Source: GUNN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A critical examination of facts or conditions to provide information on a situation. Usually conducted by interviews and/or on-site visitations. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Development that provides economic, social and environmental benefits in the long term having regard to the needs of living and future generations. Defined by the World Commission on Environment and Development in 1987 as: development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs. (Source: GILP96)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Statistical indicators used for measuring sustainable development that may be chosen among a wide range of themes as, for example, environmental capacity and quality of life. (Source: PORT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Use of the environment and its living resources at a rate that does not exceed its capacity for renewal in order to ensure its availability for future generations. (Source: DUNSTE / UNUNa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An periodically inundated area of low ground having shrubs and trees, with or without the formation of peat. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A sweetening agent, especially one that does not contain sugar. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A close and mutually beneficial association of organisms of different species. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Study of the ecology of organisms, populations, communities or systems. (Source: LBC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An ecological association in which the physiological processes of behaviour of an individual are enhanced by the nearby presence of another organism. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) A state in which the combined effect of two or more substances is greater than the sum of the separate effects. 2) An effect whereby two toxic substance together have more of an impact than anticipated. (Source: PORT / GILP96)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An artificially produced solid or liquid cleansing substance that acts like soap but is stronger, and is capable of dissolving oily materials and dispersing them in water. (Source: DOE / RIC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Material made artificially by chemical reaction. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An artificially produced filament or threadlike strand used by manufacturers to produce clothes or other goods that require weaving, knitting or felting, including polyester, nylon, rayon and other similar material. (Source: INP / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A means of organizing elements into an integrated analytic and/or decisionmaking procedure to achieve the best possible results. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Analysis or estimate noting similarities and differences in the operations of businesses and organizations. (Source: ISEP / OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The science concerned with the general study of structures and behaviours of systems which may be applicable in different branches of learning. (Source: ECHO2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: In criminal law and torts, the act of laying hold upon an evidence, with or without removing the same.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A truck designed for bulk shipment of liquids or gases.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A ship designed for bulk shipment of liquids or gases.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Storage space for containers of liquids or gases. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: One of a group of complex organic chemicals commonly found in leaves, unripe fruits, and the bark of trees. Their function is uncertain though the unpleasant taste may discourage grazing animals. Some tannins have commercial uses, notably in the production of leather and ink; used in tanning, as a mordant in dyeing, and in ink manufacture. (Source: DICCHE / UVAROV)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A viscous material composed of complex, high-molecular-weight, compounds derived from the distillation of petroleum or the destructive distillation of wood or coal. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A collection of people selected and approached by some entity for a variety of purposes, including assistance, recruitment, information dissemination, marketing and research. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A classified list or scale of charges made in any private or public business. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The manufacture of dark, heavy, viscous substances or residue, which is obtained by the distillation of organic materials such as coal, wood and petroleum. (Source: ENC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A sandstone in which hydrocarbons have been trapped; the lighter compounds evaporate, leaving a residue of asphalt in the rock pores. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any employment or utilization of dark, heavy, viscous substances or residue derived from the distillation of certain organic materials, often to produce benzene, soap, dyes, cosmetics and other products. (Source: ENC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An amount of money demanded by a government for its support or for specific facilities or services, most frequently levied upon income, property or sales. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act or result of a government requiring money for its support or for specific facilities or services. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A binding rule or body of rules prescribed by a government stipulating the sum of money and manner of collection it demands for governmental support, facilities and services, usually levied upon income, property, sales or other financial resources. (Source: RHW / BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The branch of biology concerned with the classification of organisms into groups based on similarities of structures, origin, etc. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act of imparting knowledge or skill. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A procedure, technique or system with definite plans for instruction or imparting knowledge. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Technical Guideline for Dangerous Substances: technical rules for handling dangerous materials. (Source: FKTa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Changing of industrial methods by introducing new technology. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any application of practical or mechanical sciences to industry or commerce capable of harming persons, property or the environment. (Source: ISEP / FFD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Systematic knowledge of and its application to industrial processes; closely related to engineering and science. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The approval, favorable reception and ongoing use of newly introduced devices and systems, usually developed from recent advances in the engineering sciences or industrial arts. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The systematic analysis of the anticipated impact of a particular technology in regard to its safety and efficacy as well as its social, political, economic, and ethical consequences. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The transfer of development and design work: a) from a parent company to a subsidiary, perhaps in another nation where it will be paid for in repatriated profits or royalties; b) from one country to another as a form of aid to help promote development and sustainable growth. Many nations have made great progress on the strength of technology transfer. (Source: GILP96)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A branch of geology dealing with the broad architecture of the outer part of the Earth, that is, the regional assembling of structural or deformation features, a study of their mutual relations, origin and historical evolution. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The conveyance of images, speech and other sounds, usually over great distances, through technological means, particularly by television, telegraph, telephone or radio. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The convergence of computing and communications technologies, thus the use of telephone or radio to link computers and the use of computers to send messages via telephone or radio links. (Source: NECTAR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The use of radio waves, telephone lines, etc., to transmit the readings of measuring instruments to a device on which the readings can be indicated or recorded. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process, equipment or programming involved in converting a succession of audiovisual images into corresponding electrical signals that are transmitted by means of electromagnetic waves to distant receivers or screens, at which the signals can be used to reproduce the original image. (Source: MHD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The interacting system of a biological community and its non-living environmental surroundings in regions of or related to moderate climates, intermediate between tropical and polar zones and having distinct warm to hot summer seasons and cool to cold winter seasons. (Source: TOE / DOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Mixed forest of conifers and broad-leaf deciduous trees, or mixed conifer and broad-leaf evergreen trees, or entirely broad-leaf deciduous, or entirely broad-leaf evergreen trees, found in temperate regions across the world; characterized by high rainfall, warm summers, cold winters occasionally subzero, seasonality; typically with dense canopies, understorey saplings and tall shrubs, large animals, carnivores dominant, very rich in bird species. (Source: LBC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Forest dominated by broad-leaved hardwoods, which occurs over large tracts in the mid-latitudes of Europe, N. America, and eastern Asia, but which is restricted in the southern hemisphere to Chilean Patagonia. (Source: ALL2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A property that determines the direction of heat flow when an object is brought into thermal contact with other objects: heat flows from regions of higher to those of lower temperatures. (Source: PITT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Simple facilities for asylum or provisional lodgings to individuals or groups in emergencies. (Source: ECHO2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any deposit or holdings of goods, materials or waste in a facility, container, tank or some other physical location for a brief or short time period. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process whereby abnormalities of the offspring are generated, usually as the result of damage to the embryonal structure during the first trimester of pregnancy, producing deformity of the fetus. (Source: CONFER)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The ability or tendency to produce anomalies of formation.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Substances causing formation of a congenital anomaly or monstrosity in the embryo. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The body of specialized words relating to a particular subject. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A soft-bodied insect of the order Isoptera; individuals feed on cellulose and live in colonies with a caste system comprising three types of functional individuals: sterile workers and soldiers, and the reproductives. Also known as white ant. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Subdivisions of the continental surfaces distinguished from one another on the basis of the form, roughness, and surface composition of the land. (Source: PARCOR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any source of supply derived from plants, animals or other wildlife inhabiting land or ground, which may be used by humans for food, clothes and other necessities. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any terrestrial environment, from small to large, in which plants and animals interact with the chemical and physical features of the environment. (Source: GILP96)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A course of action adopted and pursued by government, business or some other organization, which determines the present and future use of each parcel of land in an area. (Source: DOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An area that an animal or group of animals defends, mainly against members of the same species. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The part of a country or region's economy that produces services or assets lacking a tangible and storable form. (Source: ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: To carry out an examination on (a substance, material, or system) by applying some chemical or physical procedure designed to indicate the presence of a substance or the possession of a property. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Animals on which experiments are conducted in order to provide evidence for or against a scientific hypothesis, or to prove the efficacy of drugs or the reaction to certain products. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any animal organism used for scientific research. (Source: DELFIN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Industry for the production of fabrics. (Source: MGHa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A material made of natural or man-made fibers and used for the manufacture of items such as clothing and furniture fittings. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Bluish-white metal with tinlike malleability, but a little softer; used in alloys. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A coherent group of general propositions about the supply and demand of money, interest rates, the flow of money's influence on the overall economy or the policies that should be adopted by institutions controlling the money supply. (Source: ODE / MGHME)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A political conception of government in a capitalist economy where the state is responsible for insuring that all members of society attain a minimum standard of living through redistribution of resources, progressive taxation and universal social programs, including health care and education. (Source: APS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The treatment of physical, mental or social disorders or disease. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of preventing the passage of heat to or from a body by surrounding it with a nonconducting material. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The excessive raising or lowering of water temperature above or below normal seasonal ranges in streams, lakes, or estuaries or oceans as the result of discharge of hot or cold effluents into such water. (Source: LANDY / WPR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A power-generating plant which uses heat to produce energy. Such plants may burn fossil fuels or use nuclear energy to produce the necessary thermal energy. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The concept of utilizing the temperature differences of 20C or more that occur between the surface of an ocean and its depths to achieve a continuous supply of power; this temperature difference may be found in the tropical regions of the world. Various small plants have been constructed to demonstrate the principle. (Source: GILP96)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) Heating and cooling a metal or alloy to obtain desired properties or conditions. 2) Treatment of hazardous waste in a device which uses elevated temperatures as the primary means to change the chemical, physical, or biological character or composition of the hazardous waste. Examples of thermal treatment processes are incineration, molten salt, pyrolysis, calcination, wet air oxidation, and microwave discharge. (Source: MGH / LEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Water, generally of a spring or geyser, whose temperature is appreciably above the local mean annual air temperature. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The branch of physics which seeks to derive, from a few basic postulates, relationships between properties of matter, especially those connected with temperature, and a description of the conversion of energy from one form to another. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Trade-Mark-Name for a thermic waste processing technology. Gasification is emerging as an alternative to combustion in the treatment and energy recovery from Municipal Solid Waste. Several innovative processes and demonstration plants are trying to achieve higher electrical efficiencies and lower emissions using this technology. (Source: ENSDK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A compilation of terms showing synonyms, related terms and other relationships and dependencies, often used in a book format or as a standardized, controlled vocabulary for an information storage and retrieval system. (Source: CCL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The maximum concentration of a particular substance to which a worker should be exposed in a given period of time. (Source: BRACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Mechanical power, which may be converted to electrical power, generated by the rise and fall of ocean tides. The possibilities of utilizing tidal power have been studied for many generations, but the only feasible schemes devised so far are based on the use of one or more tidal basins, separated from the sea by dams (known as barrages), and of hydraulic turbines through which water passes on its way between the basins and the sea. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any water whose level changes periodically due to tidal action. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The periodic rise and fall of the water resulting from gravitational interaction between the sun, moon and earth. In each lunar day of 24 hours and 49 minutes there are two high tides and two low tides. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Industry related with timber harvesting and processing. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) The dimension of the physical universe which, at a given place, orders the sequence of events. 2) A designated instant in this sequence, as the time of day. Also known as epoch. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A metallic element, occurring in cassiterite, that has several allotropes; the ordinary malleable silvery-white metal slowly changes below 13.2C to a grey powder. It is used extensively in alloys, especially bronze and pewter, and as a noncorroding coating for steel. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A part of an organism consisting of a large number of cells having a similar structure and function. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A strong malleable white metallic element, which is very corrosion-resistant and occurs in rutile and ilmenite. It is used in the manufacture of strong lightweight alloys, especially aircraft parts. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A white, water-insoluble powder that melts at 1560C, and which is produced commercially from the titanium dioxide minerals ilmenite and rutile; used in paints and cosmetics. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any anuran amphibian of the class Bufonidae, such as Bufo bufo of Europe. They are similar to frogs but are more terrestrial, having a drier warty skin. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The grey, brown, or blackish mixture of gases and suspended carbon particles resulting from the combustion of tobacco. Tobacco smoke is inhaled and distributes toxins widely throughout the body and causes an enormous variety of illness among users and among non-smokers exposed to tobacco smoke.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A rapidly rotating column of air developed around a very intense low-pressure centre. It is associated with a dark funnel-shaped cloud and with extremely violent winds (>300km/h) blowing in a counterclockwise spiral, but accompanied by violent downdraughts. The precise mechanisms are not fully understood but the following atmospheric conditions appear to be necessary for tornado development: a layer of warm moist air at low altitude; a layer of dry air at higher altitude with an inversion of temperature at about 1.000 m; a triggering mechanism, usually in the form of an active, intense cold front or solar heating of the ground which will create a vortex. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any herbivorous terrestrial chelonian reptile of the family Testudinidae, of most warm regions, having a heavy dome-shaped shell and clawed limbs. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The sum of parameters that must be taken into account when assessing water quality (organoleptic factors, physico-chemical factors, toxic substances, microbiological parameters. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The temporary movement of people to destinations outside their normal places or work and residence, the activities undertaken during their stay in those destinations and the facilities created to cater for their needs. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: All the services connected with tourism, especially when regarded as an industry. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any section of a region which attracts travelers, often because of its scenery, objects of interest or recreational activities. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A result produced by the ingestion or contact of poisonous materials. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The degree of danger posed by a substance to animal or plant life. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Metals (usually heavy metals) which interfere with the respiration, metabolism or growth of organisms. (Source: EPAGLO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of characterizing and evaluating the inherent toxicity of a chemical substance, a poison, etc. (Source: KORENa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Test for the determination of the inherent toxicity of a chemical. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A science that deals with poisons, their actions, their detection, and the treatment of the conditions they produce. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any product which can cause acute or chronic injury to the human body or which is suspected of being able to cause disease or injury under some conditions. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A chemical or mixture that may present a risk or injury to health or the environment. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Refuse posing a significant hazard to the environment or to human health when improperly handled; includes carcinogenic, mutagenic, teratogenic or phytotoxic wastes, or wastes harmful to aquatic species, or poisonous wastes. (Source: DEE / HMD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A poisonous substance generally of plant or animal origin. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any of various chemical elements that occur in very small amounts in organisms and are essential for many physiological and biochemical processes. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) Both metals and non-metals, essential for the metabolic processes of algae, invertebrates and vertebrates. Organisms that derive nearly all their energy via photosynthesis are especially dependent upon dissolved trace substances. 2) Impurities that are present at small but detectable levels. (Source: NATURE / GEMAIR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A large group of plants characterized by the presence of specialized conducting tissues (xylem and phloem) in the roots, stems, and leaves. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A formulated or systematic method for following or tracing environmentally related issues or concerns. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act or process of buying, selling or exchanging goods and services at either wholesale or retail, within a country or between countries. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Tradable emissions permits are used in an environmental regulatory scheme where the sources of the pollutant to be regulated (most often an air pollutant) are given permits to release a specified number of tons of the pollutant. The government issues only a limited number of permits consistent with the desired level of emissions. The owners of the permits may keep them and release the pollutants, or reduce their emissions and sell the permits. The fact that the permits have value as an item to be sold gives the owner an incentive to reduce their emissions. (Source: WEATHE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act or process of buying, selling, or exchanging commodities and the use of goods and services. (Source: ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An artificial restraint on the free exchange of goods and services between nations. The most common types of trade barriers are tariffs, quotas, and exchange control. Such obstacles to trade are usually imposed by a country that wishes to protect domestic products in their home market against foreign competition, better its terms of trade, reduce domestic unemployment, or improve its balance-of-payments position. The raising of trade barriers by one country often provokes other nations position. Generally, the effect of a trade barrier is to reduce the volume of trade while increasing the domestic price of the protected good. Thus, it results in a relatively inefficient allocation of world resources and reduces the level of total world income and production. (Source: GREENW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act or the business of buying and selling for money. Mercantile or commercial business in general or the buying and selling, or exchanging, of commodities, either by wholesale or retail within a country or between countries. (Source: WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Trade impacts on the environment can be direct, such as trade of endangered species, of natural resources, of natural products such as tropical timber, etc., or indirect, such as deforestation, loss of habitats, pollution from mining, from energy production, oil spills, global warming, etc., increases in transport infrastructures. (Source: NWFa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A course of action adopted and pursued by government, business or some other organization, which promotes or determines the direction for the act or process of buying, selling or exchanging goods and services within a country or between countries. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act or process of buying, selling, or exchanging commodities, at either wholesale or retail, within a country or between countries.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Commercial discrimination that apply to the exports of certain countries but not to similar goods from other countries. (Source: USIA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An organization whose members are wholly or mainly workers and whose principal purposes include the regulation of relations between workers and employers or employers' associations. (Source: DICLAW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Learned, nonrandom, systematic behavior and knowledge transmitted over several generations, especially customs and beliefs originating before the advent of modern science and technology. (Source: ANT / OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A system of treating and healing maladies based on cultural beliefs and practices handed down from generation to generation. (Source: FIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) The movement of vehicles, ships, aircraft, persons, etc., in an area or over a route. 2) The vehicles, persons, etc., moving in an area or over a route.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An unexpected incident with potential for harm occurring through the movement or collision of vessels, vehicles or persons along a land, water, air or space route. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The organization of a more efficient movement of traffic within a given road network by rearranging the flows, controlling the intersections and regulating the times and places for parking. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Means of controlling the number and speed of motorvehicles using a road. (Source: PHCa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Exhaust gases and vapours emitted by motorvehicles. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The determination of the required capacity and layout of highway and street facilities that can safely and economically serve vehicular movement between given points. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The fundamental facilities and systems used for the movement of vehicles, often provided through public funding. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A number of vehicles so obstructed that they can scarcely move. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The periodic or continuous surveillance or analysis of the movement of persons, objects, vehicles or other conveyances along an area of passage. (Source: TOE / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Noise emitted by vehicles (heavy vehicles, cars and motorcycles, tyre/road interaction).

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Traffic noise can be controlled by reduction at source, by fitting motor vehicles with silencers, by installing barriers which interrupt the direct path of sound or by insulating dwellings exposed to high noise levels, such as those related to motorways or airports. (Source: GRAHAWa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The movement of boats and other vessels over any water route or area. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A connected group of railroad cars, usu. pushed or pulled by a locomotive.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of bringing a person or a group of persons to an agreed standard of proficiency, by practice and instruction. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Place where people are prepared for a specific purpose. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The path described by an object moving in air or space under the influence of such forces as thrust, wind resistance, and gravity, especially the curved path of a projectile. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Polluted air and water, or any other contaminated waste, that is generated in one country and transmitted to others. (Source: BRACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Rules, guidelines or an agreement on the process of changing the administration, structure or constitution of a government or organization. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A small village, community or group of houses, or other shelters, usually located in a thinly populated area and existing there for only a short time. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: One of a group of metallic elements in which the members have the filling of the outermost shell to 8 electrons interrupted to bring the penultimate shell from 8 to 18 or 32 electrons; includes elements 21 through 29 (scandium through copper), 39 through 47 (yttrium through silver), 57 through 79 (lanthanum through gold), and all known elements from 89 (actinium) on. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The loss of water vapour from a plant, mainly through the stomata and to a small extent through the cuticle and lenticels. Transpiration results in a stream of water, carrying dissolved minerals salts, flowing upwards through the xylem. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any commercial venture involved in the processes of conveying things or people from one place to another. (Source: RHW / OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Transportation of gases, liquids or slurries by a system of tubes, of steel or plastics. Petroleum, natural gas and products derived from them are the main substances transported by pipelines. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Comprehensive statements of the objectives and policies which a local transport authority intends to pursue; it includes and estimate of transport expenditure, a statement of transport objectives, etc. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act or means of moving tangible objects (persons or goods) from place to place. Often involves the use of some type of vehicle. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A programme of action to provide for present and future demands for movement of people and goods. Such a programme is preceded by a transport study and necessarily includes consideration of the various modes of transport. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Transfer of mass, momentum, or energy in a system as a result of molecular agitation, including such properties as thermal conduction and viscosity. (Source: PITT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: System of lines of movements or communication by road, rail, water or air. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: To catch an animal in a mechanical device or enclosed place or pit. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Moving from one place to another generally by using a transportation mean. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Expenditure of money or the amount of money incurred for journeying or going from one place to another by some mode of transportation. (Source: ISEP / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An international agreement in writing between two states or a number of states. Treaties are binding in international law; some treaties create law only for those states that are parties to them. (Source: DICLAW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any large woody perennial plant with a distinct trunk giving rise to branches or leaves at some distance from the ground. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An area where trees, shrubs, or plants are grown for transplanting, for use as stocks for budding and grafting. (Source: ECHO2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The general drift, tendency, or bent of a set of statistical data as related to time or another related set of statistical data. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Azines that contain three nitrogen atoms in their molecules. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Method in which water drips to the soil from perforated tubes or emitters. This irrigation technology is water conserving compared to flooding, furrows, and sprinklers. (Source: CNIE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Three fundamental principles of environmental policy: precautionary principle, polluter pays-principle and cooperation principle. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The hydrogen isotope having mass number 3; it is one form of heavy hydrogen, the other being deuterium. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any of the feeding levels through which the passage of energy through an ecosystem proceeds; examples are photosynthetic plants, herbivorous animals, and microorganisms of decay. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The interacting system of a biological community and its non-living environmental surroundings in the land and water of the equatorial region between the Tropic of Cancer and the Tropic of Capricorn. (Source: TOE / ENC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The interacting system of a biological community and its non-living environmental surroundings in forests found in tropical regions near the equator, which are characterized by warm to hot weather and abundant rainfall. (Source: TOE / DOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A vegetation class consisting of tall, close-growing trees, their columnar trunks more or less unbranched in the lower two-thirds, and forming a spreading and frequently flat crown; occurs in areas of high temperature and high rainfall. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The most valuable and the richest ecosystem on Earth. It plays a critical part in the Earth's life support systems and house 50%, and possibly as much as 90%, of all the species on Earth. It is a key storehouse of foods, oils and minerals, and a source of ingredients that make up a range of medical treatments. It also represents home and livelihood for many people. However, more than half of the rainforests have disappeared, chopped down for valuable tropical hardwoods, or cleared to provide areas for cattle grazing or human habitation. The forests play an important part in climate patterns, and deforestation is thought to be responsible for 18% of global warming. Furthermore, as they disappear there is also an albedo effect - a damaging increase in the sunlight reflected - which affects wind and rainfall patterns. (Source: WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The region of the earth's surface lying between two parallels of latitude on the earth, one 2327' north of the equator and the other 2327' south of the equator, representing the points farthest north and south at which the sun can shine directly overhead and constituting the boundaries of the Torrid Zone. (Source: AMHER)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The lowest of the concentric layers of the atmosphere, occurring between the Earth's surface and the tropopause. It is the zone where atmospheric turbulence is at its greatest and where the bulk of the Earth's weather is generated. It contains almost all the water vapour and aerosols and three-quarters of the total gaseous mass of the atmosphere. Throughout the troposphere temperature decreases with height at a mean rate of 6.5C/km and the whole zone is capped by either an inversion of temperature or an isothermal layer at the tropopause. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Tropospheric ozone is a secondary pollutant formed from emissions of nitrogen oxides, non-methane volatile organic compounds and carbon monoxide. Ozone scars lung tissue, makes eyes sting and throats itch. It has been implicated as a contributor to forest dieback, damage to agricultural crops, etc. (Source: WPR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A main road, especially one that is suitable for heavy vehicles. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any new and abnormal growth, specifically one in which cell multiplication is uncontrolled and progressive. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An area supporting some vegetation (lichens, mosses, sedges and low shrubs) between the northern upper limit of trees and the lower limit of perennial snow on mountains, and on the fringes of the Antarctic continent and its neighbouring islands. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A underground passageway, especially one for trains or cars that passes under a mountain, river or a congested urban area. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Cloudy or hazy appearance in a naturally clear liquid caused by a suspension of colloidal liquid droplets or fine solids. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A fluid acceleration machine for generating rotary mechanical power from the energy in a stream of fluid. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A sea-going vessel that includes space between two continuous floor-like surfaces or platforms, which is also designed for bulk shipments of liquids or gases. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Oil tank vessels provided with a double-hull to meet the regulatory safety requirements in oil transportation. Requirements include minimum values for depths and breadth of double bottoms. Also called double-hull tank vessel. (Source: PZa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An internal combustion engine whose cycle is completed in two strokes of the piston. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The class or category of an enterprise or organization involved in an economy. (Source: ISEP / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A class or category of interests or remedies recognized in law or equity that create in the holder a right to the interest or its proceeds, typically taking the form of money, property or privilege. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The different, specific methods of business administration. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A severe tropical cyclone in the western Pacific. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A rubber ring placed over the rim of a wheel of a road vehicle to provide traction and reduce road shocks. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Separation of colloidal or very fine solid materials by filtration through microporous or semipermeable mediums. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Sound waves having a frequency above about 20,000 hertz. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The part of the electromagnetic spectrum with wavelengths shorter than light but longer than x-rays; in the range of 4-400 nm. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: United Nations Conference on Environment and Development, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, 1992. (Source: WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Place where waste is left on the ground and not buried in a hole. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Sealing of a landfill with a relatively impermeable barrier designed to keep leachate inside. Liner materials include plastic and dense clay. (Source: EPAGLO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Storage located underground designed to hold gasoline or other petroleum products or chemical solutions. (Source: LEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A train for transportation of people, mostly beneath the surface of the ground, in order to lessen the traffic. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A segment of the population that does not have access to the rights or benefits granted to the rest of society, often because of low economic or social status. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any commercial activity, position or site associated with the preparation of the dead for burial and the management and arrangement of funerals. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Point of water disposal located below the sea surface. (Source: LANDYa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The condition of being without remunerative employment. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Hoofed mammals, including the Artiodactyla and Perissodactyla. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A voluntary association of around 180 state signatory to the UN charter (1945), whose primary aim is to maintain international peace and security, solve economic, social, and political problems through international co-operation, and promote respect for human rights.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Petrol with a low octane rating, which has no lead additives in it and therefore creates less lead pollution in the atmosphere. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Areas where significant reductions in ozone forming pollutants have been achieved through industrial initiatives to control and/or prevent pollution, through implementation of transportation improvement plans, national efforts to reduce automobile tailpipe emissions and lower the volatility (evaporation rate) of gasoline. (Source: CIHUNT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Water that has not been treated. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The body of a bicameral legislature comprising either representatives of member states in a federation or a select number of individuals from certain privileged estates or social classes. (Source: (Source: CIV / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A metallic element highly toxic and radioactive; used as nuclear fuel. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A planned, coordinated group of activities or services intended for improving urban centers in order to provide healthy and safe living conditions, efficient transport and communication, adequate public facilities and aesthetic surroundings. (Source: RHW / INP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Areas within the legal boundaries of cities and towns; suburban areas developed for residential, industrial or recreational purposes. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Condition where part of a city or town becomes old or dirty or ruined, because businesses and wealthy families have moved away from it. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A plan, outline or preliminary sketch of, or for, a city or town. (Source: ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any physical extension of, or changes to, the uses of land in metropolitan areas, often involving subdivision into zones; construction or modification of buildings, roads, utilities and other facilities; removal of trees and other obstructions; and population growth and related economic, social and political changes. (Source: CGP / AAG)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A binding rule or body of rules prescribed by government to regulate public services and the competing claims of residential, commercial and industrial interests in municipal areas generally characterized by moderate to high population density. (Source: CGP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Towns and cities viewed as ecosystems, having an input of matter and energy, recycling within the system, and an output of matter and energy into the surroundings. (Source: GILP96)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Supply of essential services to the community, e.g. electricity, gas, water. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The complex of private and public gardens in an urban area. (Source: DIFID)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The state of being or becoming a community with urban characteristics. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The traits, patterns and structure of a city's specific geographic area, including its biological composition, its physical environment and its social patterns. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The administration, organization and planning performed for cities or towns, particularly the process of converting farmland or undeveloped land into offices, businesses, housing and other forms of development. (Source: DOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The activity of designing, organizing or preparing for the future lay-out and condition of a city or town. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A course of action adopted and pursued by government, business or some other organization, which seeks to improve or develop cities or towns through land use planning, water resource management, central city development, policing and criminal justice, or pollution control. (Source: MGHME)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Pollution of highly populated areas mainly deriving from motor vehicles, industrial plants, combustion and heating plants, etc. (Source: GREMES)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The total number of persons inhabiting a city, metropolitan region or any area where the sum of residents exceeds a designated amount. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A continuing process of remodelling urban areas by means of rehabilitation and conservation as well as redevelopment. Urban renewal programmes are generally undertaken by public authorities and concern those parts of the city which have fallen below current standards of public acceptability. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The renovation or redevelopment of the decaying areas of cities by the demolition or up-grading of existing dwellings and buildings and a general improvement in environmental conditions. (Source: GILP96)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal:
A collection of dwellings located in an urban area.
(Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A state of bodily or mental tension developed through city living, or the physical, chemical, or emotional factors that give rise to that tension. (Source: MED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The built-up components, the street system and the facilities which make up an urban unit. (Source: ZINZAN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The study and theory of building and other physical needs in cities or predominantly urban cultures. (Source: ECHO2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Movements of vehicles and people within a city. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal:
Water destined for private and public use in a town.
(Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The distribution of water, including collection, treatment and storage, for use in a town, city or municipal area, and used generally for domestic and industrial needs. (Source: WWC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A family of mammals in the order Carnivora including the bears and their allies. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Recyclable material from discarded motor vehicle tyres. (Source: APD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Making use of free time to carry out recreational activities. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Calorific value is the heat per unit mass produced by complete combustion of a given substance. Calorific values are used to express the energy values of fuels; usually these are expressed in megajoules per kilogram. They are also used to measure the energy content of foodstuffs; i.e. the energy produced when the food is oxidized in the body. The units here are kilojoules per gram. Calorific values are measured using a bomb calorimeter (apparatus consisting of a strong container in which the sample is sealed with excess oxygen and ignited electrically. The heat of combustion at constant volume can be calculated from the resulting rise in temperature). (Source: DICCHE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The use of a source of supply from a municipal or regional area, which can be readily drawn upon when needed. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Use of chemical or biological substances to deliberately kill unwanted plants or animals. (Source: DUNSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A condition or extent of time in a government enforced contract, instrument or agreement that lacks precision, distinguishing characteristics or fixed boundaries. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any low-lying land bordered by higher ground; especially an elongate, relatively large, gently sloping depression of the Earth's surface, commonly situated between two mountains or between ranges of hills or mountains, and often containing a stream with an outlet. It is usually developed by stream erosion, but may be formed by faulting. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An appraised, evaluated or estimated element or ingredient of a biological community and its non-living environmental surroundings. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A silvery-white, ductile metal resistant to corrosion; used in alloy steels and as an x-ray target. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The deliberate or wanton destruction of personal or public property caused by a vandal. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Species which have disappeared from an area because of adverse environmental conditions. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The partial pressure of water vapour in the atmosphere. For a liquid or solid, the pressure of the vapour in equilibrium with the liquid or solid. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A transparent surface coating which is applied as a liquid and then changes to a hard solid; all varnishes are solutions of resinous materials in a solvent. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An agent or organism that acts as a carrier or transmitter of a human illness. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Number of plants growing on a certain area of land. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Cultivation of herbaceous plants that are used as food. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Study of the relationships between plants and their environment. (Source: LBC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The selection by man of particular genotypes in a plant population because they exhibit desired phenotypic characters. (Source: LBC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An edible, mixed glyceride oil derived from plants (fruit, leaves, and seeds), including cottonseed, linseed, tung, and peanut; used in food oils, shortenings, soaps, and medicine, and as a paint drying oil. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any of various processes, either sexual or asexual, by which a plant produces one or more individuals similar to itself. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any of various herbaceous plants having parts that are used as food. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Waste, comprised mainly of vegetable matter, which is capable of being decomposed by microorganisms. (Source: BHE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) The plants of an area considered in general or as communities, but not taxonomically; the total plant cover in a particular area or on the Earth as a whole. 2) The total mass of plant life that occupies a given area. (Source: ALL / MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A community of plants or plant life that share distinguishable characteristics. (Source: PEM)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal:
Any conveyance in or by which people or objects are transported.
(Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An aeriform fluid of fine particles suspended in air, produced and vented as a byproduct of the operation of wheeled machines or conveyances self-propelled by internal combustion engines. (Source: RHW / MHD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An official periodical examination of an automobile, truck, boat, airplane or other means of conveyance to determine compliance in design or operation with legal standards for safety or pollution emissions. (Source: DAM / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A sector of the economy in which an aggregate of commercial enterprises is engaged in the manufacture and sale of equipment that conveys people, goods or materials by land, air or water. (Source: SIC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of supplying or removing air, by natural or mechanical means, to or from any space; such air may or may not have been conditioned. (Source: HARRIS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Small animals and insects that can be harmful and which are difficult to control when they appear in large numbers. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any chordate animal of the subphylum Vertebrata, characterized by a bony or cartilaginous skeleton and a well-developed brain: the group contains fishes, amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The branch of medical practice which treats of the diseases and injuries of animals. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A long high bridge, usually held up by many arches, which carries a railway or a road over a valley or other similar area at a lower level. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A periodic motion of small amplitude and high frequency, characteristic of elastic bodies. (Source: ZINZAN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A format or system used to record and transmit visual or audiovisual information by translating moving or still images into electrical signals. (Source: MVG)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A group of houses and other buildings, such as a church, a school and some shops, which is smaller than a town, usually in the countryside. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The residual liquid from the distillation of alcoholic liquors, specifically, that remaining from the fermentation and distillation of beet-sugar molasses, valuable as yielding potassium salts, ammonia, etc.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The study of submicroscopic organisms known as viruses. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Submicroscopic agents that infect plants, animals and bacteria, and are unable to reproduce outside the tissues of the host. A fully formed virus consists of nucleic acid (DNA or RNA) surrounded by a protein and lipid (fat) coat. The nucleic acid of the virus interferes with nucleic acid-synthesizing mechanism of the host cell, organizing it to produce more viral nucleic acid. Viruses cause many diseases (e.g., mosaic diseases of many cultivated plants, myxomatosis, foot and mouth disease, the common cold, influenza, measles, poliomyelitis). Many plant viruses are transmitted by insects, some by eelworms. Animal viruses are spread by contact, droplet infection or by insect vectors and some are spread by the exchange of body fluids. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Energy dissipation and generation of stresses in a fluid by the distortion of fluid elements; quantitatively, when otherwise qualified, the absolute viscosity. Also known as flow resistance. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An organic compound present in variable, minute quantities in natural foodstuffs and essential for the normal processes of growth and maintenance of the body. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: That division of horticulture concerned with grape growing, studies of grape varieties, methods of culture, and insect and disease control. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A list of words or phrases of a language, technical field or some specialized area, usually arranged in alphabetical order and often provided with brief definitions and with foreign translations. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A special training for a regular occupation or profession, especially, one for which one is specially suited or qualified.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Organic compound readily passing off by evaporation. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The property of a substance or substances to convert into vapor or gas without chemical change. (Source: LEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The ejection of solid, liquid, or gaseous material from a volcano. (Source: ZINZAN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The processes by which magma and its associated gases rise into the crust and are extruded onto the Earth's surface and into the atmosphere. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A vent in the surface of the Earth through which magma and associated gases and ash erupt; also, the form or structure, usually conical, that is produced by the ejected material. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The total amount of refuse or unusable material that enters a process or system. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Unpaid activities done by citizens often organized in associations, to provide services to others, particularly to elderly and poor people, handicapped, etc. (Source: ZINZAN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A chemical reaction of sulfur (or other vulcanizing agent) with rubber or plastic to cause cross-linking of the polymer chains; it increases strength and resiliency of the polymer. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Species which is likely to become endangered unless protective measures are taken. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The Wadden sea is a shallow sea extending along the North Sea coasts of The Netherlands, Germany and Denmark. It is a highly dynamic ecosystem with tidal channels, sands, mud flats, salt marshes, beaches, dunes, river mouths and a transition zone to the North Sea, the offshore zone. Most parts of the Wadden Sea, in particular in The Netherlands and Lower Saxony, are sheltered by barrier islands and contain smaller or wider areas of intertidal flats. The present form of the Wadden Sea is the result of both natural forces and action by man. Twice a day, on average, 15 km3 of sea water enter the Wadden sea. With the water from the North Sea, large amount of sand and silt are imported which settle in places with little water movement. During low tides large parts of the Wadden Sea emerge. These so-called tidal flats cover about 2/3 of the tidal area and are one of its most characteristic features. Nowhere in the world can such a large unbroken stretch of tidal flats be found. They account for 60% of all tidal areas in Europe and North Africa. (Source: CWSS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: System which compensates the employees with a fixed sum per piece, hour, day or another period of time, covering all compensations including salary.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A vertical construction made of stone, brick, wood, etc., with a length and height much greater than its thickness, used to enclose, divide or support. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A conflict or a state of hostility between two or more parties, nations or states, in which armed forces or military operations are used. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Animal which has a body temperature that stays the same and does not change with the temperature of its surroundings. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A scheme or method of acting developed in advance to notify as quickly as possible the affected population of any sudden, urgent and usually unexpected occurrence requiring immediate action. (Source: ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any series of procedures and devices designed to detect sudden or potential threats to persons, property or the environment, often utilizing radar technology. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Extravagant or useless consumption or expenditures. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Material, often unusable, left over from any manufacturing, industrial, agricultural or other human process; Material damaged or altered during a manufacturing process and subsequently left useless. (Source: HMD / OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Exhaust or gaseous air given off by any industrial, manufacturing or chemical process. (Source: TOE / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An investigation carried out to decide what arrangements are appropriate for dealing with different kinds of wastes. (Source: PORTa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The inventory of all waste produced or recovered during a certain time period, classified by type and quantity. (Source: DOG)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A container for litter, rubbish, etc. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A grouping by type of unusable material left over from any process. (Source: ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Imposed fee, expense, or cost for the management of refuse or unwanted materials left over from a manufacturing process. (Source: TOE / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The arrangement of unwanted materials left over from manufacturing processes or refuse from places of human or animal habitation into a variety of categories based on chemical and microbiological constituents or other common characteristics. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The periodic or on-demand removal of solid waste from primary source locations using a collection vehicle and followed by the depositing of this waste at some central facility or disposal site. (Source: GSW / ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The gathering and transporting of refuse from its place of origin. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The component material types, by percentage or weight, emanating from any source. (Source: AWD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any specialized procedure or method used to transform refuse from one state, form or chemical composition into another. (Source: RHW / ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The removal of gaseous components form waste. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The orderly process of discarding unwanted or useless material. (Source: GSW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Law that settles the rules concerning the disposal, recycling and treatment of wastes. (Source: DIZAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The amount of money incurred for the action of removing or getting rid of refuse or unwanted materials left over from a manufacturing process. (Source: EFP / OED / TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The planned discharge, deposit or burial of refuse or other unserviceable material into the surface of the earth, as in a landfill. (Source: OED / LIV / CTC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Imposed fee, expense, or cost for the action of removing or getting rid of refuse or unwanted materials left over from a manufacturing process. (Source: TOE / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Area where wastes are deposited and burned. (Source: ZINZAN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The disposal of solid wastes without environmental controls. (Source: LANDYa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Exchange of the recyclable part of wastes. This procedure allows to minimize waste volume and the cost relating to waste disposal. The basis of waste exchange is the concept that "one company's waste is another company's raw material". (Source: ECOUK / ECHO2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Transporting unwanted materials, including those leftover from a manufacturing processes, refuse, or trash to other countries or areas for the conduct of foreign trade. (Source: TOE / MGHME)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Heating and power production plant where fuel is provided from refuse. (Source: PHCa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Heating plant where fuel is provided from refuse. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal:
Power station that functions with refuse-derived fuel.
(Source: PARCORa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any unusable aeriform fluid, or suspension of fine particles in air, given off by a manufacturing process or the burning of a substance in a enclosed area. (Source: OED / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The direct or indirect discharge of exhaust gas into the atmosphere. (Source: LEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Qualitative and quantitative analysis of exhaust gases emitted from vehicles, industrial plants, etc. in order to asses their composition. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Reduction of the quantity of gaseous emissions in the atmosphere, from motorvehicles, industrial and heating plants, etc. by the adoption of clean technologies, the effectiveness of process operations, the improvement of fuel quality and the installment of chimney stacks high enough to ensure the dispersion of gases. (Source: FLGISA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Discarded material from the glass manufacturing process or from used consumer products made of glass. (Source: GMR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: By-product of the wet limestone flue gas desulphurisation process. (Source: PORTa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Heat derived from the cooling process of electric power generating plants and which can cause thermal pollution of water courses, promoting algal bloom. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The release of heat generated as a byproduct from industrial or power generation processes. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Waste heat applications include space heating and refrigeration in urban areas, thawing of ice-bound seaways, agricultural use to stimulate growth and to extend the growing season and in aquaculture to stimulate the growth of algae, shellfish, and other potential marine food sources. (Source: PZ)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An authorization, license or equivalent control document issued by a government agency that approves bringing in refuse or unwanted materials left over from a manufacturing process from foreign countries. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Establishment where waste is burnt. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A binding rule or body of rules prescribed by a government to regulate the disposal of unwanted materials left over from a manufacturing process or the refuse from places of human or animal habitation. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The total supervision of waste production, handling, processing, storage, and transport from its point of generation to its final acceptable disposal. (Source: HMD / ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Measures or techniques, including plans and directives, that reduce the amount of wastes generated. Examples of waste minimisation are environmentally-sound recycling and source reduction practices. (Source: TOE / DEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The capability of measures or techniques that reduce the amount of refuse or unwanted materials that is generated, particularly during industrial production processes. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Oil arising as a waste product of the use of oils in a wide range of industrial and commercial activities, such as engineering, power generation and vehicle maintenance and should be properly disposed of, or treated in order to be reused. (Source: GRAHAW / DEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Newspapers, magazines, cartons and other paper separated from solid waste for the purpose of recycling.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of collecting and separating wastes in preparation for reuse. (Source: GSW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of obtaining materials or energy resources from waste. (Source: EED)

binding.name: definition
