binding.literal: A method of recovering wastes as resources which includes the collection, and often involving the treatment, of waste products for use as a replacement of all or part of the raw material in a manufacturing process. (Source: GRT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Practices that reduce the amount of waste generated by a specific source through the redesigning of products or patterns of production or consumption. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The aggregate of commercial enterprises primarily concerned with eliminating or getting rid of refuse from places of human or animal habitation or of unwanted materials left over from a manufacturing process. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Separating waste into different materials, such as glass, metal, paper, plastic, etc. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Temporary holding of waste pending treatment or disposal. Storage methods include containers, tanks, waste piles, and surface impoundments. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Transportation of wastes by means of special vehicles. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any process or combination of processes that changes the chemical, physical or biological composition or character of any waste or reduces or removes its harmful properties or characteristics for any purpose. (Source: HMD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Place where waste material is treated to make it reusable or so it may be disposed of safely. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The incorporation of wastes into natural or artificial cycles, mainly in order to recover secondary raw materials or energy.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The total amount of refuse or unusable material produced at any source. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Used water, or water that is not needed, which is permitted to escape, or unavoidably escapes from canals, ditches, reservoirs or other bodies of water, for which the owners of these structures are legally responsible. (Source: WWC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Imposed fee, expense, or cost for the management of spent or used water that contains dissolved or suspended matter from a home, community farm, or industry. (Source: TOE / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The flow of treated effluent from any wastewater treatment process. (Source: WWC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Collection and removal of wastewater deriving from industrial and urban settlements by means of a system of pipes and treatment plants. (Source: MANCOS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Liquid or waterborne wastes polluted or fouled by commercial operations. (Source: ISEP / DEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A binding rule or body of rules prescribed by a government to regulate the outflow and disposal of spent or used water from a home, community, farm or industry that contains dissolved or suspended matter. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The amount of spent or used water, often containing dissolved and suspended matter, that is found in a stream or some other body of water. (Source: WWC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Processing of waste water for reuse. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The state or condition of spent or used water that contains dissolved or suspended matter from a home, community farm or industry. (Source: TOE / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act or process of lessening the volume of used or spent water that is discharged from homes, businesses or industries. (Source: RHW / FFD / TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The removed materials resulting from physical, biological and chemical treatment of waste water. (Source: WWC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any process to which wastewater is subjected which would remove, or otherwise render harmless to human health and the environment, its constituent wastes. (Source: WWC / WQA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Plant where, through physical-chemical and biological processes, organic matter, bacteria, viruses and solids are removed from residential, commercial and industrial wastewaters before they are discharged in rivers, lakes and seas. (Source: PARCOR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Study of the chemical, physical and biological properties of water. (Source: PORT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The amount of ingoing and outgoing water in a system, which are assumed to be equal in the long term so that the water budget will balance. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any mass of water having definite hydrological, physical, chemical and biological characteristics and which can be employed for one or several purposes. (Source: FLGISA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The floor upon which any body of water rests. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The catching of water, especially rain water, in a structure such as a basin or reservoir. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The protection, development and efficient management of water resources for beneficial purposes. (Source: PARCOR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The utilization patterns and quantities entailed in a community or human group's use of water for survival, comfort and enjoyment. (Source: ODE / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A natural stream arising in a given drainage basin but not wholly dependent for its flow on surface drainage in its immediate area, flowing in a channel with a well-defined bed between visible banks or through a definite depression in the land, having a definite and permanent or periodic supply of water, and usually, but not necessarily, having a perceptible current in a particular direction and discharging at a fixed point into another body of water. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The system of pipes supplying water to communities and industries. (Source: PARCOR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Can be caused by a variety of means, e.g. farm pollution from animal wastes and silage liquor (liquors from green leaf cattle food which has had molasses added to promote fermentation and preservation; they are highly polluting and can be a seasonal cause of fish deaths in small streams), leachate from landfill sites, and spoil heaps, solvent discharge to sewers or to land and inadequate sewage treatment works. (Source: PORT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The breakdown of solid rock into smaller particles and its removal by water. As weathering, erosion is a natural geological process, but more rapid soil erosion results from poor land-use practices, leading to the loss of fertile topsoil and to the silting of dams, lakes, rivers and harbours. There are three classes of erosion by water. a) Splash erosion occurs when raindrops strike bare soil, causing it to splash, as mud, to flow into spaces in the soil and to turn the upper layer of soil into a structureless, compacted mass that dries with a hard, largely impermeable crust. b) Surface flow occurs when soil is removed with surface run-off during heavy rain. c) Channelized flow occurs when a flowing mixture of water and soil cuts a channel, which is then deepened by further scouring. A minor erosion channel is called a rill, a larger channel a gully. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Pumping of water for different purposes (i.e. agriculture, land reclamation, domestic and industrial use, etc.). (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A perpendicular or steep descent of the water of a stream, as where it crosses an outcrop of resistant rock overhanging softer rock that has been eroded or flows over the edge of a plateau of cliffed coast. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Fresh-water branchiopod crustaceans characterized by a transparent bivalve shell. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The characteristic behaviour and the total quantity of water involved in a drainage basin, determined by measuring such quantities as rainfall, surface and subsurface storage and flow, and evapotranspiration. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Water used in agriculture for irrigation and livestock. Livestock watering is only 1 percent of the total water withdrawal for agricultural use. Of all functional water uses, irrigation is the largest agricultural use of water. (Source: CORBIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Consumptive water use starts with withdrawal, but in this case without any return, e.g. irrigation, steam escaping into the atmosphere, water contained in final products, i.e. it is no longer available directly for subsequent use. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Water used by industries for purposes such as fabrication, processing, washing and cooling, which is obtained from a public supply or through self-supplied sources. (Source: WWC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Aquatic birds which constitute the order Anseriformes, including the swans, ducks, geese, and screamers. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The amount of calcium and magnesium salts dissolved in water. (Source: MGHa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Floating aquatic plant, Eichornia crassipes of tropical America, having showy bluish-purple flowers and swollen leafstalks: family Pontederiaceae. It forms dense masses in rivers, ponds, etc., and is a serious pest in the southern U.S., Java, Australia, New Zealand, and parts of Africa. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The level reached by the surface of a body of water. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Waterlogging is an effect of canal irrigation; it occurs when the water table rises to within 3 meters of a crop's roots, impeding their ability to absorb oxygen and ultimately compromising crop yields. Many factors contribute to waterlogging. These include inadequate drainage, improper balance in the use of groundwater and surface water, seepage and percolation from unlined channels, overwatering, planting crops not suited to specific soils, and inadequate preparation of land before irrigation. (Source: WRES)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Measures taken to ensure an adequate supply of water and a responsible utilization of water resources. (Source: KORENa / PARCOR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Studies conducted to estimate the quantity and the quality of pollutants, nutrients and suspended solids contained in water bodies and to assess sources and factors associated with agricultural practices, industrial activities or other human activities. (Source: DNRa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A chemical or physical agent introduced to any body of water that may detrimentally alter the natural condition of that body of water and other associated bodies of water. (Source: FFD / ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The manmade or man-induced alteration of the chemical, physical, biological and radiological integrity of water. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Precautionary measures, actions or installations implemented to avert or hinder human-made or human-induced alteration of the physical, biological, chemical and radiological integrity of water. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Measures to conserve surface and groundwater; to ensure the continued availability of water for growing domestic, commercial and industrial uses and to ensure sufficient water for natural ecosystems. (Source: GILP96a)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A machine or apparatus used to lift water, usually from a well or borehole, which is powered manually or by engine, wind or some other source. (Source: RHW / GLG)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any of several processes in which undesirable impurities in water are removed or neutralized. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Plant where water, through physical and chemical processes, is made suitable for human consumption and other purposes. (Source: PARCOR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A graded value of the components (organic and inorganic, chemical or physical) which comprise the nature of water. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: EC Directive establishing the rules relating to water for human consumption. (Source: DIRAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Water quality management concerns four major elements: the use (recreation, drinking water, fish and wildlife propagation, industrial or agricultural) to be made of the water; criteria to protect those uses; implementation plans (for needed industrial-municipal waste treatment improvements) and enforcement plans, and an anti-degradation statement to protect existing high quality waters. (Source: USC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The administration or handling of the amount of available potable water. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The power of a government agency or its administrators to administer and implement regulations, laws and government policies relating to the preservation and protection of water resources. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Water in any of its forms, wherever located - atmosphere, surface or ground - which is or can be of value to man. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Controlled utilization or protection of any supply of water so that it is potentially useful for some purpose, such as for an economic, recreational or life-sustaining purpose. (Source: MHE / EEN / WWC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Use of process wastewater or treatment facility effluent in a different manufacturing process. (Source: LEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Process by which water becomes more salty, found especially in hot countries where irrigation is practised. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Management of water resources aiming at ensuring the continued availability of water for human uses and natural ecosystems. (Source: GILP96)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The science that treats the occurrence, circulation, distribution, and properties of the waters of the earth, and their reaction with the environment. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The liquid that forms streams, lakes, and seas, and issues from the ground in springs. (Source: WEBSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Use, regulation and treatment of water and land resources of a watershed to accomplish stated objectives. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The dividing line between two adjacent river systems, such as a ridge. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any physical extension of, or changes to, the uses of land in waterfront areas. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Common liquid (H2O) which forms rain, rivers, the sea, etc., and which makes up a large part of the bodies of organisms. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A source or volume of water available for use; also, the system of reservoirs, wells, conduits, and treatment facilities required to make the water available and usable. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Transportation of goods or persons by means of ships travelling on the sea or on inland waterways. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Purification of water to make it suitable for drinking or for any other use. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Three types of water use are distinguished: a) withdrawal, where water is taken from a river, or surface or underground reservoir, and after use returned to a natural water body, e.g. water used for cooling in industrial processes. Such return flows are particularly important for downstream users in the case of water taken from rivers; b) consumptive, which starts with withdrawal but in this case without any return, e.g. irrigation, steam escaping into the atmosphere, water contained in final products, i.e. it is no longer available directly for subsequent uses; c) non-withdrawal, i.e. the in situ use of a water body for navigation (including the floating of logs by the lumber industry), fishing, recreation, effluent disposal and hydroelectric power generation. (Source: LEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A river, canal, or other navigable channel used as a means of travel or transport. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A well sunk to extract water from a zone of saturation. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Plant for treating and purifying water before it is pumped into pipes for distribution to houses, factories, schools, etc. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Power extracted from the motion of sea waves at the coast. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A moving ridge or swell of water occurring close to the surface of the sea, characterized by oscillating and rising and falling movements, often as a result of the frictional drag of the wind. (Source: OED / INP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An instrument of attack or defense in combat, as a gun, missile, or sword. (Source: AMHER)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The day-to-day meteorological conditions, especially temperature, cloudiness, and rainfall, affecting a specific place. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal:
The complex of meteorological characteristics in a given region.
(Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The changing of natural weather phenomena by technical means. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The periodic or continuous surveillance or analysis of the state of the atmosphere and climate, including variables such as temperature, moisture, wind velocity and barometric pressure. (Source: TOE / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act or process of predicting and highlighting meteorological conditions that are expected for a specific time period and for a specific area or portion of air space, by using objective models based on certain atmospheric parameters, along with the skill and experience of a meteorologist. (Source: FEM / AUS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any plant that grows wild and profusely, especially one that grows among cultivated plants, depriving them of space, food, etc. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Freeing an area of land from weeds by several means, such as herbicides, tillage, burning, mowing, and crop competition. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The gravitational force with which the earth attracts a body. By extension, the gravitational force with which a star, planet, or satellite attracts a nearby body. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Joining two metals by applying heat to melt and fuse them, with or without filler metal. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A hole dug into the earth to reach a supply of water, oil, brine or gas. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A geographic region of the African continent bordered in the west and south by the Atlantic Ocean, including the republics of Benin, Burkina Faso, Cabo Verde, Cote D'ivoire, Gambie, Ghana, Guinee Bissau, Liberia, Mali, Mauritanie, Niger, Nigeria, Sengegal, Sierra Leone and Togo. (Source: ECW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A geographic region of Asia that includes Turkey, Iran and other countries of the Middle East and the Arabian peninsula. (Source: INP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A geographic region of the European continent surrounded by the North Sea, Atlantic Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea, including Belgium, France, Germany, Great Britain, Greece, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Portugal, Spain and other member countries of the Western European Union. (Source: CIA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Areas that are inundated by surface or ground water with frequency sufficient to support a prevalence of vegetative or aquatic life that requires saturated or seasonally saturated soil conditions for growth or reproduction. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Ecosystems of areas largely inundated with water but offering elevated lands as a habitat for wildlife. This areas include swamps, both seasonal and permanent, marsh, open fresh water, shallow saline lagoons, the estuaries of rivers, floodplains and coastal sand dunes. They provide food, breeding grounds, water and sanctuary for many forms of fish, birds and other animal and plant life. They are among the most productive ecosystems producing timber, peat moss and crops such as rice and a variety of berries. (Source: GILP96 / WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Process used to remove particulate matter and/or gaseous pollutants by means of an aqueous stream or slurry. (Source: KORENa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) An air cleaning device that literally washes out the dust. Exhaust air is forced into a spray chamber, where fine water particles cause the dust to drop from the air stream. The dust-ladden water is then treated to remove the solid material and is often recirculated. 2) Equipment through which a gas is passed to remove impurities (solid, liquid, or gaseous particles) by intimate contact with a suitable liquid, usually an aqueous medium. (Source: LANDY / BRACK / ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Organic refuse or material left over from a manufacturing process, which is characterized by the presence of moisture. (Source: RHW / GRP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Large marine mammals of the order Cetacea; the body is streamlined, the broad flat tail is used for propulsion, and the limbs are balancing structures. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Catching whales to use as food or for their oil, etc. Whales are the largest mammals still in existence. They are caught mainly for their oils, though in some case for food. Some species of whale have become extinct because of overexploitation and the population of many of the existing species is dangerously low. Commercial whaling is severely restricted. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The business of selling goods to retailers in larger quantities than they are sold to final consumers but in smaller quantities than they are purchased from manufacturers. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Not domesticated animals living independently of man. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Animals and plants that grow independently of people, usually in natural conditions. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A series of measures required to maintain or restore the natural habitats and the populations of species of wild fauna and flora at a favourable status. (Source: ECHO1)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Suitable upland or wetland areas promoting survival of wildlife. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The numerical facts or data collected through various methodologies, such as sighting surveys, which represent or estimate the size of any wildlife species for purposes such as analyzing population trends. (Source: RHW / EEN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) An area, usually in natural condition, which is reserved (set aside) by a governmental or private agency for the protection of particular species of animals during part or all of the year. 2) An area designated for the protection of wild animals, within which hunting and fishing is either prohibited or strictly controlled. (Source: UNUN / LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A state of nature or a quality or state of being undomesticated, untamed or uncultivated. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Plants growing in a natural state (not cultivated). (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The motion of air relative to the earth's surface; usually means horizontal air motion, as distinguished from vertical motion. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The breakdown of solid rock into smaller particles and its removal by wind. It may occur on any soil whose surface is dry, unprotected by vegetation (to bind it at root level and shelter the surface) and consists of light particles. The mechanisms include straightforward picking up of dust and soil particles by the airflow and the dislodging or abrasion of surface material by the impact of particles already airborne. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A machine for grinding or pumping driven by a set of adjustable vanes or sails that are caused to turn by the force of the wind. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Energy extracted from wind, traditionally in a windmill, but increasingly by more complicated designes including turbines, usually to produce electricity but also for water pumping. The power available from wind is proportional to the area swept by the rotating place and the cube of the wind velocity, but less than half the available power can be recovered. (Source: BRACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Power station which uses wind to drive a turbine which creates electricity. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The social position, rank or relative importance of women in society.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A wood, especially when regarded as a construction material. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A dense growth of trees more extensive than a grove and smaller than a forest. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The permanent clear-felling of an area of forest or woodland. On steep slopes this can lead to severe soil erosion, especially where heavy seasonal rains or the melting of snow at higher levels cause sudden heavy flows of water. In the humid tropics it may also lead to a release of carbon dioxide from the soil. (Source: ALL2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The interacting system of a biological community and its non-living environmental surroundings in wooded areas or land areas covered with trees and shrubs. (Source: TOE / WOR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The use of chemicals to prevent or retard the decay of wood, especially by fungi or insects; widely used preservatives include creosote, pitch, sodium fluoride and tar; especially used on wood having contact with the ground. (Source: HARRIS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Waste which is left over after the processing of raw timber. (Source: ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A textile fiber made from raw wool characterized by absorbency, resiliency and insulation. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Accident occurring in the course of the employment and caused by inherent or related factors arising from the operation of materials of one's occupation. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A mine where all the mineral that could be profitably exploited has been removed. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: All existing circumstances affecting labor in the workplace, including job hours, physical aspects, legal rights and responsibilities. (Source: CIV)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The time devoted to gainful employment or job-related activities, usually calculated as hours per day or per week. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Ploughing the soil for agricultural purposes. (Source: PHCa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any or all locations or environments where people are employed. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The Earth with all its inhabitants and all things upon it. (Source: WEBSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Sites of great cultural significance and geographic areas of outstanding universal value. They include the Pyramids of Egypt, the Grand Canyon of United States, the Taj Mahal of India, the Great Wall of China, etc. (Source: GILP96)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Accounting procedure that is used when an asset is uncollectible and is therefore charged-off as a loss. (Source: ISEP / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An act contrary to the rules of natural or legal justice. (Source: CURZON)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A deed performed by a government official or agent in exercise of police, constitutional, legislative, administrative or judicial powers that infringes upon the rights of another and causes damage, without protecting an equal or superior right. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A substance which would not normally be found in a given environment, and usually means a toxic chemical which is entirely artificial, such as a chlorinated aromatic compound or an organomercury compound. (Source: BIOTAZ)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A penetrating electromagnetic radiation, usually generated by accelerating electrons to high velocity and suddenly stopping them by collision with a solid body, or by inner-shell transitions of atoms with atomic number greater than 10; their wavelength ranges from about 10(-5) angstrom to 10(3) angstroms, the average wavelength used in research being 1 angstrom. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Many species of unicellular fungi, most of which belong to the Ascomycetes and reproduce by budding. The genus Saccharomyces is used in brewing and winemaking because in low oxygen concentration it produces zymase, an enzyme system that breaks down sugars to alcohol and carbon dioxide. Saccharomyces is also used in bread-making. Some yeasts are used as a source of protein and of vitamins of the B group. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Profit or income created through an investment or a business transaction.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A young child in the first years of life. (Source: ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The state of being young; the period between childhood and adult age. (Source: ZINZAN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Job opportunities and employment for adolescents, either for financial reward or educational enrichment. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A brittle bluish-white metallic element that becomes coated with a corrosion-resistant layer in moist air and occurs chiefly in sphalerite and smithsonite. It is a constituent of several alloys, especially brass and nickel-silver, and is used in die-casting, galvanizing metals, and in battery electrodes. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Designation and reservation under a master plan of land use for light and heavy industry, dwellings, offices, and other buildings; use is enforced by restrictions on types of buildings in each zone. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Area in which animals, especially wild animals, are kept so that people can go and look at them, or study them. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The study of animals, including their classification, structure, physiology, and history. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Diseases which are biologically adapted to and normally found in animals but which under some conditions also infect man. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Method of recording all the transactions affecting the financial condition of a business or organization.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Economic good that directly satisfies human wants or desires. (Source: WEBSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A central government organization that has authority or oversight over government activity relating to the preservation and safeguarding of ecological or natural resources. (Source: BLD / TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Noise consequences on human health consist in loss of hearing and psychological effects. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The entire physical structure of an human being. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Group of sciences including sociology, anthropology, psychology, pedagogy, etc. as opposed to the humanistic group. (Source: ZINZAN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The communication or conveyance of data or materials for the purpose of enhancing knowledge from one person, place or position to another. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Acts relating to the administration of justice. (Source: CURZON)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Study of meteorological elements such as wind speed and direction, air temperature and humidity, atmospheric pressure, precipitation, evaporation, solar radiation, visibility and cloud cover in order to collect data for weather forecast or for specific research purposes. (Source: YOUNG)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Active management of nature areas in order to ensure that wildlife is protected and the quality of its environment is maintained. (Source: PHCa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Precautionary measures, actions or installations implemented to avert the probability of harm to humans, property or natural resources posed by conditions or events in the environment neither initiated nor formed by human activity. (Source: HMD / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A science dealing with the effects of physical phenomena on chemical properties. (Source: LEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The quantitative determination of the presence, extent or type of pollutant substances in the environment using mechanical means, including optical, electrical, acoustical and thermodynamic techniques. (Source: APD / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Eliminating the production of hazardous wastes and greenhouse gases at their source, within the production process. This can often be achieved through a variety of relatively simple strategies, including minor changes in manufacturing processes, substitution of non-polluting products for polluting products, and simplification of packaging. Companies practicing waste reduction have saved hundreds of millions of dollars, and used it to catalyze employee involvement and eliminate the need for expensive end-of-the-pipe filtering. (Source: GLOCHA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of evaluating and selecting alternative regulatory and non-regulatory responses to prepare for the probability of an accidental occurrence and its expected magnitude of damage, including the consideration of legal, economic and behavioral factors. (Source: HMD / TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A unified, coordinated assemblage or plan of procedures and devices intended to lower the occurrence or risk of injury, loss and danger to persons, property or the environment. (Source: OED / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The study of the behavior of foundations and structures relative to seismic ground motion, and the attempt to mitigate the effect of earthquakes on structures. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The study of society and of the relationship of individual members within society, including economics, history, political science, psychology, anthropology, and sociology. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The administration or handling of water naturally open to the atmosphere (rivers, lakes, reservoirs, ponds, streams, seas, etc.). (Source: RHW / TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Precautionary actions, procedures or installations undertaken to prevent or reduce harm to animals, plants and other organisms living in their natural state. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: That part of a town or city in which the principal public and historic buildings are located. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any activity that encourages or supports the buying, selling or exchanging of goods or services with other countries, which could include marketing, diplomatic pressure or the provision of export incentives such as credits and guarantees, government subsidies, training and consultation or advice. (Source: ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A construction of stone or similar materials such as concrete or brick. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A sandy tidal flat barren of vegetation. A tidal flat is an extensive, nearly horizontal, marshy or barren tract of land that is alternately covered and uncovered by the tide, and consisting of unconsolidated sediment (mostly mud and sand). It may form the top surface of a deltaic deposit. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Species belonging to the animal kingdom. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Species belonging to the plant kingdom. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The common beliefs, practices, customs and other cultural elements of an ethnic or social group that are rooted in the past, but are persisting into the present due to means such as arts and crafts, songs and music, dance, foods, drama, storytelling and certain forms of oral communication. (Source: VFP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A subdivision of the body of principles and regulations established by a government or other authority, generally defined by its scope or application. (Source: BLD / ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Entire network of courts in a particular jurisdiction. (Source: WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The quantitative determination of the presence, extent or type of pollutant substances in the environment by studying the actions or reactions of known chemicals to those pollutants. (Source: APD / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of cumulative reactive change following the introduction of a pollutant into the environment. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Noise emitted from various sources in an urban environment.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The state of being clean and keeping healthy conditions. (Source: PHCa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Environment where the manifold activities connected with the production of goods and services take place. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Probability of harm to human health, property or the environment posed by any aspect of the physical world other than human activity. (Source: APD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Analysis of the probability of occurrence, within a specific period of time in a given area, of a potentially damaging phenomenon of nature. (Source: GUNN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The high probability that a given hazard or situation will yield a significant amount of lives lost, persons injured, damage to property , disruption of economic activity or harm to the environment; or any product of the probability of occurrence and the expected magnitude of damage beyond a maximum acceptable level. (Source: TOE / HMD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any series of procedures and devices used by trained personnel to provide immediate assistance to persons who are in danger or injured. (Source: GT2 / HMD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The technique, practice or science of handling or controlling situations of acute difficulty, danger or instability; or the total of measures taken to provide a solution for political, economic, environmental or other similar dangers and conflicts. (Source: ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A co-ordinated body of methods or plan of procedures for levying compulsory charges for the purpose of raising revenue. (Source: ISEP / EFP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The development at any level of a general notion of the surrounding ecosystem, its foundational relationship to human life and the need to preserve its integrity. (Source: TOE / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The science that deals with the relationship of forest trees to their environment, to one another, and to other plants and to animals in the forest. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The study of the interrelationship among living organisms and between organisms and their environment, utilizing the methods or theories of science. (Source: DOE / APD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Concept derived from biology: the city is viewed as a total environment, as a life-supporting system for the large number of people concentrated there, and within this people organize themselves and adapt to a constantly changing environment. Regarded as the same as human ecology. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A broad geographic area in which there are distinctive climate patterns, ocean conditions, types of landscapes and species of plants and animals. (Source: SCHNET)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Branch of engineering concerned with the environment and its proper management. The major environmental engineering disciplines regard water supply, wastewater, stormwater, solid waste, hazardous waste, noise radiology, industrial hygiene, oceanography and the like. (Source: PORT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The application of ecological concepts to fossil and sedimentary evidence to study the interactions of Earth surface, atmosphere, and biosphere in former times. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The inheritance and preservation of the earth's or a particular region's balanced, integrated functionality as a natural habitat, with special concern for the water resources necessary to maintain the ecosystem. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) In general, a term used to describe a topographic eminence. 2) A specific altitude or height above a given level. 3) In surveying, the term refers to the angle between the horizontal and a point at a higher level. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) A deep recess hollow, or nook in a cliff or steep mountainside, or a small, straight valley extending into a mountain or down a mountainside. 2) A valley or portion of lowland that penetrates into a plateau or mountain front. (Source: BJGEO / WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A long deep, relatively narrow steep-sided valley confined between lofty and precipitous walls in a plateau or mountainous area, often with a stream at the bottom; similar to, but largest than, a gorge. It is characteristic of an arid or semiarid area (such as western U.S.) where stream downcutting greatly exceeds weathering. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A cape or promontory jutting seawards from a coastline, usually with a significant sea cliff. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A deep steep-walled half-bowl-like recess or hollow, variously described as horseshoe- or crescent-shaped or semi-circular in plan, situated high on the side of a mountain and commonly at the head of a glacial valley and produced by the erosive activity of a mountain glacier. It often contains a small round lake, and it may or may not be occupied by ice or snow. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A protuberance of the earth's crustal shell, with an area of several million square miles and sufficient elevation so that much of it above sea level. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An elongated sand or shingle bank which lies parallel to the coastline and is not submerged by the tide. If it is high enough to permit dune growth it is termed a barrier island. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A narrow inlet or bay, especially of the sea. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A fracture or a zone of fractures along which there has been displacement of the sides relative to one another parallel to the fracture. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A steep coastal declivity which may or may not be precipitous, the slope angle being dependent partly on the jointing, bedding and hardness of the materials from which the cliff has been formed, and partly on the erosional processes at work. Where wave attack is dominant the cliff-foot will be rapidly eroded and cliff retreat will take place, especially in unconsolidated materials such as clays, sands, etc., frequently leaving behind an abrasion platform at the foot of the cliff. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The high seas lying outside the exclusive economic zones of states. All states have equal rights to navigate, to overfly, to lay submarine cables, to construct artificial islands, to fish, and to conduct scientific research within the high seas. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A coastal stretch of shallow saltwater virtually cut off from the open sea by a coral reef. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The channel containing or formerly containing the water of a river. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The material surroundings of a system, process or organism. (Source: APD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A level or gently sloping tract or a slightly undulating land surface produced by extensive deposition of alluvium, usually adjacent to a river that periodically overflows its banks; it may be situated on a flood plain, a delta, or an alluvial fan. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An elongated accumulation of coral lying at low-tide level parallel to the coast but separated from it by a wide and deep lagoon or strait. The coral is thought to have formed initially on a flat surface: then as the sea-level rose in post-glacial times, thereby submerging the irregular wave-cut platform, the coral growth kept pace with the rising ocean level, so creating the great thickness witnessed today in such places as the Great Barrier Reef off the East coast of Queensland, Australia. This stretches for more than 1900 km and varies in width from about 30 km to 150 km. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The physical shape, configuration or general unevenness of a part of the Earth's surface, considered with reference to variation of height and slope or to irregularities of the land surface; the elevation or difference in elevation, considered collectively, of a land surface. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An ordinance or decree regarding an area of ecological habitat that is characterized by a high degree of uniformity in its environmental conditions and in its distribution of plants and animals. (Source: DOE / OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Terrestrial or aquatic area or other fragile natural setting with unique or highly-valued environmental features. (Source: EPAGLO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The non-living components of the environment (rocks, minerals, soil, water and climate). (Source: WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Waters, including wetlands, that serve as habitat for interrelated and interacting communities and populations of plants and animals. (Source: LEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any parcel of land, large or small, under public or private control, that already has, or with remedial action could achieve, desirable environmental attributes. These attributes contribute to the retention and/or creation of wildlife habitat, soils stability, water retention or recharge, vegetative cover, and similar vital ecological functions. Environmentally sensitive areas range in size from small patches to extensive landscape features. They can include rare or common habitats, plants and animals. (Source: DUNSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The continental as distinct from the marine and atmospheric environments. It is the environment in which terrestrial organisms live. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A permanent reservation on the seabed for the conservation of species. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A park operated and managed by a region. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any area of land or water that has been set aside for a special purpose, often to prevent or reduce harm to its wildlife and ecosystems. (Source: RHW / DOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An area of land and/or of water designated as having protected status for purposes of preserving certain biological features. Reserves are managed primarily to safeguard these features and provide opportunities for research into the problems underlying the management of natural sites and of vegetation and animal populations. Regulations are normally imposed controlling public access and disturbance. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Forest areas which are protected and guarded from deforestation because of the fragility of its ecosystems, and because they provide habitats for hundreds of species of plants and animals. (Source: TOURISa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Area of national interest which is protected under the responsibility of its owner in order to safeguard wildlife, archeological and geological sites. (Source: UNIONa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The core area of a park or of a reserve where there can be no interference with the natural ecosystem. (Source: WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Sea area where marine wildlife is protected. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A zone of the park where scientific research is allowed. Beyond this there is a buffer zone which protects the whole reserve from agricultural, industrial and urban development. (Source: WRIGHTa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The selection and detailed layout of public transport routes in the light of construction, operation, service, technology, and economic criteria. (Source: ECHO2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The wooded countryside characteristic of northern France, with small irregular-shaped fields and many hedges and copses. In the French language the word bocage refers both to the hedge itself and to a landscape consisting of hedges. Bocage landscapes usually have a slightly rolling landform, and are found mainly in maritime climates. Being a small-scale, enclosed landscape, the bocage offers much variations in biotopes, with habitats for birds, small mammals, amphibians, reptiles and butterflies. (Source: CED / DOBRIS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A plot of ground consisting of an orderly and balanced arrangement of masses of flowers, shrubs and trees, following British traditions or style. (Source: CBO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Landscape resulting from the method of cultivating land by cutting terraces or benches into slopes to create areas of flat land. The practice is common in mountainous areas where land is scarce and rainfall uncertain. (Source: GOODa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Precautionary actions, procedures or installations undertaken to prevent or reduce harm to the environmental integrity of a physical area or location. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A form of environmental management designed to allay the progressive degradation of the land by coastal erosion processes. Sea defence works can be undertaken to protect the land from erosion and encroachment by the sea and against flooding. These involve engineering solutions such as groynes, sea walls, bulkheads, revetments and breakwaters. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The restoration of the ecological quality of an area or location. (Source: ISEP / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Site which is declared protected because of its natural, landscape, artistic or archeological features in order to guarantee its conservation, maintenance and restoration. (Source: SKENEa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Area which is officially registered because of its unique features; a description is provided concerning its location, size, latitude, longitude, orientation, elevation, boundaries, wildlife, hydrological and soil characteristics, etc. (Source: IUCNa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A graphic representation of a city area or other densely populated region, portraying the location of groups or select types of people in their environment through various geographic techniques. (Source: SOC / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The state, character or behavior of a person viewed as a member of the ecosystem with attendant rights and responsibilities, especially the responsibility to maintain ecological integrity and the right to exist in a healthy environment. (Source: TOE / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Unified, combined and coordinated management of environmental problems which correlates relevant organisations, groups, individuals and disciplines by bringing the parts together for a complete approach. (Source: UNUN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A person, firm, organization, etc. that provides or pledges money for an undertaking or event.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A formulated or systematic method for the management of a city or town's natural or ecological resources. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An organized, systematic effort through various communications media to alert the general population of a given area to anything of significant interest or concern. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Fishes that migrate in a body, often between breeding places and winter feeding grounds. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Predatory mammal, including cats, lions, leopards, tigers, jaguars, and cheetahs, typically having a round head and retractile claws. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Mammals which have adapted to live in the sea, such as whales, dolphins, porpoises, etc. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Horned ruminant mammals raised in many breeds for wool, edible flesh, or skin. (Source: AMHER)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Cover or protection, as from weather or danger; place of refuge. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal:
A place where birds gather to lay eggs.
(Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Line corridors (roads, paths, and hedgerows) which lack interior habitat but may serve as movement groups for organisms. Corridors may also provide an efficient migratory pathway for animals. The presence or absence of breaks in a corridor may be a very important factor in determining the effectiveness of its conduit and barrier functions. (Source: PARCOR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Harm caused to the environment by animals as, for instance, in the case of overgrazing, trampling, etc. Overgrazing damage is reduced by properly located watering facilities to decrease daily travel by livestock. Rotation of grazing areas allows time for recovery of grass. Some land can be easily restored if grazing is allowed only during one season. Animals may cause damage to crops when agriculture land borders on virgin territory or game reserves. In addition wild animals may bring disease in valuable domestic herds. Cattle overstocking has caused serious degradation of habitat, and cattle raising is thus, to some extent, counterproductive. (Source: WPR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The habit of many animal species of moving inside their habitats or of travelling, during migrations, to different biotopes, often considerable distances apart; in aquatic environments displacements can occur horizontally or vertically while in terrestrial environments animal populations that breed in the alpine or subalpine zones in summer, move to lower levels in winter; animal displacements usually follow circadian rhythms and are related to the necessity of finding breeding, resting and feeding areas. (Source: RAMADE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Area of water where fish come each year to produce their eggs. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The locality in which an animal naturally grows or lives. It can be either the geographical area over which it extends, or the particular station in which an animal is found. (Source: WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The building of nests for egg laying and rearing of offspring. (Source: AMHER)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A group of animals inhabiting a given area. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any of various processes, either sexual or asexual, by which an animal produces one or more individuals similar to itself. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act or fact of surviving or condition of having survived. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Species native to, and restricted to, a particular geographical region. (Source: LBC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Deciduous tree which has wide leaves, as opposed to the needles on conifers. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Seaweeds communities formed by green, brown and red macroscopic algae and by sea phanerogams such as Posidonia oceanica and Zostera noltii, etc. (Source: PARCORa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A large macroscopic plant, used especially of aquatic forms such as kelp (variety of large brown seaweed which is a source of iodine and potash). (Source: LBC / PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Plants growing in areas adjacent to rivers and streams. (Source: EPAGLO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any north temperate fagaceous tree of the genus Castanea, such as Castanea sativa, which produce flowers in long catkins and nuts in a prickly bur. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A very large family of plants including cereals such as wheat, maize, etc. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Plant with elongated, planar, green leaves which measure up to 1,5 m. The flowers come out in the autumn but not every year. The fruits are dark balls, which one often finds washed up on beaches after storms. The same happens with the leaves which wilt and separate from the plant at the end of summer. It grows on sandy substrates, and has a rhizome from which several plants grow. The compact form of its growths retains the sediments pulled by the currents along the sea bed. Neptunegrass forms extensive prairies, always on the continental shelf. The plant's presence, apart from constituting an excellent refuge and food reserve for many species, gives an indication of the maturity and good condition of the whole marine ecosystem. (Source: DDGI)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A subdivision of vegetation characteristic of a certain altitude above sea level at a given latitude. (Source: ECHO2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The number of plants in an area. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Collection of trees from different parts of the world, grown for scientific study. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The study of the causal relations between geographical phenomena occurring within a particular region. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Assemblage of cultivated plants that are distinguished by any characteristics (morphology, physiology, etc.) significant for purposes of horticulture, agriculture or forestry. (Source: DUNSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Areas for the conservation of rare or endangered animal species. (Source: RAMADE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Gardens for the conservation of rare species of plants. (Source: RAMADE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Animals which have been translocated by human agency into lands or waters where they have not lived previously, at least during historic times. Such translocation of species always involves an element of risk if not of serious danger. Newly arrived species, depending on their interspecific relationships and characteristics, may act as or carry parasites or diseases, prey upon native organisms, display toxic reactions, or be highly competitive with or otherwise adversely affect native species and communities. (Source: WPR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Plants which have been translocated by human agency into lands or waters where they have not lived previously, at least during historic times. Such translocation of species always involves an element of risk if not of serious danger. Newly arrived species may be highly competitive with or otherwise adversely affect native species and communities. Some may become a nuisance through sheer overabundance. They may become liable to rapid genetic changes in their new environment. Many harmful introductions have been made by persons unqualified to anticipate the often complex ecological interaction which may ensue. On the other hand many plants introduced into modified or degraded environments may be more useful than native species in controlling erosion or in performing other positive functions. (Source: WPR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The sum of the earth's or a particular region's non-human, non-vegetable, multicellular organisms viewed as the inheritance of the present generation, especially animal species deemed worthy of preservation and protection from extinction. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The sum of the earth's or a particular region's herb, vegetable, shrub and tree life viewed as the inheritance of the present generation, especially plant species deemed worthy of preservation and protection from extinction. (Source: PPP / OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Attempts made to prevent the extinction of threatened species and populations by reintroducing them in their natural habitat. The reintroduction of species in a region requires a preliminary study to establish the reasons of their disappearance and the modifications that might have occurred in the biotopes. (Source: RBGKEWa / RAMADE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Reintroducing wild plant species to their natural habitat. The reintroduction of species in a region requires a preliminary study to establish the reasons of their disappearance and the modifications that might have occurred in the biotopes. (Source: SCIFRI / RAMADE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The planting of trees in an area, or the management of an area to allow trees to regenerate or colonize naturally, in order to produce a forest. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) Falling of old trees in a forest caused by a storm or strong wind. It plays an important role in the spontaneous regeneration of forest ecosystems. 2) A plot of land covered with trees blown down by the wind. (Source: RAMADE / CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The cutting off or removal of dead or living parts or branches of a plant to improve shape or growth. (Source: AMHERa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Forests have been exploited over the centuries as a source of wood and for obtaining land for agricultural use. The mismanagement of forest lands and forest resources has led to a situation where the forest is now in rapid retreat. The main aspects of the situation are: serious shortages in the supply of industrial wood; the catastrophic erosion and floods accompanying the stripping of forests from mountainous land; the acute shortages of fuel wood in much of the developing world; the spread of desert conditions at an alarming rate in the arid and semi-arid regions of the world; and the many environmental effects of the destruction of tropical rainforests. (Source: WPR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An extensive area of woodland that is found at natural elevations usually higher than 2000 feet. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Forest owned and managed by the State. (Source: WEBSTEa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Type of forest found in the Mediterranean area comprising mainly xerophilous evergreen trees. (Source: ALL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Forest whose trees are all in the adult stage and have reached the reproductive period. (Source: RAMADE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A low evergreen shrub formation, usually found on siliceous soils in the Mediterranean lands where winter rainfall and summer drought are the characteristic climate features. It consists of a profusion of aromatic species, such as lavender, myrtle, oleander and rosemary and often includes abundant spiny shrubs. It has been suggested that the maquis is a secondary vegetation, occupying the lands cleared of their natural evergreen oak forests by human activity. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Branch of forestry concerned with the prevention and control of damage to forests arising from the action of people or livestock, of pests and abiotic agents. (Source: DUNSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The replacement by an organism of tissues or organs which have been lost or severely injured. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Plants yielding or producing resin. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A traditional system of woodland management whereby timber trees are grown above a coppiced woodland. It is used in particular as a method of exploiting oakwoods, in which all the trees except a rather open network of tall, well-formed oaks - the standards at about fifty per hectare - are felled, leaving plenty of space for hazels and other underwood to grow and be coppiced at intervals of ten to fifteen years. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An amusement or pastime; diversion. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Large wild animals that weigh typically more than 30 lb when fully grown, hunted for food, sport or profit. (Source: CORBIT / AMHER)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Raising of shellfish in inland waters, estuaries or coastal waters, for commercial purposes. All commercial shellfish beds producing bivalve molluscs must be monitored for microbial contamination. Samples of water and shellfish flesh must be tested for the presence of algal toxins. Periodic monitoring of fish and shellfish must be carried out to check for the presence of contaminants. (Source: WRIGHTa / MAFF)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: There are two types of oyster farming: suspension culture, in which oysters are grown off bottom, in floating trays, is a labor-intensive form of cultivation that requires continuous tending and cleaning of both gear and shellfish, and bottom culture, which is similar to conventional crop farming on land; it involves selecting areas of the sea floor that provide a natural food supply, necessary currents, minimum exposure to predators, and proper temperature and then "seeding" the bottom with shellfish stock that are left to grow to market size. Then they are harvested with a bottom drag from a boat. Both suspension culture and bottom culture depend on natural food supplies for growing the shellfish being raised. (Source: MSTF)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Such fisheries belong to one of two groups: one catching demersal (bottom-living) fish, e.g. cod, haddock, plaice, sole; the other catching pelagic (surface-living) fish, e.g. anchovy, tuna, herring. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Limited portion of a water body belonging to the State where angling is allowed. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Instruction or events designed to offer learning or cultural experiences to populations without access to traditional educational institutions due to social or economic barriers. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A test given to a candidate for a certificate or a position and concerned typically with problems to be solved, skills to be demonstrated, or tasks to be performed. (Source: WEBSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Various forms, methods, and processes of formal and informal education for the continued learning of all ages and categories of the general public. Oriented toward the continued learning/developmental processes of the individual throughout life. (Source: UNUN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any education, instruction or discipline occurring at the beginning of an activity, task, occupation or life span. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The principles, practice, or profession of teaching. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Gainful employment or job-related activity pertaining to ecological concerns, including the preservation of natural resources and the integrity of the ecosystem. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Activity carried out for the benefit of the community. (Source: NDGIUR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The coordination or structuring of work practices and production processes in order to influence the way jobs are designed and performed in the workplace. (Source: NIO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A building containing a swimming pool and a large room or other places where you can play sports. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Buildings, equipment and services provided for a community. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Part of the road or a special path for the use of people riding bicycles. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A trail, slope, or course for skiing. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An established or selected course for travel consisting, typically, of secondary roads with significant scenic, cultural, historic, geological or natural features and including vistas, rest areas, and interpretive sites matching the scenic characteristics of the course. (Source: GTT / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A private, non-profit facility where plants and animals can be viewed in a natural outdoor setting. (Source: AGRENV)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The traditional and common beliefs, practices and customs of a people, which are passed on as a shared way of life, often through oral traditions such as folktales, legends, anecdotes, proverbs, jokes and other forms of communication. (Source: VFP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A small house or a hut located in the countryside. (Source: HARRIS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Provision of accommodation for rest or for residence in a room or rooms or in a dwelling place. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The community or people in general or a part or section of the community grouped because of a common interest or activity. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A route or track between one place to another. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal:
A route or track running along the coast.
(Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A guided trail, designed to explain to children a piece of countryside, the type of soil, flora, fauna, etc. Such trails may be self-guiding, using either explanatory notices set up at intervals or numbered boards referring to a printed leaflet: in other cases parties may be led by a demonstrator or warden. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A place near the sea where people spend their holidays and enjoy themselves. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A place in the mountains where people spend their holidays and enjoy themselves. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Resort where sports held in the open air on snow or ice, especially skiing are practiced. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A land carriage so constructed that it can be used on any kind of road or rough terrain and can be operated for many purposes, such as carrying goods, transporting the injured, conveying passengers, etc. (Source: ECHO1)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The number of people relative to the space occupied by them. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The number of people available and eligible for employment within a given enterprise, region or nation. (Source: ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act of assigning various hours of one's day, week or year to particular activities, especially those falling within the categories of work and leisure. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Goods which have a reasonably long life and which are not generally consumed in use: e.g. refrigerator. (Source: WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A good bought by consumers that tends to last for less than a year. Common examples are food and clothing. The notable thing about nondurable goods is that consumers tend to continue buying them regardless of the ups and downs of the business cycle. (Source: AMOS2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A term of variable content and meaning. It may include every species of personal chattels or property. Items of merchandise, supplies, raw materials, or finished goods. Land is excluded. (Source: DICLAW / WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The total of economic assets, including both physical or storable objects and intangible acts of human assistance. (Source: ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Determining or planning for allotment of time in hours, days, weeks, etc. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: External conditions or surroundings in which people live or work. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A product life cycle includes the following phases: acquisition of raw materials, production, packaging, distribution, use, recyling, and disposal. (Source: HELIOSa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A mark, seal or written identification attached or affixed to products that provides specific ecological information allowing consumers to make comparisons with other similar products, or instructions on how to safely use or properly recycle or dispose of both products and packaging. (Source: OPP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The formal assertion in writing that a commodity, service or other product has attained a recognized and relatively high grade or level of excellence. (Source: BLD / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A measurement of the development level in a country or community, gauged by factors such as personal income, education, life expectancy, food consumption, health care, technology and the use of natural resources. (Source: TEX)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The relationship between the amount or quantity of a commodity that is available for purchase and the desire or ability of consumers to buy or purchase the commodity, which, in theory, determines the commodity's price in a free market. (Source: MGHME)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any imbalance or disparity among inhabitants of the same living environment deemed inappropriate, unjust or detrimental to that environment's integrity. (Source: TOE / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Unequal rewards or opportunities for different individuals within a group or groups within a society. If equality is judged in terms of legal equality, equality of opportunity, or equality of outcome, then inequality is a constant feature of the human condition.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A traditional or legendary story, usually dealing with supernatural beings, ancestors, heroes or events, that is with or without determinable basis of fact or a natural explanation, but is used to explain some practice, rite or phenomenon of nature, or to justify the existence of a social institution. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Not In My BackYard: phrase used to describe people who encourage the development of agriculture land for building houses or factories, provided it is not near where they themselves are living. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Study of the effects of social structure on cognition and behavior, of processes of face-to-face interaction, and of the negotiation of social order. (Source: SASW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A system of values, ideas and practices established to orient individuals in their community and culture and to provide them with naming, classification and communication codes. (Source: SRD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A consciousness, sensibility or sympathetic perception of the physical world and its scenery in their uncultivated state. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Economic and social structure of communities, tax rates, characteristic types of development. (Source: PASTU)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The legal right of access to administrative documents or the opportunity to avail oneself of the same. (Source: BLACKa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any formal and legitimate step taken or decision made on matters of policy by a chief or other top-level officer within an organization. (Source: DAM)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An administrative body or system in which political direction or control is exercised over a designated area or an administrative division of a city, county or larger geographical area. (Source: RHW / BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The skill, knowledge, qualification, capacity or authority associated with the chief of an administrative department or other high ranking official selected by the head of state. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A native or naturalized member of a state or nation who owes allegiance, bears responsibilities and obtains rights, including protection, from the government. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An administrative body or system in which political direction and control is exercised over the community of a city, town or small district. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
