binding.literal: An infrastructure, body of people or homogenous constituency that is physically situated in a localized exurban area. (Source: RHW / TEF)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Formal discussion or dispute on a particular matter among the members of the parliament. (Source: ZINZANa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The underlying reason or cause, a psychological or social factor, that incites or stimulates managers, executives or supervisors to complete tasks that achieve organizational or company goals. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A design, scheme or project pertaining to the production, distribution and use of income, wealth and commodities. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The fundamental doctrine or tenet that policy making decisions should be made at the most decentralized level, in which a centralized governing body would not take action unless it it is more effective than action taken at a lower government level. (Source: ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The transfer of funds from developed to underdeveloped countries. (Source: GOODa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Economic, military, technical or financial aid or support given to nations or countries in need, often from other governments or international or intergovernmental organizations. (Source: INP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Government aid in the form of monies or food stamps to the poor, disabled, aged or to dependent children. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Organised method of recording all business transactions in the national economy.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A separate financial record or statement that discloses financial activity in a particular area and supplements existing financial records. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any spending done by a person living alone or by a group of people living together in shared accommodation and with common domestic expenses. (Source: ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Spending by national or local government, government-owned firms or quasi-autonomous non-government organizations. (Source: ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Money or financial resources set aside to interpose or interfere in any business affair in order to affect an outcome. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Monetary resources set aside for some purpose. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Fund organized by the European Monetary System in which members of the European Community deposit reserves to provide a pool of resources to stabilize exchange rates and to finance balance of payments in support of the pending full European Monetary Union.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An international organization established in 1944, affiliated with the United Nations that acts as an international bank facilitating the exchange of national currencies and providing loans to member nations. It also evaluates the performance of the economies of the world's countries. (Source: KINGST)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Rewards or penalties offered by government or management to induce an economic sector, company or group of workers to act in such a way as to produce results that plan objectives or policy goals. (Source: ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The total output of goods and services produced by a national economy in a given period, usually a year, valued at market prices. It is gross, since no allowance is made, for the value of replacement capital goods. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Compulsory charges levied by a government unit in special or unique instances for the purpose of raising revenue to pay for services or improvements for the general public benefit. (Source: EFP / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The periodic or continuous verification of the accounts, assets and liabilities of a company or other organization, often to confirm compliance with legal and professional standards. (Source: West's / ODE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Evaluation of the natural structures, resources and landscapes to ensure their careful management and preservation. (Source: GILP96a)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The value or the amount of money exchanged for the production and sustained supply of water. (Source: EFP / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The buying, selling, advertising, shipping, and storing of goods in compliance with ecological principles. (Source: ISEP / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A type of leadership and management style attempting to gain the loyalty and support of subordinates by excessively providing for their needs and interests.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Securities held for the production of income in the form of interest and dividends with the aim of controlling or reducing pollution or substances in the environment deemed harmful to human health and natural resources. (Source: ISEP / EFP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A prize or bonus given as an inducement or reward for efforts to reduce the presence of pollution or substances in the environment deemed harmful to human health or natural resources. (Source: ISEP / OED / TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Applying a monetary rate or value at which water can be bought or sold. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A structured simulation or explanation based on observation, experimentation and reasoning that seeks to demonstrate, characterize or explain the actions and interactions of the total surrounding conditions of a given system. (Source: APD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A stage of growth or advancement in any aspect of a community that is defined by or restricted to a particular and usually small district or area. (Source: RHW / ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The gathering and studying of data to determine the projection of demand for an item or service. (Source: ISEP / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Trade which is unimpeded by tariffs, import and export quotas and other measures which obstruct the free movement of goods and services between states. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: One of the world's poorest nations, typically small in area and population, with low per capita incomes, literacy levels and medical standards, subsistence agriculture and a lack of exploitable minerals and competitive industries. (Source: UIA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The connections, associations or involvement of developed nations, found predominantly in the Northern Hemisphere, with developing nations, found predominantly in the Southern Hemisphere. (Source: UIA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act, process or result of calculating. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The mass of unit volume of a substance. (Source: UVAROV)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A distribution or set of geographic observations representing the values of behaviour of a particular phenomenon or characteristic across many locations on the surface of the Earth. (Source: GOOD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A list of record surrogates arranged in order of some attribute expressible in machine-orderable form. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An official periodic count of a population including such information as sex, age, occupation, etc. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An ordered sequence of data samples in numerical form used to predict or demonstrate trends through time and space. (Source: RHW / APD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The canvassing of a representative sample of a large group of people on some question in order to determine the general opinion of a group. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The amount of change in some quantity during a time interval divided by the length of the time interval. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: In time series, that part of the movement which is assigned to the effect of the seasons on the year. (Source: ECHO2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An organized group of persons elected or appointed to discuss scientific matters. (Source: ZINZANa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Research directed toward using knowledge gained by basic research to make things or to create situations that will serve a practical or utilitarian purpose. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Systematic investigation to establish facts or principles concerning a specific scientific subject. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The principles and procedures of soil management and of field crop and special-purpose plant improvement, management, and production. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Ecosystem dominated by the continuous agricultural intervention of man. (Source: ECHO1)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Violent, sudden and destructive change in the environment either affecting or caused by land cultivation or the raising of crops or livestock. (Source: ISEP / APD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The underrating or diminishing in value of agricultural or farming goods and services. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any course destined to promote economic growth, modernization, increase in agricultural production and the creation of a framework in which to fulfill primary needs, such as education, health and supply of water in the rural areas. The attainment of such objectives depends in general on the type of administrative systems proposed for the various programmes and on the national political situation as regards, for instance land tenure, agrarian reform, the disbursement of assistance and food policy. (Source: GREMES)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Science and technology involved in the management of water resources, in the control of erosion and in the removal of unwanted water. (Source: ECHO2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The business, art, or skill of agriculture. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Cultivation of crops for consumption by livestock. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The business of growing fruit and vegetables on a commercial scale. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A fertilized ovule containing an embryo which forms a new plant upon germination. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Use of chemicals in order to avoid damage of crops by insects or weeds. (Source: WRIGHTa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Removal of heavy metals from water by the employment of plants or treatment by which plant organisms act to degrade hazardous organic contaminants or transform hazardous inorganic contaminants to environmentally safe levels in soils, subsurface materials, water, sludges, and residues. (Source: ENVAR / LBL)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The raising, keeping, and care of birds. (Source: AMHER)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Term referring to the systems employed in animal rearing (extensive and intensive). (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The seasonal migration of livestock to suitable grazing grounds. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any naturally occurring inorganic substances with a definite chemical composition and usually of crystalline structure, such as rocks, which are used to stabilize soil, improving its resistance to erosion, texture and permeability. (Source: RHW / SOI)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The removal of water from a marshy area by artificial means, e.g. the introduction of drains. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A traditional farming system that has been used by generations of farmers in tropical forests and the savannah of north and east Africa. It is known to be an ecologically sound form of cultivation, and because the soil is poor in tropical rain forests it is a sustainable method of farming. It is still practised today, primarily in the developing countries. Small areas of bush or forests are cleared and the smaller trees burned. This unlocks the nutrients in the vegetation and gives the soil fertilizer that is easily taken up by plants. A few years later the soil is degraded and the farmer moves on to do the same at another site. The original ground is left fallow for anything up to 20 years so that the forest can regenerate. With the growth in population and in the subsequent need for more farming land to produce food, the method is increasingly being used today to clear large areas of tropical forests for cattle ranching, and in most cases the ground is not left fallow for long enough and, with modern mechanized farming systems, not enough tree stumps or suitable habitats for plant life are left to start the regeneration process. (Source: WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A soft, pure, earthy, fine-textured, usually white to light gray or buff limestone of marine origin, consisting almost wholly (90-99%) of calcite, formed mainly by shallow-water accumulation of calcareous tests of floating microorganisms (chiefly foraminifers) and of comminuted remains of calcareous algae (such as cocoliths and rhabdoliths), set in a structureless matrix of very finely crystalline calcite. The rock is porous, somewhat friable, and only slightly coherent. It may include the remains of bottom-dwelling forms (e.g. ammonites, echinoderms, and pelecypods), and nodules of chert and pyrite. The best known and most widespread chalks are of Cretaceous age, such as those exposed in cliffs on both sides of the English Channel. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Fertilizer materials, natural or synthesized, containing nitrogen available for fixation by vegetation, such as potassium nitrate or ammonium nitrate. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Fertilizer compound or mixture containing available (soluble) phosphate; examples are phosphate rock (phosphorite), superphosphates or triple superphosphates, nitrophosphate, potassium phosphate, or N-P-K mixtures. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A chemical fertilizer containing potassium. Potassium (K) is required by all plant and animal life. Plants require potassium for photosynthesis, osmotic regulation and the activation of enzyme systems. (Source: AGRIC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act or process in which a section of the ground is freed from pollution or any type of contamination, often through natural processes. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The removal of water or any soluble constituents from the soil. Leaching often occurs with soil constituents such as nitrate fertilizers with the result that nitrates end up in potable waters. (Source: PORT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Inorganic materials having a distinct chemical composition, characteristic crystalline structure, colour, and hardness. (Source: DUNSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Plant and animal residue that decomposes and becomes a part of the soil. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A surface stream, or a body of impounded surface water, together with all other such streams and water bodies that are tributary to it and by which a region is drained. An artificial drainage system includes also surface and subsurface conduits. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A system of man-made channels for supplying water to land to allow plants to grow. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Measurement of the quantity of mineral salts found in a soil. Many semi-arid and arid areas are naturally salty. By definition they are areas of substantial water deficit where evapotranspiration exceeds precipitation. Thus, whereas in humid areas there is sufficient water to percolate through the soil and to leach soluble materials from the soil and the rocks into the rivers and hence into the sea, in deserts this is not the case. Salts therefore tend to accumulate. (Source: PHC / GOUD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The monetary or material worth at which buyers and sellers agree to do business for agricultural goods and services. (Source: AGP / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The activity or process of overseeing and preparing for the future physical arrangement and condition of any agricultural or pastoral area, which may involve protecting and developing natural and human resources that affect an area's economic vitality. (Source: RHW / NPH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The administration, promotion, organization and planning for the business or industry of providing information, transportation, entertainment, accommodations and other services to travelers or visitors. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any entity or group of individuals involved with the creation, management and conservation of an extensive area of woodland, often to produce products and benefits such as timber, clean water, biodiversity and recreation. (Source: NCF)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A formulated or systematic method for the supply of material necessities such as tools, gear, provisions or furnishings. (Source: OED / ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The way or means of entry or access. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A place along a route or line at which a train stops to pick up or let off passengers or goods, especially with ancillary buildings and services. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A place along a route or line at which a bus stops for fuel or to pick up or let off passengers or goods, especially with ancillary buildings and services. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The aggregation of components used for building streets, highways and other routes, such as asphalt, concrete, brick, sand and gravel. (Source: ROA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal:
The whole system of railway distribution in a country.
(Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal:
The system of roads through a country.
(Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The science or art of conducting ships or aircraft from one place to another, esp. the method of determining position, course, and distance travelled over the surface of the earth by the principles of geometry and astronomy and by reference to devices (as radar beacons or instruments) designed as aids. (Source: WEBSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Transportation of persons and goods by means of ships travelling along fixed navigation routes. (Source: ZINZANa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Transport in which more than one carrier is used, e.g. road, rail and sea. (Source: ECHO1)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Body of people living in a town or city.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A written or printed text furnishing proposals or procedures for the improvement of living conditions, especially housing, for the inhabitants of a city or densely populated area. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any expanse of land or region located on the outskirts of a city or town. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An unattached dwelling unit inhabited by an adult person plus one or more related persons. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The key element of a comprehensive plan; describes the recommended location and intensity of development for public and private land uses, such as residential, commercial, industrial, recreational and agricultural. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The activity or process of preparing for the future arrangement and condition of an urban center, particularly the development of its physical lay-out, which would include the construction, reconstruction, conversion, alteration or enlargement of buildings and other structures, and the extension or use of undeveloped land. (Source: RHW / ELD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Relation existing between the landowner and the tenant farmer who cultivates the land. (Source: ECHO1)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any of several recent urban developments that constitute small and essentially self-sufficient cities with a planned ordering of residential, industrial, and commercial development. (Source: WEBSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Areas that are subject to the pre-emption right which is a privilege accorded by the government to the actual settler upon a certain limited portion of the public domain, to purchase such tract at a fixed price to the exclusion of all other applicants. (Source: BLACKa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any expanse of land which requires a person or agency with authority to interpose or interfere in how it is used or administrated. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The tearing down of buildings by mechanical means. (Source: MGHa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Branch of engineering dealing with the form and functions of urban areas. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The accurate reestablishment of the form and details of a building, its artifacts, and the site on which it is located, usually as it appeared at a particular time. (Source: HARRIS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A declaration made in a prescribed form before a justice of the peace, notary public, or other person authorized to administer an oath. (Source: DICLAW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A standard which has been approved pursuant to the statutes of the standards bodies with which the Community has concluded agreements. (Source: ECHO2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Documented agreements containing technical specifications or other precise criteria to be used consistently as rules, guidelines, or definitions of characteristics, to ensure that materials, products, processes and services are fit for their purpose. (Source: ISOCH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A government or management prescribed rule that provides detailed or stringent requirements, either directly or by referring to or incorporating the content of a standard, technical specification or code of practice. (Source: PVG)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of collecting and arranging systematically, usually by subject, the laws of a state or country, or the rules and regulations covering a particular area or subject of law or practice. (Source: WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A rule, principle, theory, or tenet of the law, as the doctrine of merger, the doctrine of relation, etc. (Source: WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Rules concerning the movement of goods or persons by sea, railway or road. (Source: WESTSa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A binding rule or body of rules prescribed by a government pertaining to matters of importance to residents of sparsely populated regions, especially agricultural and other economic issues. (Source: RUR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Just claims, legal guarantees or moral principles accorded to sentient, non-human species, including freedom from abuse, consumption, experimentation, use as clothing or performing for human entertainment. (Source: ONE / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The moral, legal or ethical claims of posterity on present people, based on the recognition that the young and unborn are vulnerable to contemporary decision-making, especially decisions having long-term effect on the societies and environment they inherit. (Source: FUT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Rights recognized and protected by law, pertaining to the members of a state. (Source: ZINZANa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Factual information, advice or a written warning communicated to a person by an authorized source, often conveyed because of a legal or administrative rule requiring transmission of such information to all concerned parties. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A memorandum, letter or notice in either paper or electronic format distributed widely throughout an organization or to a general list of interested parties. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) A direction or command of a court. In this sense it is often used synonymously with judgment. 2) The document bearing the seal of the court recording its judgment in a case. (Source: DICLAW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Education in the theories and practices of managing an office, business or organization. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The education, instruction, or discipline pertaining to or connected with the mechanical or industrial arts and the applied sciences. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A body of rules of action or conduct prescribed by controlling authority, and having binding legal force. (Source: WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Official permission granted to individuals or commercial enterprises allowing and regulating by time, location, species, size or amount the wild animals or game that can be killed and taken from lands within a particular jurisdiction. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Authorization required by local governmental bodies for the erection of an enclosed structure or for the major alteration or expansion of an existing edifice. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Official permission granted to individuals or commercial enterprises allowing and regulating by time, location, species, size or amount the fish that can be caught from rivers, lakes or ocean waters within a particular jurisdiction. (Source: BLD / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The form in which proposed statutes, resolutions or special acts are introduced into a legislative body, before they are enacted or passed. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act of regulating; a rule or order prescribed for management or government; a regulating principle; a precept. Rule of order prescribed by superior or competent authority relating to action on those under its control. (Source: BLACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any rebate, abatement, voluntary grant of or a yielding to a demand or claim, typically made by a government or controlling authority to an individual or organization. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Consideration, commentary by argument or informal debate on some issue that is open and of concern to the general populace. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Administrative Act giving the right to take private property for public use. (Source: BLACKa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Generally, land and water owned by individuals or corporations as opposed to the state; in French civil law, any government property capable of being owned by non-public entities, which cannot be seized and which is restricted to the stipulated ownership and use. (Source: BLD / ADM)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Rivers, canals and lakes owned by the state as opposed to individuals or corporations. (Source: BLD / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: eas or ocean areas owned by the state as opposed to individuals or corporations. (Source: BLD / RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An investigation, especially a formal one conducted into a matter of public utility by a body constituted for that purpose by a government, local authority, or other organization. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An investigation, especially a formal one conducted into a matter of public utility by a body constituted for that purpose by a government, local authority, or other organization. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of assigning or transferring authority, decision making or a specific administrative function from one entity to another. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The power or authority of a government to regulate or command industry, organizations, programs, initiatives and individuals. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The rights of use over the property of another; a burden on a piece of land causing the owner to suffer access by another. (Source: DUHA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any act done in violation of those duties which an individual owes to the community, and for the breach of which the law has provided that the offender shall make satisfaction to the public. (Source: BLACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The rules of law governing the procedure by which crimes are investigated, prosecuted, adjudicated, and punish. (Source: BLACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The official and authentic decision of a court of justice upon the respective rights and claims of the parties to an action or suit therein litigated and submitted to its determination. The final decision of the court resolving the dispute and determining the rights and obligations of the parties. The law's last word in a judicial controversy, it being the final determination by a court of the rights of the parties upon matters submitted to it in an action or proceeding. (Source: WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A state of opposition or disagreement between ideas, interests, etc. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A judicial contest, a judicial controversy, a suit at law. (Source: BLACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An independent, specialized judicial tribunal in which judges or officials are authorized by a government agency to conduct hearings and render decisions in proceedings between the government agency and the persons, businesses or other organizations that it regulates. (Source: BLD)

binding.name: label
binding.literal: Court of Justice of the European Communities

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Institution set up under Treaty of Rome to ensure that in interpretation and application of the Treaty the law is observed. It consists of judges from each member state, appointed for 6-year periods, assisted by three Advocates General. It sits in Luxembourg, expressing itself in judgements when called upon to do so in proceedings initiated by member states, institutions of the EC and natural or legal persons. Procedures are generally inquisitorial. (Source: CURZON)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The correct application of law as opposed to arbitrariness. (Source: CURZON)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A judicial examination and determination of issues between parties to action; whether they need issues of law or of fact. A judicial examination, in accordance with law of the land, of a cause, either civil or criminal, of the issues between the parties, whether of law or fact, before a court that has proper jurisdiction. (Source: WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An organ of the government, belonging to the judicial department, whose function is the application of the laws to controversies brought before it and the public administration of justice. The presence of a sufficient number of the members of such a body regularly convened in an authorized place at an appointed time, engaged in the full and regular performance of its functions. A body in the government to which the administration of justice is delegated. A body organized to administer justice, and including both judge and jury. An incorporeal, political being, composed of one or more judges, who sit at fixed times and places, attended by proper officers, pursuant to lawful authority, for the administration of justice. An organized body with defined powers, meeting at certain times and places for the hearing and decision of causes and other matters brought before it, and aided in this, its proper business, by its proper officers, attorneys and counsel to present and manage the business, clerks to record and attest its acts and decisions, and ministerial officers to execute its commands, and secure due order in its proceedings. (Source: WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any agreement which gives rise to relationship of landlord and tenant (real property) or lessor and lessee (real or personal property). Contract for exclusive possession of lands or tenements for determinate period. Contract for possession and profits of lands and tenements either for life, or for certain period of time, or during the pleasure of the parties. (Source: WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The formal assertion in writing of some fact. (Source: BLACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The approval given by the judge of certain acts and agreements for the purpose of rendering them more binding and executory. (Source: WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Information concerning a fact, actually communicated to a person by an authorized person. (Source: BLACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The right of first refusal to purchase land in the event that the grantor of the right should decide to sell.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Acquisition of a personal right to use a way, water, light and air by reason of continuous usage. Prescription is a peremptory and perpetual bar to every species of action, real or personal, when creditor has been silent for a certain time without urging his claim. (Source: WESTS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act, as by power or authority, of arresting or inhibiting the communication of ideas or facts as expressed in a practice, movement, publication or piece of evidence in a court proceeding. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act of assigning or entrusting authority, powers or functions to another as deputy or agent, typically to a subordinate in the administrative structure of an organization or institution. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The forward continuous motion or diffusion of polluting substances, or the rate or quantity in which polluting substances move from one place to another. (Source: MHD / WWC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The sea and the atmosphere are fluids in contact with one another, but in different energy states - the liquid and the gaseous. The free surface boundary between them inhibits, but by no means totally prevents, exchange of mass and energy between the two. Almost all interchanges across this boundary occur most effectively when turbulent conditions prevail. A roughened sea surface, large differences in properties between the water and the air, or an unstable air column that facilitates the transport of air volumes from sea surface to high in the atmosphere. Both heat and water (vapor) tend to migrate across the boundary in the direction from sea to air. Heat is exchanged by three processes: radiation, conduction, and evaporation. The largest net exchange is through evaporation, the process of transferring water from sea to air by vaporization of the water. (Source: PARCOR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Uncontrolled movement, caused by percolation or other processes, of liquid or gaseous polluting materials from an original source area into other parts of an ecosystem. (Source: MHD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Pollution caused by oil spills, by the accidental release of radioactive substances, by the immission in water bodies or in the atmosphere of chemical substances deriving from industrial activities. (Source: DIFIDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Contamination of water, soil and air with pathogen bacteria. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Pollution from widespread activities with no one discrete source, e.g. acid rain, pesticides, urban run-off etc. (Source: HGD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Pollution deriving from all classes of mining operations and having an adverse effect on aquatic life, water supplies and the recreational use of waters. (Source: GILP96a)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Pollution caused by animal or plant material derived from living and dead organisms that may contain pathogenic bacteria and negatively influences the environment. (Source: GILP96a)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Air pollution containing ozone and other reactive chemical compounds formed by the action of sunlight on nitrogen oxides and hydrocarbons, especially those in automobile exhaust.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Pollution by toxic substances that produce a harmful effect on living organisms by physical contact, ingestion, or inhalation.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Discharge of solid, liquid or gaseous waste into a river.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The discharge, dumping or emission of wastes below the surface of the soil. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Measures taken in advance to prevent the occurrence of disasters or similar emergencies. (Source: GUNNa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any precautionary action, procedure or installation conceived or undertaken to guard or defend from harm persons, property or the environment. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: High degree of ionization of an acid in water solution. (Source: KORENa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A normal metabolite that, when present in abnormal concentrations in certain body fluids, can indicate the presence of a particular disease or toxicological condition. (Source: DICCHE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The presence in the environment of living organisms or agents derived by viruses, bacteria, fungi, and mammal and bird antigens that can cause many health effects. (Source: KORENa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The addition or presence of chemicals to, or in, another substance to such a degree as to render it unfit for its intended purpose. Also refers to the result(s) of such an addition or presence. (Source: ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Effects of pollution on living systems. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: That quality of a process that precludes a prior state from being attained again. (Source: MICHa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any goal or target established for a product, service or endeavor that aspires to attain a relatively high grade or level of excellence. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any tiny or very small mass of material that has a definite volume and shape and resists forces that would alter its volume or shape. (Source: OMD / MHD / APD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Regenerative capacity of a system, of soils, water, etc. (Source: ECHO2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The generic name for a device that senses either the absolute value or a change in a physical quantity such as temperature, pressure, flow rate, or pH, or the intensity of light, sound, or ratio waves and converts that change into a useful input signal for an information-gathering system. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Designing, manufacturing, and utilizing physical instruments or instrument systems for detection, observation, measurement, automatic control, automatic computation, communication, or data processing. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Man-made device that orbits the earth, receiving, processing and transmitting signals and generating images such as weather pictures. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Herbicide belonging to the triazine group, widely employed and particularly in maize crops. It is highly toxic for phytoplancton and freshwater algae and, being highly soluble in water, it easily contaminates aquifers. (Source: RAMADE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Essential nutrient of the food supply of plants and the diets of animals. Animals obtain it in nitrogen-containing compounds, particularly aminoacids. Although the atmosphere is nearly 80% gaseous nitrogen, very few organisms have the ability to use it in this form. The higher plants normally obtain it from the soil after microorganisms have converted the nitrogen into ammonia or nitrates, which they can then absorb. This conversion of nitrogen, known as nitrogen fixation, is essential for the formation of amino acids which, in turn, are the building blocks of proteins. (Source: WRIGHT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal:
A substance containing halogen atoms.
(Source: MGHa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A gas at ordinary temperatures; produces an orange-red deposit when cooled to temperatures of liquid air; prepared by passing an electric discharge through a mixture of sulfur vapor and sulfur dioxide at low temperature. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Chemical compound belonging to the polychlorinated biphenyls family, used in the production of electrical equipment which requires dielectric fluid such as power transformers and capacitors, as well as in hydraulic machinery, vacuum pumps, compressors and heat-exchanger fluids. (Source: PZ)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A non-malignant progressive, irreversible, lung disease, characterized by diffuse fibrosis, resulting from the inhalation of asbestos fibers. (Source: CONFER)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The state of being poisoned; the condition produced by a poison which may be swallowed, inhaled, injected, or absorbed through the skin. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The laboratory determination of the effects of substances upon specific living organisms. (Source: GILP96)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The amount of carbon covalently bound in organic compounds in a water sample. (Source: WQA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act or process of simplifying or breaking down a molecule into smaller parts, either naturally or artificially. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Tests, examinations or evaluations performed in a laboratory. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Scale for showing the quality of an environment by indicating the types of organisms present in it (e.g. how clean a river is). (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Substance that can undergo a chemical reaction with oxygen. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The amount of oxygen dissolved in a stream, river or lake is an indication of the degree of health of the stream and its ability to support a balanced aquatic ecosystem. The oxygen comes from the atmosphere by solution and from photosynthesis of water plants. The maximum amount of oxygen that can be held in solution in a stream is termed the saturation concentration and, as it is a function of temperature, the greater the temperature, the less the saturation amount. The discharge of an organic waste to a stream imposes an oxygen demand on the stream. If there is an excessive amount of organic matter, the oxidation of waste by microorganisms will consume oxygen more rapidly than it can be replenished. When this happens, the dissolved oxygen is depleted and results in the death of the higher forms of life. (Source: PORT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The capability of being decomposed by prolonged exposure to light. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Substance incapable of forming a solution, especially in water. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Substance that is not capable of changing from a solid or liquid form to a vapour. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A substance that is not easily converted to another, usually less complex compound. (Source: GILP96a)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A substance capable of readily changing from a solid or liquid form to a vapour; having a high vapour pressure and a low boiling point. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The tendency of a metal to wear away another by chemical attack. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Analysis based on the physical changes associated with chemical reactions. (Source: UVAROVa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) The determination of the different grain size in a granular material. 2) The proportion by weight of particles of different sizes in granular material. (Source: ECHO2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: To cause to discharge from an abscess or wound or to obtain a sample of tissue or organic liquid for examination. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A substance characterized by definite molecular composition. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Material having the ability to generate a sufficient concentration of combustible vapors to produce a flame, if ignited. (Source: LEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Properties that can be perceived by sense organs. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The system that is concerned with the perception of sound, is mediated through the organ of Corti of the ear in mammals or through corresponding sensory receptors of the lagena in lower vertebrates, is normally sensitive in man to sound vibrations between 16 and 27.000 cycles per second but most receptive to those between 2.000 and 5.000 cycles per second, is conducted centrally by the cochlear branch of the auditory nerve, and is coordinated especially in the medial geniculate body. (Source: WEBSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Those structures, including the heart and blood vessels, which provide channels for the flow of blood. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any of a subgroup of the picornaviruses infecting the gastrointestinal tract and discharged in feces, including coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and polioviruses; may be involved in respiratory disease, meningitis, and neurological disease. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The scientific study of the natural processes of animals. (Source: CAMBa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal:
The scientific study of the natural processes of plants.
(Source: CAMBa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The total number of genes or the amount of genetic information possessed by all the reproductive members of a population of sexually reproducing organisms. (Source: ALL2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A unit used to express relative difference on power, usually between acoustic or electric signals, equal to ten times the common logarithm of the ratio of the two level. (Source: AMHER)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The characteristics of a confined space that determines its ability to enable music and speech to be heard clearly within it. (Source: UVAROV)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The range of frequencies occurring in the noise emitted by a source. (Source: UVAROV)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A motion, usually unintentional and often undesirable, of parts of machines and structures. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Noise caused by the movement of large volumes of air and the use of high-pressure air. (Source: CORBIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Noise coming from source other than the noise source being monitored. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Deeply resounding, reverberating noise caused by the friction between car tyres and road surfaces. (Source: CEDa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: General noise from a local source (such as the noise of a factory) which is disturbing to people living in the area. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A formulated or systematic method to prevent the effects of being subjected to loud or harsh sounds. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Power station where the generation of power is provided by the ebb and flow of the tides. The principle is that water collected at high tide behind a barrage is released at low tide to turn a turbine that, in turn, drives a generator. (Source: PORT / BRACK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The free renewable source of energy provided by falling water that drives the turbines. Hydropower is the most important of the regenerable energy sources because of its highest efficiency at the energy conversion. There are two types of hydroelectric power plants: a) run-of-river power plants for the use of affluent water; b) storage power plants (power stations with reservoir) where the influx can be regulated with the help of a reservoir. Mostly greater differences in altitudes are being used, like mountain creeks. Power stations with reservoirs are generally marked by barrages with earth fill dam or concrete dams. Though hydropower generally can be called environmentally acceptable, there exist also some problems: a) change of groundwater level and fill up of the river bed with rubble. b) Risk of dam breaks. c) Great demand for land space for the reservoir. d) Diminution, but partly also increase of value of recreation areas. As the hydropowers of the world are limited, the world energy demand however is rising, finally the share of hydropower will decrease. (Source: PORT / PHC / PZ)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Power station of small size for the generation of energy at local level. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A mill whose power is provided by a large wheel which is turned by moving water, especially a river. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process by which a power plant is finally taken out of operation. (Source: ECHO1a)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: An element that is naturally radioactive. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Nuclear reactor which produces more fissile material than it consumes, using fast-moving neutrons and making plutonium-239 from uranium-238, thereby increasing the reactor's efficiency. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any site or region that is damaged, harmed or made unfit for use by the introduction of unwanted substances, particularly microorganisms, chemicals, toxic and radioactive materials and wastes. (Source: TOE / HMD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Particulate matter suspended in the air. The particulate matter may be in the form of dusts, fumes, or mist. Aerosols in the atmosphere are the form in which pollutants such as smoke are dispersed. (Source: LANDY / PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A gaseous, liquid, or solid fuel that contains an energy content derived from a biological source. The organic matter that makes up living organisms provides a potential source of trapped energy that is beginning to be exploited to supply the ever-increasing energy demand around the world. An example of a biofuel is rapeseed oil, which can be used in place of diesel fuel in modified engines. The methyl ester of this oil, rapeseed methyl ester (RME), can be used in unmodified diesel engines and is sometimes known as biodiesel. Other biofuels include biogas and gasohol. (Source: DICCHE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Reduction of tree population in forests caused by acidic precipitation, forest fires, air pollution, deforestation, pests and diseases of trees, wildlife, etc. (Source: WPR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A colorless liquid, miscible with water, used as a reagent and solvent. Also known as alcohol; ethyl alcohol; grain alcohol. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Pollution caused by gases vented to the atmosphere by internal-combustion-engine driven vehicles.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The sedimentation of dust or fine particles from the atmosphere. (Source: LEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Vehicles that function without emitting pollutants in the atmosphere. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The study of paleoclimates throughout geologic time, and of the causes of their variations, on either a local or a worldwide basis. It involves the interpretation of glacial deposits, fossils and sedimentologic and other types of data. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A climate characterized by hot summers, cold winters, and little rainfall, typical of the interior of a continent. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A climate type which is characterized by insufficient moisture to support appreciable plant life; that is, a climate of extreme aridity. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Climate characterized by constant temperatures, abundant rainfall and a very short dry season. (Source: RAMADE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A type of climate characterized by hot, dry, sunny summers and a winter rainy season; basically, this is the opposite of a monsoon climate. Also known as etesian climate. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Very generally, the climate of relatively high elevations; mountain climates are distinguished by the departure of their characteristics from those of surrounding lowlands, and the one common basis for this distinction is that of atmospheric rarefaction; aside from this, great variety is introduced by differences in latitude, elevation, and exposure to the sun; thus, there exists no single, clearly defined, mountain climate. Also known as highland climate. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A regional climate which is under the predominant influence of the sea, that is, a climate characterized by oceanity; the antithesis of a continental climate. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The climate of the middle latitudes; the climate between the extremes of tropical climate and polar climate. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A climate which is typical of equatorial and tropical regions, that is, one with continually high temperatures and with considerable precipitation, at least during part of the year. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A temperature inversion in the atmosphere in which the temperature, instead of falling, increases with height above the ground. With the colder and heavier air below, there is no tendency to form upward currents and turbulence is suppressed. Inversions are often formed in the late afternoon when the radiation emitted from the ground exceeds that received from the sinking sun. Inversions are also caused by katabatic winds, that is cold winds flowing down the hillside into a valley, and by anticyclones. In inversion layers, both vertical and horizontal diffusion is inhibited and pollutants become trapped, sometimes for long periods. Low-level discharges of pollutants are more readily trapped by inversions than high level dischargers, hence the case for high stacks. Furthermore, high level discharges into an inversion tend to remain at a high level because of the absence of vertical mixing. (Source: GILP96)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A storm caused by strong rising air currents and characterized by thunder and lightning and usually heavy rain or hail. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A coating of ice, generally clear and smooth but usually containing some air pockets, formed on exposed objects by the freezing of a film of supercooled water deposited by rain, drizzle, or fog, or possibly condensed from supercooled water vapour. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of extracting underground water from a source. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The movement of surface water into soil or rock through cracks and pores. (Source: DUNSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Water that occupies pores, cavities, cracks and other spaces in the crustal rocks. It includes water precipitated from the atmosphere which has percolated through the soil, water that has risen from deep magmatic sources liberated during igneous activity and fossil water retained in sedimentary rocks since their formation. The presence of groundwater is necessary for virtually all weathering processes to operate. Phreatic water is synonymous with groundwater and is the most important source of any water supply. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Precautionary actions, procedures or installations undertaken to prevent or reduce harm to the environmental integrity of drainage areas used to catch water, such as reservoirs or basins. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Water table is inherently susceptible to contamination from landuse activities. Remediation is very expensive and often impractical. Prevention of contamination is therefore critical in effective groundwater management. (Source: TECHBA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The total quantity of water flowing from the catchment during the period of the flood. (Source: ECHO2)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The filling or partial filling with silt of a reservoir that receives fine-grained sediment brought in by streams and surface runoff. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The science and technology of measuring specific gravities, particularly of liquids. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The hydrological processes generating river floods have been studied extensively and several modelling concepts have been proposed. The standard procedure for flood forecasting consists of calibrating the parameters of the model of a particular river basin on a representative set of historical hydrometric data and subsequently applying this calibrated model in a real-time environment. (Source: YOUNG)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The configuration or arrangement in plan view of the natural stream courses in an area. It is related to local geologic and geomorphologic features and history. Synonym: drainage pattern. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The scientific study of sedimentary rocks and of the processes by which they were formed; the description, classification, origin, and interpretation of sediments. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: 1) The drainage basin of a stream. 2) An area occupied by a lake and its drainage basin. (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Freshwater in which bathing is explicitly authorised or in which bathing is not prohibited and is traditionally practised by a large number of bathers. Water in such areas must meet specified quality standards relating to chemical, microbiological and physical parameters. (Source: GILP96a)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A body of water that is owned and maintained by a national governmental body or agency. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A body of water that is owned and maintained by an individual or entity other than the national government. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A commonly used term in Scotland and Ireland for a stretch waterlogged, spongy ground, chiefly composed of decaying vegetable matter, especially of rushes, cotton grass, and sphagnum moss. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any mechanical procedure or process where some or all of the salt is removed from water. (Source: LEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Sea waters in which bathing is explicitly authorised or in which bathing is not prohibited and is traditionally practised by a large number of bathers. Water in such areas must meet specified quality standards relating to chemical, microbiological and physical parameters. (Source: GILP96a)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The mouth or outlet of a river, drain, sewer or any other place at which drainage or wastewater is discharged into a body of oceanic water. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The utilization of the ocean for its food resources, mineral resources, and energy and water sources. (Source: PARCORa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A regular movement of marine waves created by wind stress in the open ocean which travels considerable distances away from the generating field and into another wind field. The waves are characterized by relatively smooth, generally unbroken, crests and a fairly regular wavelength, but swell increases in wavelength and decreases in wave height as it moves away from the generating area. Local wind waves may be superimposed upon swell waves as they approach a coastline, thereby creating sharper crests and a choppy sea. (Source: WHIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Contamination of the generally broad portion of a stream near its outlet which is influenced by the tide of the water body into which it flows. Many estuaries have become badly contaminated by wastes that have been generated from heavily populated areas.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The administration or handling of a waterway or a stream of flowing water. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Removing lodged deposits of rock fragments and other debris by water flow at high velocity; used to clean water conduits and drilled boreholes. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A chamber with gates on both ends connecting two sections of a canal or other waterway, to raise or lower the water level in each section. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Cutting down by scythe or machine at intervals the vegetation growth and grasses on banks and berms of irrigation and drainage channels or cropped areas. (Source: ECHO1)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Engineering work which aims at the protection of banks of a river, or slopes of embankments along it, from erosion by the current of flow, from floods, etc. (Source: ECHO1a)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Basin used to hold water in storage. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The drawing of water from a reservoir by means of draining pipes located at the bottom of the basin and controlled by a system of sluices which ensure, if necessary, the emptying of the basin in a given period of time in respect of downstream conditions. (Source: MANCOS)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Complex series of reactions between the water and metal surfaces and materials in which the water is stored or transported. The corrosion process is an oxidation/reduction reaction that returns refined or processed metal to their more stable ore state. With respect to the corrosion potential of drinking water, the primary concerns include the potential presence of toxic metals , such as lead and copper. (Source: WILKES)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Progress in, or betterment of, the environmental condition and integrity of water. (Source: RHW / TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Taste in water can be caused by foreign matter, such as organic compounds, inorganic salts or dissolved gases. These materials may come from domestic, agricultural or natural sources. Some substances found naturally in groundwater, while not necessarily harmful, may impart a disagreeable taste or undesirable property to the water. Magnesium sulphate, sodium sulphate, and sodium chloride are but a few of these. Acceptable waters should be free from any objectionable taste at point of use. (Source: CORBIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A proliferation of a marine green plankton toxic and often fatal to fish, perhaps stimulated by the addition of nutrients. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Matter suspended in a fluid by the upward components of turbulent currents or by colloidal suspension. (Source: DUNSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The degree of dissolved salts in water measured by weight in parts per thousand. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A structure in which water is collected. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A stream of water that is forced up into the air through a small hole, especially for decorative effect or the structure in a lake or pool from which this flows. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Artificial or natural area of water, used for storing water for domestic or industrial use. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The removal of minerals from water by chemical, ion-exchange, or distillation procedures. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A process in which used or spent water is treated at the point of origin or where it was produced, by using a septic tank or some other system to remove or reduce the impact of constituent wastes on human health and the environment. (Source: WQL / WWC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Basin used to hold water which falls as rain during a storm. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal:
Channels for clearing away rain water.
(Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Sewer system having distinct pipes for collecting superficial water and sewage water. (Source: FLGISA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A sewer intended to serve as a sanitary sewer and a storm sewer, or as an industrial sewer and a storm sewer. (Source: JJK)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Addition of air to sewage or water so as to raise its dissolved oxygen level. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of using a natural system or mechanical device to collect, treat and discharge or reclaim wastewater from an individual dwelling without the use of community-wide sewers or a centralised treatment facility. (Source: DWT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A basin in which suspended matter is removed either by quiescent settlement or by continuous flow at high velocity and extended retention time to allow deposition. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A system of secondary sewage treatment which is similar to self-purification action of streams; it is more accurately a biological oxidizing bed; the effluent is placed on the stones in the bed and microorganisms present consume the solids as a food supply. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Wastewater or utilized water from a home, community, farm or industry, which is often discharged after utilization. (Source: WRT / TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The liquid wastes deriving from domestic, commercial and industrial activities of an urban settlement. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Partially or completely treated water or waste water flowing out of a waste treatment plant. (Source: DEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Types of wastewater treatment in which biochemical or bacterial action is intensified to oxidize and stabilize the unstable organic matter present. Examples of this type of treatment use intermittent sand filters, trickling filters, and activated sludge processes and sludge digestion. (Source: WWC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process in which sunlight, bacterial action and oxygen cause self-purification in waste water, Usually taking place in a shallow pond, or system of such ponds. (Source: TOEa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A process in which naturally occurring microorganisms, plants, trees or geophysical processes break down, degrade or filter out hazardous substances or pollutants from a body of water, cleansing and treating contaminated water without human intervention. (Source: OSW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Measures and activities concerning the supply of water, the improvement of efficiency in its use, the reduction of losses and waste, water-saving practices to reduce costs and to slow the depletion of the water supply to ensure future water availability. (Source: EARTH1a)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Centralized recycling centres to which waste materials are brought and where they are separated. (Source: CORBIT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Area where waste material, especially metal, is dumped. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Industry for the transformation of solid waste into useful products. (Source: GRN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of removing dirt, litter or other unsightly materials from shore line property or surrounding areas. (Source: ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Large items of waste material, such as appliances, furniture, large auto parts, trees, branches, stumps, etc. (Source: LANDY)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A primary cell that uses an alkaline electrolyte, usually potassium hydroxide, and delivers about 1.5 volts at much higher current rates than the common carbon-zinc cell. Also known as alkaline-manganese cell. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A direct-current voltage source made up of one or more units that convert chemical, thermal, nuclear, or solar energy into electrical energy. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Wastes resulting from the operations of pollutant removal from industries, cleaning processes, etc. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Discarded material produced in any industrial process for which there is no specified mode of disposal. (Source: INW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Metal material discarded during manufacturing or processing operations which cannot be directly fed back into the operation; Worn or discarded metal materials removed from service at the end of its useful life. (Source: GMR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Waste material resulting from ore extraction that is usually left on the soil surface. (Source: GREMES)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The hulk of a wrecked or stranded ship; a ship dashed against rocks or land and broken or otherwise rendered useless. (Source: ISEP)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Oil which derives from petroleum and is made up of hydrocarbons. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The watery liquid that separates from the curd when the milk is clotted, as in making cheese. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A manner of waste disposal in which refuse or unwanted material is dumped or submerged beneath the surface of a body of water. (Source: RHW)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Dust or other residue left after reducing a material to very small particles. (Source: MHD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Material left over from the treatment of any type of waste. (Source: DEE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any material, solid or semisolid, left after processing in a device designed to reduce waste volume by combustion. (Source: DEE / HMD)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Sludge whose water content has been reduced by physical means. (Source: LEEa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The excess, unusable semi-solids or sediment resulting from a wastewater treatment or industrial process. (Source: RHW / TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any process beyond gravity sedimentation that increases the concentration of solids in sludge with or without the use of chemical flocculants. (Source: WWC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Usually anaerobic sludge digestion, a treatment that stabilizes raw sludge. Fully digested sludge has little readily biodegradable organic matter. It is not smelly and about 50% of the solids are inorganic. Sludge can also be digested aerobically.

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Operations, functions and processes involved in industrial production. (Source: RRDA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Area of land which is no longer usable for cultivation or for any other purpose after having been the site of an industrial plant. (Source: PHCa)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Facility that is forbidden to be disclosed outside a specified ring of secrecy for reasons of national security. (Source: WEBSTE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The act of dismembering the carcass of an animal with the production of organic waste which if improperly disposed cause problems of pollution and fawl smells. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A place where pigs are kept and reared. (Source: CED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The petroleum industry is a complex industry utilizing complex combination of interdependent operations engaged in the storage and transportation, separation of crude molecular constituents, molecular cracking, molecular rebuilding and solvent finishing to produce petrochemical products. Treatment may involve oil separation, precipitation, adsorption, and biological treatment. The refining operations can be divided into four major steps: separation, conversion, treating, and blending. The crude oil is first separated into selected fractions (gasoline, kerosine, fuel oil, etc.). Some of the less valuable products such as heavy naphtha, are converted to products with a greater sale value such as gasoline. The final step is the blending of the refined base stocks with each other and various additive to meet final product specifications. The major pollutants emitted are sulphur oxides, nitrogen oxides, hydrocarbons, carbon monoxide, and malodorous materials. (Source: PZ)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A container or a reservoir for the storage of hydrocarbons. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Boring a hole for extracting oil. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Extraction of crushed rock or gravel screened to sizes for use in road surfaces, concretes, or bituminous mixes. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: A sector of the economy in which an aggregate of enterprises is engaged in the design, manufacture and marketing of mechanical apparatuses for commercial or industrial usage. (Source: SIC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: All interrelated steps of the lumber manufacturing process including tree felling, the removal of tops, branches and bark, the piling and sawing of logs, and the transportation and loading of finished boards or other products. (Source: TIM)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The distribution of settled sewage on a bed of inert granular material through which it is allowed to percolate. In doing so, the effluent is aerated thus allowing aerobic bacteria and fungi to reduce its biochemical oxygen demand. (Source: PORT)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Removal of chlorine from a substance. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The science by which the properties of matter and the sources of power in nature are made useful to humans in structures, machines, and products. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process of deriving methane from any source, including livestock manure, landfills, coal mines, etc. (Source: OED)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The introduction of air into sewage so as to provide aerobic biochemical stabilization during a detention period. (Source: KOREN)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Breakdown of organic material without the presence of oxygen, a treatment which permanently removes the unpleasant odour of many organic wastes so that they can be used on agricultural land. (Source: PHC)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Process that uses microorganisms to decompose organic wastes either into water, carbon dioxide, and simple inorganic substances, or into simpler organic substances, such as aldehydes and acids. The purpose of a biological treatment system is to control the environment for microorganisms so that their growth and activity are enhanced, and provide a means for maintaining high concentration of the microorganisms in contact with the wastes. (Source: PARCOR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Any processing of wastewater, toxic substances or other materials involving a combination of physical and chemical methods, such as physical processes including air-stripping or filtration and chemical processes including coagulation, chlorination or ozonation. (Source: TOE)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Processes that separate components of a waste stream or change the physical form of the waste without altering the chemical structure of the constituent materials. Physical treatment techniques are often used to separate the materials within the waste stream so that they can be reused or detoxified by chemical or biological treatment or destroyed by high-temperature incineration. (Source: PARCOR)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Removal of floating solids and suspended solids, both fine and coarse, from raw sewage. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Stage of the process of waste water treatment: following primary treatment by sedimentation, the second step in most wastewater systems in which biological organisms decompose most of the organic matter into a innocuous, stable form. (Source: CORBIT / WQA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The process which remove pollutants not adequately removed by secondary treatment, particularly nitrogen and phosphorus; accomplished by means of sand filters, microstraining, or other methods (referring to wastewater treatment). (Source: WQA)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Formation of a glassy or noncrystalline material. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: Quarry located below the surface of the earth. (Source: CAMB)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The application of scientific methods and engineering principles to civil engineering problems through acquiring, interpreting, and using knowledge of materials of the crust of the earth. (Source: MGH)

binding.name: definition
binding.literal: The theoretical and applied science of the physical behavior of rocks, representing a "branch of mechanics concerned with the response of rock to the force fields of its physical environment". (Source: BJGEO)

binding.name: definition
